<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<40%>
	You have prevail'd: I will depart in quiet,
	And, in despite of mirth, mean to be merry.
	I know a wench of excellent discourse,
	Pretty and witty, wild and yet, too, gentle:
	There will we dine: this woman that I mean,
	My wife,—but, I protest, without desert,—
	Hath oftentimes upbraided me withal:
	To her will we to dinner. <STAGE DIR>
<To Angelo.>
</STAGE DIR> Get you home,
	And fetch the chain; by this I know 'tis made:
	Bring it, I pray you, to the Porpentine;
	For there's the house: that chain will I bestow,
	Be it for nothing but to spite my wife,
	Upon mine hostess there. Good sir, make haste.
	Since mine own doors refuse to entertain me,
	I'll knock elsewhere, to see if they'll disdain me.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ANGELO>	<41%>
	I'll meet you at that place some hour hence.
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<41%>
	Do so. This jest shall cost me some expense.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 1>


<SCENE 2>
<The Same.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Luciana and Antipholus of Syracuse.>
</STAGE DIR>
<LUCE>	<41%>
	And may it be that you have quite forgot A husband's office? Shall, Antipholus,
	Even in the spring of love, thy love-springs rot?
	Shall love, in building, grow so ruinous?
	If you did wed my sister for her wealth,
	Then, for her wealth's sake use her with more kindness:
	Or, if you like elsewhere, do it by stealth;
	Muffle your false love with some show of blindness;
	Let not my sister read it in your eye;
	Be not thy tongue thy own shame's orator;
	Look sweet, speak fair, become disloyalty;
	Apparel vice like virtue's harbinger;
	Bear a fair presence, though your heart be tainted;
	Teach sin the carriage of a holy saint;
	Be secret-false: what need she be acquainted?
	What simple thief brags of his own attaint?
	'Tis double wrong to truant with your bed,
	And let her read it in thy looks at board:
	Shame hath a bastard fame, well managed;
	Ill deeds are doubled with an evil word.
	Alas! poor women, make us but believe,
	Being compact of credit, that you love us;
	Though others have the arm, show us the sleeve;
	We in your motion turn, and you may move us.
	Then, gentle brother, get you in again;
	Comfort my sister, cheer her, call her wife:
	'Tis holy sport to be a little vain,
	When the sweet breath of flattery conquers strife.
</LUCE>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<42%>
	Sweet mistress,—what your name is else, I know not,
	Nor by what wonder you do hit of mine,—
	Less in your knowledge and your grace you show not
	Than our earth's wonder; more than earth divine.
	Teach me, dear creature, how to think and speak:
	Lay open to my earthy-gross conceit,
	Smother'd in errors, feeble, shallow, weak,
	The folded meaning of your words' deceit.
	Against my soul's pure truth why labour you
	To make it wander in an unknown field?
	Are you a god? would you create me new?
	Transform me then, and to your power I'll yield.
	But if that I am I, then well I know
	Your weeping sister is no wife of mine,
	Nor to her bed no homage do I owe:
	Far more, far more, to you do I decline.
	O! train me not, sweet mermaid, with thy note,
	To drown me in thy sister flood of tears:
	Sing, siren, for thyself, and I will dote:
	Spread o'er the silver waves thy golden hairs,
	And as a bed I'll take them and there lie;
	And, in that glorious supposition think
	He gains by death that hath such means to die:
	Let Love, being light, be drowned if she sink!
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<LUCE>	<44%>
	What! are you mad, that you do reason so?
</LUCE>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<44%>
	Not mad, but mated; how, I do not know.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<LUCE>	<44%>
	It is a fault that springeth from your eye.
</LUCE>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<44%>
	For gazing on your beams; fair sun, being by.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<LUCE>	<44%>
	Gaze where you should, and that will clear your sight.
</LUCE>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<44%>
	As good to wink, sweet love, as look on night.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<LUCE>	<44%>
	Why call you me love? call my sister so.
</LUCE>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<44%>
	Thy sister's sister.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<LUCE>	<44%>
	That's my sister.
</LUCE>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<44%>
	No;
	It is thyself, mine own self's better part;
	Mine eye's clear eye, my dear heart's dearer heart;
	My food, my fortune, and my sweet hope's aim,
	My sole earth's heaven, and my heaven's claim.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<LUCE>	<44%>
	All this my sister is, or else should be.
</LUCE>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<44%>
	Call thyself sister, sweet, for I aim thee.
	Thee will I love and with thee lead my life:
	Thou hast no husband yet nor I no wife.
	Give me thy hand.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<LUCE>	<45%>
	O! soft, sir; hold you still:
	I'll fetch my sister, to get her good will.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

</LUCE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Dromio of Syracuse, hastily.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<45%>
	Why, how now, Dromio! where run'st thou so fast?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<45%>
	Do you know me, sir? am I Dromio? am I your man? am I myself?
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<45%>
	Thou art Dromio, thou art my man, thou art thyself.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<45%>
	I am an ass, I am a woman's man and besides myself.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<45%>
	What woman's man? and how besides thyself?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<45%>
	Marry, sir, besides myself, I am due to a woman; one that claims me, one that haunts me, one that will have me.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<45%>
	What claim lays she to thee?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<45%>
	Marry, sir, such claim as you would lay to your horse; and she would have me as a beast: not that, I being a beast, she would have me; but that she, being a very beastly creature, lays claim to me.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<46%>
	What is she?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<46%>
	A very reverent body; aye, such a one as a man may not speak of, without he say, 'Sir-reverence.' I have but lean luck in the match, and yet is she a wondrous fat marriage.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<46%>
	How dost thou mean a fat marriage?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<46%>
	Marry, sir, she's the kitchen-wench, and all grease; and I know not what use to put her to but to make a lamp of her and run from her by her own light. I warrant her rags and the tallow in them will burn a Poland winter; if she lives till doomsday, she'll burn a week longer than the whole world.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<46%>
	What complexion is she of?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<46%>
	Swart, like my shoe, but her face nothing like so clean kept: for why she sweats; a man may go over shoes in the grime of it.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<46%>
	That's a fault that water will mend.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<47%>
	No, sir, 'tis in grain; Noah's flood could not do it.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<47%>
	What's her name?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<47%>
	Nell, sir; but her name and three quarters,—that is, an ell and three quarters,—will not measure her from hip to hip.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<47%>
	Then she bears some breadth?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<47%>
	No longer from head to foot than from hip to hip: she is spherical, like a globe; I could find out countries in her.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<47%>
	In what part of her body stands Ireland?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<47%>
	Marry, sir, in her buttocks: I found it out by the bogs.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<47%>
	Where Scotland?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<47%>
	I found it by the barrenness; hard in the palm of the hand.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<47%>
	Where France?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<47%>
	In her forehead; armed and reverted, making war against her heir.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<47%>
	Where England?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<47%>
	I looked for the chalky cliffs, but I could find no whiteness in them: but I guess it stood in her chin, by the salt rheum that ran between France and it.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<48%>
	Where Spain?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<48%>
	Faith, I saw not; but I felt it hot in her breath.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<48%>
	Where America, the Indies?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<48%>
	O, sir! upon her nose, all o'er embellished with rubies, carbuncles, sapphires, declining their rich aspect to the hot breath of Spain, who sent whole armadoes of caracks to be ballast at her nose.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<48%>
	Where stood Belgia, the Netherlands?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<48%>
	O, sir! I did not look so low. To conclude, this drudge, or diviner, laid claim to me; call'd me Dromio; swore I was assured to her; told me what privy marks I had about me, as the mark of my shoulder, the mole in my neck, the great wart on my left arm, that I, amazed, ran from her as a witch.
	And, I think, if my breast had not been made of faith and my heart of steel,
	She had transform'd me to a curtal dog and made me turn i' the wheel.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<49%>
	Go hie thee presently post to the road:
	An if the wind blow any way from shore,
	I will not harbour in this town to-night:
	If any bark put forth, come to the mart,
	Where I will walk till thou return to me.
	If every one knows us and we know none,
	'Tis time, I think, to trudge, pack, and be gone.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<49%>
	As from a bear a man would run for life,
	So fly I from her that would be my wife.
</DROMIO SYR.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<49%>
	There's none but witches do inhabit here,
	And therefore 'tis high time that I were hence.
	She that doth call me husband, even my soul
	Doth for a wife abhor; but her fair sister,
	Possess'd with such a gentle sovereign grace,
	Of such enchanting presence and discourse,
	Hath almost made me traitor to myself:
	But, lest myself be guilty to self-wrong,
	I'll stop mine ears against the mermaid's song.

</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Angelo.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ANGELO>	<50%>
	Master Antipholus!
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<50%>
	Ay, that's my name.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<ANGELO>	<50%>
	I know it well, sir: lo, here is the chain.
	I thought to have ta'en you at the Porpentine;
	The chain unfinish'd made me stay thus long.
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<50%>
	What is your will that I shall do with this?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<ANGELO>	<50%>
	What please yourself, sir: I have made it for you.
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<50%>
	Made it for me, sir! I bespoke it not
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<ANGELO>	<50%>
	Not once, nor twice, but twenty times you have.
	Go home with it and please your wife withal;
	And soon at supper-time I'll visit you,
	And then receive my money for the chain.
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<50%>
	I pray you, sir, receive the money now,
	For fear you ne'er see chain nor money more.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<ANGELO>	<50%>
	You are a merry man, sir: fare you well.
</ANGELO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit, leaving the chain.>
</STAGE DIR>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<50%>
	What I should think of this, I cannot tell:
	But this I think, there's no man is so vain
	That would refuse so fair an offer'd chain.
	I see, a man here needs not live by shifts,
	When in the streets he meets such golden gifts.
	I'll to the mart, and there for Dromio stay:
	If any ship put out, then straight away.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

</SCENE 2>

</ACT 3>

<ACT 4>


<SCENE 1>
<A Public Place.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Second Merchant, Angelo, and an Officer.>
</STAGE DIR>
<MERCHANT>	<51%>
	You know since Pentecost the sum is due,
	And since I have not much importun'd you;
	Nor now I had not, but that I am bound
	To Persia, and want guilders for my voyage:
	Therefore make present satisfaction,
	Or I'll attach you by this officer.
</MERCHANT>

<ANGELO>	<51%>
	Even just the sum that I do owe to you
	Is growing to me by Antipholus;
	And in the instant that I met with you
	He had of me a chain: at five o'clock
	I shall receive the money for the same.
	Pleaseth you walk with me down to his house,
	I will discharge my bond, and thank you too.

</ANGELO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Antipholus of Ephesus and Dromio of Ephesus from the Courtezan's.>
</STAGE DIR>
<OFFICER>	<52%>
	That labour may you save: see where he comes.
</OFFICER>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<52%>
	While I go to the goldsmith's house, go thou
	And buy a rope's end, that I will bestow
	Among my wife and her confederates,
	For locking me out of my doors by day.
	But soft! I see the goldsmith. Get thee gone;
	Buy thou a rope, and bring it home to me.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<52%>
	I buy a thousand pound a year: I buy a rope!
</DROMIO EPH.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<52%>
	A man is well holp up that trusts to you:
	I promised your presence and the chain;
	But neither chain nor goldsmith came to me.
	Belike you thought our love would last too long,
	If it were chain'd together, and therefore came not.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ANGELO>	<52%>
	Saving your merry humour, here's the note
	How much your chain weighs to the utmost carat.
	The fineness of the gold, and chargeful fashion,
	Which doth amount to three odd ducats more
	Than I stand debted to this gentleman:
	I pray you see him presently discharg'd,
	For he is bound to sea and stays but for it.
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<53%>
	I am not furnish'd with the present money;
	Besides, I have some business in the town.
	Good signior, take the stranger to my house,
	And with you take the chain, and bid my wife
	Disburse the sum on the receipt thereof:
	Perchance I will be there as soon as you.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ANGELO>	<53%>
	Then, you will bring the chain to her yourself?
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<53%>
	No; bear it with you, lest I come not time enough.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ANGELO>	<53%>
	Well, sir, I will. Have you the chain about you?
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<53%>
	An if I have not, sir, I hope you have,
	Or else you may return without your money.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ANGELO>	<53%>
	Nay, come, I pray you, sir, give me the chain:
	Both wind and tide stays for this gentleman,
	And I, to blame, have held him here too long.
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<54%>
	Good Lord! you use this dalliance to excuse
	Your breach of promise to the Porpentine.
	I should have child you for not bringing it,
	But, like a shrew, you first begin to brawl.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<MERCHANT>	<54%>
	The hour steals on; I pray you, sir, dispatch.
</MERCHANT>

<ANGELO>	<54%>
	You hear how he importunes me: the chain!
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<54%>
	Why, give it to my wife and fetch your money.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ANGELO>	<54%>
	Come, come; you know I gave it you even now.
	Either send the chain or send by me some token.
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<54%>
	Fie! now you run this humour out of breath.
	Come, where's the chain? I pray you, let me see it.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<MERCHANT>	<54%>
	My business cannot brook this dalliance.
	Good sir, say whe'r you'll answer me or no:
	If not, I'll leave him to the officer.
</MERCHANT>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<54%>
	I answer you! what should I answer you?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ANGELO>	<54%>
	The money that you owe me for the chain.
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<55%>
	I owe you none till I receive the chain.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ANGELO>	<55%>
	You know I gave it you half an hour since.
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<55%>
	You gave me none: you wrong me much to say so.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ANGELO>	<55%>
	You wrong me more, sir, in denying it:
	Consider how it stands upon my credit.
</ANGELO>

<MERCHANT>	<55%>
	Well, officer, arrest him at my suit.
</MERCHANT>

<OFFICER>	<55%>
	I do;
	And charge you in the duke's name to obey me.
</OFFICER>

<ANGELO>	<55%>
	This touches me in reputation.
	Either consent to pay this sum for me,
	Or I attach you by this officer.
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<55%>
	Consent to pay thee that I never had!
	Arrest me, foolish fellow, if thou dar'st.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ANGELO>	<55%>
	Here is thy fee: arrest him, officer.
	I would not spare my brother in this case,
	If he should scorn me so apparently.
</ANGELO>

<OFFICER>	<55%>
	I do arrest you, sir: you hear the suit.
</OFFICER>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<55%>
	I do obey thee till I give thee bail.
	But, sirrah, you shall buy this sport as dear
	As all the metal in your shop will answer.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ANGELO>	<56%>
	Sir, sir, I shall have law in Ephesus,
	To your notorious shame, I doubt it not.

</ANGELO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Dromio of Syracuse.>
</STAGE DIR>
<DROMIO SYR.>	<56%>
	Master, there is a bark of Epidamnum
	That stays but till her owner comes aboard,
	And then she bears away. Our fraughtage, sir,
	I have convey'd aboard, and I have bought
	The oil, the balsamum, and aqua-vitæ.
	The ship is in her trim; the merry wind
	Blows fair from land; they stay for nought at all
	But for their owner, master, and yourself.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<56%>
	How now! a madman! Why, thou peevish sheep,
	What ship of Epidamnum stays for me?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<56%>
	A ship you sent me to, to hire waftage.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<56%>
	Thou drunken slave, I sent thee for a rope;
	And told thee to what purpose, and what end.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<56%>
	You sent me for a rope's end as soon:
	You sent me to the bay, sir, for a bark.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<57%>
	I will debate this matter at more leisure,
	And teach your ears to list me with more heed.
	To Adriana, villain, hie thee straight;
	Give her this key, and tell her, in the desk
	That's cover'd o'er with Turkish tapestry,
	There is a purse of ducats: let her send it.
	Tell her I am arrested in the street,
	And that shall bail me. Hie thee, slave, be gone!
	On, officer, to prison till it come.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Merchant, Angelo, Officer, and Antipholus of Ephesus.>
</STAGE DIR>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<57%>
	To Adriana! that is where we din'd,
	Where Dowsabel did claim me for her husband:
	She is too big, I hope, for me to compass.
	Thither I must, although against my will,
	For servants must their masters' minds fulfil.
</DROMIO SYR.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 1>


<SCENE 2>
<A Room in the House of Antipholus of Ephesus.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Adriana and Luciana.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ADRIANA>	<58%>
	Ah! Luciana, did he tempt thee so?
	Mights thou perceive austerely in his eye
	That he did plead in earnest? yea or no?
	Look'd he or red or pale? or sad or merrily?
	What observation mad'st thou in this case
	Of his heart's meteors tilting in his face?
</ADRIANA>

<LUCE>	<58%>
	First he denied you had in him no right.
</LUCE>

<ADRIANA>	<58%>
	He meant he did me none; the more my spite.
</ADRIANA>

<LUCE>	<58%>
	Then swore he that he was a stranger here.
</LUCE>

<ADRIANA>	<58%>
	And true he swore, though yet forsworn he were.
</ADRIANA>

<LUCE>	<58%>
	Then pleaded I for you.
</LUCE>

<ADRIANA>	<58%>
	And what said he?
</ADRIANA>

<LUCE>	<58%>
	That love I begg'd for you he begg'd of me.
</LUCE>

<ADRIANA>	<58%>
	With what persuasion did he tempt thy love?
</ADRIANA>

<LUCE>	<58%>
	With words that in an honest suit might move.
	First, he did praise my beauty, then my speech.
</LUCE>

<ADRIANA>	<58%>
	Didst speak him fair?
</ADRIANA>

<LUCE>	<58%>
	Have patience, I beseech.
</LUCE>

<ADRIANA>	<58%>
	I cannot, nor I will not hold me still:
	My tongue, though not my heart, shall have his will.
	He is deformed, crooked, old and sere,
	Ill-fac'd, worse bodied, shapeless every where:
	Vicious, ungentle, foolish, blunt, unkind,
	Stigmatical in making, worse in mind.
</ADRIANA>

<LUCE>	<59%>
	Who would be jealous then, of such a one?
	No evil lost is wail'd when it is gone.
</LUCE>

<ADRIANA>	<59%>
	Ah! but I think him better than I say,
	And yet would herein others' eyes were worse.
	Far from her nest the lapwing cries away:
	My heart prays for him, though my tongue do curse.

</ADRIANA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Dromio of Syracuse.>
</STAGE DIR>
<DROMIO SYR.>	<59%>
	Here, go: the desk! the purse! sweet, now, make haste.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<LUCE>	<59%>
	How hast thou lost thy breath?
</LUCE>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<59%>
	By running fast.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ADRIANA>	<59%>
	Where is thy master, Dromio? is he well?
</ADRIANA>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<59%>
	No, he's in Tartar limbo, worse than hell.
	A devil in an everlasting garment hath him,
	One whose hard heart is button'd up with steel;
	A fiend, a fairy, pitiless and rough;
	A wolf, nay, worse, a fellow all in buff;
	A back-friend, a shoulder-clapper, one that countermands
	The passages of alleys, creeks and narrow lands;
	A hound that runs counter and yet draws dryfoot well;
	One that, before the judgment, carries poor souls to hell.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ADRIANA>	<60%>
	Why, man, what is the matter?
</ADRIANA>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<60%>
	I do not know the matter: he is 'rested on the case.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ADRIANA>	<60%>
	What, is he arrested? tell me at whose suit.
</ADRIANA>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<60%>
	I know not at whose suit he is arrested well;
	But he's in a suit of buff which 'rested him, that can I tell.
	Will you send him, mistress, redemption, the money in his desk?
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ADRIANA>	<60%>
	Go fetch it, sister.—<STAGE DIR>
<Exit Luciana.>
</STAGE DIR> This I wonder at:
	That he, unknown to me, should be in debt:
	Tell me, was he arrested on a band?
</ADRIANA>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<60%>
	Not on a band, but on a stronger thing;
	A chain, a chain. Do you not hear it ring?
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ADRIANA>	<61%>
	What, the chain?
</ADRIANA>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<61%>
	No, no, the bell: 'tis time that I were gone:
	It was two ere I left him, and now the clock strikes one.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ADRIANA>	<61%>
	The hours come back! that did I never hear.
</ADRIANA>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<61%>
	O yes; if any hour meet a sergeant, a' turns back for very fear.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ADRIANA>	<61%>
	As if Time were in debt! how fondly dost thou reason!
</ADRIANA>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<61%>
	Time is a very bankrupt, and owes more than he's worth to season.
	Nay, he's a thief too: have you not heard men say,
	That Time comes stealing on by night and day?
	If Time be in debt and theft, and a sergeant in the way,
	Hath he not reason to turn back an hour in a day?

</DROMIO SYR.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Re-enter Luciana.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ADRIANA>	<61%>
	Go, Dromio: there's the money, bear it straight,
	And bring thy master home immediately.
	Come, sister; I am press'd down with conceit; Conceit, my comfort and my injury.
</ADRIANA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 2>


<SCENE 3>
<A Public Place.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Antipholus of Syracuse.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<62%>
	There's not a man I meet but doth salute me,
	As if I were their well acquainted friend;
	And every one doth call me by my name.
	Some tender money to me; some invite me;
	Some other give me thanks for kindnesses;
	Some offer me commodities to buy:
	Even now a tailor call'd me in his shop
	And show'd me silks that he had bought for me,
	And therewithal, took measure of my body.
	Sure these are but imaginary wiles,
	And Lapland sorcerers inhabit here.

</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Dromio of Syracuse.>
</STAGE DIR>
<DROMIO SYR.>	<62%>
	Master, here's the gold you sent me for.
	What! have you got the picture of old Adam new apparelled?
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<62%>
	What gold is this? What Adam dost thou mean?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<62%>
	Not that Adam that kept the Paradise, but that Adam that keeps the prison: he that goes in the calf's skin that was killed for the Prodigal: he that came behind you, sir, like an evil angel, and bid you forsake your liberty.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<63%>
	I understand thee not.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<63%>
	No? why, 'tis a plain case: he that went, like a base-viol, in a case of leather; the man, sir, that, when gentlemen are tired, gives them a fob, and 'rests them; he, sir, that takes pity on decayed men and gives them suits of durance; he that sets up his rest to do more exploits with his mace than a morris-pike.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<63%>
	What, thou meanest an officer?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<63%>
	Ay, sir, the sergeant of the band; he that brings any man to answer it that breaks his band; one that thinks a man always going to bed, and says, 'God give you good rest!'
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<63%>
	Well, sir, there rest in your foolery. Is there any ship puts forth to-night? may we be gone?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<64%>
	Why, sir, I brought you word an hour since that the bark Expedition put forth to-night; and then were you hindered by the sergeant to tarry for the hoy Delay. Here are the angels that you sent for to deliver you.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<64%>
	The fellow is distract, and so am I;
	And here we wander in illusions:
	Some blessed power deliver us from hence!

</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter a Courtezan.>
</STAGE DIR>
<COURTIER>	<64%>
	Well met, well met, Master Antipholus.
	I see, sir, you have found the goldsmith now:
	Is that the chain you promis'd me to-day?
</COURTIER>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<64%>
	Satan, avoid! I charge thee tempt me not!
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<64%>
	Master, is this Mistress Satan?
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<64%>
	It is the devil.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<64%>
	Nay, she is worse, she is the devil's dam, and here she comes in the habit of a light wench: and thereof comes that the wenches say, 'God damn me;' that's as much as to say, 'God make me a light wench.' It is written, they appear to men like angels of light: light is an effect of fire, and fire will burn; ergo, light wenches will burn. Come not near her.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<COURTIER>	<65%>
	Your man and you are marvellous merry, sir. Will you go with me? we'll mend our dinner here.
</COURTIER>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<65%>
	Master, if you do, expect spoon-meat, so bespeak a long spoon.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<65%>
	Why, Dromio?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<65%>
	Marry, he must have a long spoon that must eat with the devil.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<65%>
	Avoid thee, fiend! what tell'st thou me of supping?
	Thou art, as you are all, a sorceress:
	I conjure thee to leave me and be gone.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<COURTIER>	<65%>
	Give me the ring of mine you had at dinner,
	Or, for my diamond, the chain you promis'd,
	And I'll be gone, sir, and not trouble you.
</COURTIER>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<65%>
	Some devils ask but the parings of one's nail,
	A rush, a hair, a drop of blood, a pin,
	A nut, a cherry-stone;
	But she, more covetous, would have a chain.
	Master, be wise: an if you give it her,
	The devil will shake her chain and fright us with it.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<COURTIER>	<66%>
	I pray you, sir, my ring, or else the chain:
	I hope you do not mean to cheat me so.
</COURTIER>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<66%>
	Avaunt, thou witch! Come, Dromio, let us go.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<66%>
	'Fly pride,' says the peacock: mistress, that you know.
</DROMIO SYR.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Dromio of Syracuse.>
</STAGE DIR>

<COURTIER>	<66%>
	Now, out of doubt, Antipholus is mad,
	Else would he never so demean himself.
	A ring he hath of mine worth forty ducats,
	And for the same he promis'd me a chain:
	Both one and other he denies me now.
	The reason that I gather he is mad,
	Besides this present instance of his rage,
	Is a mad tale he told to-day at dinner,
	Of his own doors being shut against his entrance
	Belike his wife, acquainted with his fits,
	On purpose shut the doors against his way.
	My way is now to hie home to his house,
	And tell his wife, that, being lunatic,
	He rush'd into my house, and took perforce
	My ring away. This course I fittest choose,
	For forty ducats is too much to lose.
</COURTIER>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 3>


<SCENE 4>
<A Street.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Antipholus of Ephesus and the Officer.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<67%>
	Fear me not, man; I will not break away:
	I'll give thee, ere I leave thee, so much money,
	To warrant thee, as I am 'rested for.
	My wife is in a wayward mood to-day,
	And will not lightly trust the messenger.
	That I should be attach'd in Ephesus,
	I tell you, 'twill sound harshly in her ears.

<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Dromio of Ephesus with a rope's end.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Here comes my man: I think he brings the money.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>
	How now, sir! have you that I sent you for?
<DROMIO EPH.>	<67%>
	Here's that, I warrant you, will pay them all.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<68%>
	But where's the money?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<68%>
	Why, sir, I gave the money for the rope.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<68%>
	Five hundred ducats, villain, for a rope?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<68%>
	I'll serve you, sir, five hundred at the rate.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<68%>
	To what end did I bid thee hie thee home?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<68%>
	To a rope's end, sir; and to that end am I return'd.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<68%>
	And to that end, sir, I will welcome you.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Beats him.>
</STAGE DIR>

<OFFICER>	<68%>
	Good sir, be patient.
</OFFICER>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<68%>
	Nay, 'tis for me to be patient; I am in adversity.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<OFFICER>	<68%>
	Good now, hold thy tongue.
</OFFICER>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<68%>
	Nay, rather persuade him to hold his hands.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<68%>
	Thou whoreson, senseless villain!
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<68%>
	I would I were senseless, sir, that I might not feel your blows.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<68%>
	Thou art sensible in nothing but blows, and so is an ass.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<68%>
	I am an ass indeed; you may prove it by my long ears. I have served him from the hour of my nativity to this instant, and have nothing at his hands for my service but blows. When I am cold, he heats me with beating; when I am warm, he cools me with beating; I am waked with it when I sleep; raised with it when I sit; driven out of doors with it when I go from home; welcomed home with it when I return; nay, I bear it on my shoulders, as a beggar wont her brat; and, I think, when he hath lamed me, I shall beg with it from door to door.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<69%>
	Come, go along; my wife is coming yonder.

</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Adriana, Luciana, the Courtezan, and Pinch.>
</STAGE DIR>
<DROMIO EPH.>	<69%>
	Mistress, respice finem, respect your end; or rather, to prophesy like the parrot, 'Beware the rope's end.'
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<69%>
	Wilt thou still talk?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Beats him.>
</STAGE DIR>

<COURTIER>	<69%>
	How say you now? is not your husband mad?
</COURTIER>

<ADRIANA>	<70%>
	His incivility confirms no less.
	Good Doctor Pinch, you are a conjurer;
	Establish him in his true sense again,
	And I will please you what you will demand.
</ADRIANA>

<LUCE>	<70%>
	Alas! how fiery and how sharp he looks.
</LUCE>

<COURTIER>	<70%>
	Mark how he trembles in his ecstasy!
</COURTIER>

<PINCH>	<70%>
	Give me your hand and let me feel your pulse.
</PINCH>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<70%>
	There is my hand, and let it feel your ear.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Strikes him.>
</STAGE DIR>

<PINCH>	<70%>
	I charge thee, Satan, hous'd within this man,
	To yield possession to my holy prayers,
	And to thy state of darkness hie thee straight:
	I conjure thee by all the saints in heaven.
</PINCH>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<70%>
	Peace, doting wizard, peace! I am not mad.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ADRIANA>	<70%>
	O! that thou wert not, poor distressed soul!
</ADRIANA>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<70%>
	You minion, you, are these your customers?
	Did this companion with the saffron face
	Revel and feast it at my house to-day,
	Whilst upon me the guilty doors were shut
	And I denied to enter in my house?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ADRIANA>	<71%>
	O husband, God doth know you din'd at home;
	Where would you had remain'd until this time.
	Free from these slanders and this open shame!
</ADRIANA>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<71%>
	Din'd at home! Thou villain, what say'st thou?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<71%>
	Sir, sooth to say, you did not dine at home.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<71%>
	Were not my doors lock'd up and I shut out?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<71%>
	Perdy, your doors were lock'd and you shut out.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<71%>
	And did not she herself revile me there?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<71%>
	Sans fable, she herself revil'd you there.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<71%>
	Did not her kitchen-maid rail, taunt, and scorn me?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<71%>
	Certes, she did; the kitchen-vestal scorn'd you.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<71%>
	And did not I in rage depart from thence?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<71%>
	In verity you did: my bones bear witness,
	That since have felt the vigour of his rage.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ADRIANA>	<71%>
	Is't good to soothe him in these contraries?
</ADRIANA>

<PINCH>	<72%>
	It is no shame: the fellow finds his vein,
	And, yielding to him humours well his frenzy.
</PINCH>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<72%>
	Thou hast suborn'd the goldsmith to arrest me.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ADRIANA>	<72%>
	Alas! I sent you money to redeem you,
	By Dromio here, who came in haste for it.
</ADRIANA>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<72%>
	Money by me! heart and good will you might;
	But surely, master, not a rag of money.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<72%>
	Went'st not thou to her for a purse of ducats?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ADRIANA>	<72%>
	He came to me, and I deliver'd it.
</ADRIANA>

<LUCE>	<72%>
	And I am witness with her that she did.
</LUCE>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<72%>
	God and the rope-maker bear me witness
	That I was sent for nothing but a rope!
</DROMIO EPH.>

<PINCH>	<72%>
	Mistress, both man and master is possess'd:
	I know it by their pale and deadly looks.
	They must be bound and laid in some dark room.
</PINCH>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<72%>
	Say, wherefore didst thou lock me forth to-day?
	And why dost thou deny the bag of gold?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ADRIANA>	<72%>
	I did not, gentle husband, lock thee forth.
</ADRIANA>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<73%>
	And, gentle master, I receiv'd no gold;
	But I confess, sir, that we were lock'd out.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ADRIANA>	<73%>
	Dissembling villain! thou speak'st false in both.
</ADRIANA>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<73%>
	Dissembling harlot! thou art false in all;
	And art confederate with a damned pack
	To make a loathsome abject scorn of me;
	But with these nails I'll pluck out those false eyes
	That would behold in me this shameful sport.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ADRIANA>	<73%>
	O! bind him, bind him, let him not come near me.
</ADRIANA>

<PINCH>	<73%>
	More company! the fiend is strong within him.
</PINCH>

<LUCE>	<73%>
	Ay me! poor man, how pale and wan he looks!

</LUCE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter three or four and bind Antipholus of Ephesus.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<73%>
	What, will you murder me? Thou gaoler, thou,
	I am thy prisoner: wilt thou suffer them
	To make a rescue?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<OFFICER>	<73%>
	Masters, let him go:
	He is my prisoner, and you shall not have him.
</OFFICER>

<PINCH>	<74%>
	Go bind this man, for he is frantic too.
</PINCH>
<STAGE DIR>
<They bind Dromio of Ephesus.>
</STAGE DIR>

<ADRIANA>	<74%>
	What wilt thou do, thou peevish officer?
	Hast thou delight to see a wretched man
	Do outrage and displeasure to himself?
</ADRIANA>

<OFFICER>	<74%>
	He is my prisoner: if I let him go,
	The debt he owes will be requir'd of me.
</OFFICER>

<ADRIANA>	<74%>
	I will discharge thee ere I go from thee:
	Bear me forthwith unto his creditor,
	And, knowing how the debt grows, I will pay it.
	Good Master doctor, see him safe convey'd
	Home to my house. O most unhappy day!
</ADRIANA>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<74%>
	O most unhappy strumpet!
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<74%>
	Master, I am here enter'd in bond for you.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<74%>
	Out on thee, villain! wherefore dost thou mad me?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<74%>
	Will you be bound for nothing? be mad, good master; cry, 'the devil!'
</DROMIO EPH.>

<LUCE>	<74%>
	God help, poor souls! how idly do they talk.
</LUCE>

<ADRIANA>	<74%>
	Go bear him hence. Sister, go you with me.—
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Pinch and Assistants with Antipholus of Ephesus and Dromio of Ephesus.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Say now, whose suit is he arrested at?
</ADRIANA>

<OFFICER>	<75%>
	One Angelo, a goldsmith; do you know him?
</OFFICER>

<ADRIANA>	<75%>
	I know the man. What is the sum he owes?
</ADRIANA>

<OFFICER>	<75%>
	Two hundred ducats.
</OFFICER>

<ADRIANA>	<75%>
	Say, how grows it due?
</ADRIANA>

<OFFICER>	<75%>
	Due for a chain your husband had of him.
</OFFICER>

<ADRIANA>	<75%>
	He did bespeak a chain for me, but had it not.
</ADRIANA>

<COURTIER>	<75%>
	When as your husband all in rage, to-day
	Came to my house, and took away my ring,—
	The ring I saw upon his finger now,—
	Straight after did I meet him with a chain.
</COURTIER>

<ADRIANA>	<75%>
	It may be so, but I did never see it.
	Come, gaoler, bring me where the goldsmith is:
	I long to know the truth hereof at large.

</ADRIANA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Antipholus of Syracuse and Dromio of Syracuse, with rapiers drawn.>
</STAGE DIR>
<LUCE>	<75%>
	God, for thy mercy! they are loose again.
</LUCE>

<ADRIANA>	<76%>
	And come with naked swords. Let's call more help
	To have them bound again.
</ADRIANA>

<OFFICER>	<76%>
	Away! they'll kill us.
</OFFICER>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Adriana, Luciana, and Officer.>
</STAGE DIR>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<76%>
	I see, these witches are afraid of swords.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<76%>
	She that would be your wife now ran from you.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<76%>
	Come to the Centaur; fetch our stuff from thence:
	I long that we were safe and sound aboard.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<76%>
	Faith, stay here this night, they will surely do us no harm; you saw they speak us fair, give us gold: methinks they are such a gentle nation, that, but for the mountain of mad flesh that claims marriage of me, I could find in my heart to stay here still, and turn witch.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<76%>
	I will not stay to-night for all the town;
	Therefore away, to get our stuff aboard.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

</SCENE 4>

</ACT 4>

<ACT 5>


<SCENE 1>
<A Street before an Abbey.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Merchant and Angelo.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ANGELO>	<77%>
	I am sorry, sir, that I have hinder'd you;
	But, I protest, he had the chain of me,
	Though most dishonestly he doth deny it.
</ANGELO>

<MERCHANT>	<77%>
	How is the man esteem'd here in the city?
</MERCHANT>

<ANGELO>	<77%>
	Of very reverend reputation, sir,
	Of credit infinite, highly belov'd,
	Second to none that lives here in the city:
	His word might bear my wealth at any time.
</ANGELO>

<MERCHANT>	<77%>
	Speak softly: yonder, as I think, he walks.

</MERCHANT>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Antipholus of Syracuse and Dromio of Syracuse.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ANGELO>	<77%>
	'Tis so; and that self chain about his neck
	Which he forswore most monstrously to have.
	Good sir, draw near to me, I'll speak to him.
	Signior Antipholus, I wonder much
	That you would put me to this shame and trouble;
	And not without some scandal to yourself,
	With circumstance and oaths so to deny
	This chain which now you wear so openly:
	Beside the charge, the shame, imprisonment,
	You have done wrong to this my honest friend,
	Who, but for staying on our controversy,
	Had hoisted sail and put to sea to-day.
	This chain you had of me; can you deny it?
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<78%>
	I think I had: I never did deny it.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<MERCHANT>	<78%>
	Yes, that you did, sir, and forswore it too.
</MERCHANT>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<78%>
	Who heard me to deny it or forswear it?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<MERCHANT>	<78%>
	These ears of mine, thou know'st, did hear thee.
	Fie on thee, wretch! 'tis pity that thou liv'st
	To walk where any honest men resort.
</MERCHANT>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<78%>
	Thou art a villain to impeach me thus:
	I'll prove mine honour and mine honesty
	Against thee presently, if thou dar'st stand.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<MERCHANT>	<78%>
	I dare, and do defy thee for a villain.
<STAGE DIR>
<They draw.>
</STAGE DIR>

</MERCHANT>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Adriana, Luciana, Courtezan, and Others.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ADRIANA>	<79%>
	Hold! hurt him not, for God's sake! he is mad.
	Some get within him, take his sword away.
	Bind Dromio too, and bear them to my house.
</ADRIANA>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<79%>
	Run, master, run; for God's sake, take a house!
	This is some priory: in, or we are spoil'd.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Dromio of Syracuse to the Abbey.>
</STAGE DIR>

</DROMIO SYR.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter the Abbess.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ABBESS>	<79%>
	Be quiet, people. Wherefore throng you hither?
</ABBESS>

<ADRIANA>	<79%>
	To fetch my poor distracted husband hence.
	Let us come in, that we may bind him fast,
	And bear him home for his recovery.
</ADRIANA>

<ANGELO>	<79%>
	I knew he was not in his perfect wits.
</ANGELO>

<MERCHANT>	<79%>
	I am sorry now that I did draw on him.
</MERCHANT>

<ABBESS>	<79%>
	How long hath this possession held the man?
</ABBESS>

<ADRIANA>	<79%>
	This week he hath been heavy, sour, sad,
	And much different from the man he was;
	But, till this afternoon his passion
	Ne'er brake into extremity of rage.
</ADRIANA>

<ABBESS>	<80%>
	Hath he not lost much wealth by wrack of sea?
	Buried some dear friend? Hath not else his eye
	Stray'd his affection in unlawful love?
	A sin prevailing much in youthful men,
	Who give their eyes the liberty of gazing.
	Which of these sorrows is he subject to?
</ABBESS>

<ADRIANA>	<80%>
	To none of these, except it be the last;
	Namely, some love that drew him oft from home.
</ADRIANA>

<ABBESS>	<80%>
	You should for that have reprehended him.
</ABBESS>

<ADRIANA>	<80%>
	Why, so I did.
</ADRIANA>

<ABBESS>	<80%>
	Ay, but not rough enough.
</ABBESS>

<ADRIANA>	<80%>
	As roughly as my modesty would let me.
</ADRIANA>

<ABBESS>	<80%>
	Haply, in private.
</ABBESS>

<ADRIANA>	<80%>
	And in assemblies too.
</ADRIANA>

<ABBESS>	<80%>
	Ay, but not enough.
</ABBESS>

<ADRIANA>	<80%>
	It was the copy of our conference:
	In bed, he slept not for my urging it;
	At board, he fed not for my urging it;
	Alone, it was the subject of my theme;
	In company I often glanced it:
	Still did I tell him it was vile and bad.
</ADRIANA>

<ABBESS>	<81%>
	And thereof came it that the man was mad:
	The venom clamours of a jealous woman
	Poison more deadly than a mad dog's tooth.
	It seems, his sleeps were hinder'd by thy railing,
	And thereof comes it that his head is light.
	Thou say'st his meat was sauc'd with thy upbraidings:
	Unquiet meals make ill digestions;
	Thereof the raging fire of fever bred:
	And what's a fever but a fit of madness?
	Thou say'st his sports were hinder'd by thy brawls:
	Sweet recreation barr'd, what doth ensue
	But moody moping, and dull melancholy,
	Kinsman to grim and comfortless despair,
	And at her heels a huge infectious troop
	Of pale distemperatures and foes to life?
	In food, in sport, and life-preserving rest
	To be disturb'd, would mad or man or beast:
	The consequence is then, thy jealous fits
	Have scar'd thy husband from the use of wits.
</ABBESS>

<LUCE>	<81%>
	She never reprehended him but mildly
	When he demean'd himself rough, rude, and wildly.
	Why bear you these rebukes and answer not?
</LUCE>

<ADRIANA>	<82%>
	She did betray me to my own reproof.
	Good people, enter, and lay hold on him.
</ADRIANA>

<ABBESS>	<82%>
	No; not a creature enters in my house.
</ABBESS>

<ADRIANA>	<82%>
	Then, let your servants bring my husband forth.
</ADRIANA>

<ABBESS>	<82%>
	Neither: he took this place for sanctuary,
	And it shall privilege him from your hands
	Till I have brought him to his wits again,
	Or lose my labour in assaying it.
</ABBESS>

<ADRIANA>	<82%>
	I will attend my husband, be his nurse,
	Diet his sickness, for it is my office,
	And will have no attorney but myself;
	And therefore let me have him home with me.
</ADRIANA>

<ABBESS>	<82%>
	Be patient; for I will not let him stir
	Till I have us'd the approved means I have,
	With wholesome syrups, drugs, and holy prayers,
	To make of him a formal man again.
	It is a branch and parcel of mine oath,
	A charitable duty of my order;
	Therefore depart and leave him here with me.
</ABBESS>

<ADRIANA>	<83%>
	I will not hence and leave my husband here;
	And ill it doth beseem your holiness
	To separate the husband and the wife.
</ADRIANA>

<ABBESS>	<83%>
	Be quiet, and depart: thou shalt not have him.
</ABBESS>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

<LUCE>	<83%>
	Complain unto the duke of this indignity.
</LUCE>

<ADRIANA>	<83%>
	Come, go: I will fall prostrate at his feet,
	And never rise until my tears and prayers
	Have won his Grace to come in person hither,
	And take perforce my husband from the abbess.
</ADRIANA>

<MERCHANT 2>	<83%>
	By this, I think, the dial points at five:
	Anon, I'm sure, the duke himself in person
	Comes this way to the melancholy vale,
	The place of death and sorry execution,
	Behind the ditches of the abbey here.
</MERCHANT 2>

<ANGELO>	<83%>
	Upon what cause?
</ANGELO>

<MERCHANT 2>	<83%>
	To see a reverend Syracusian merchant,
	Who put unluckily into this bay
	Against the laws and statutes of this town,
	Beheaded publicly for his offence.
</MERCHANT 2>

<ANGELO>	<84%>
	See where they come: we will behold his death.
</ANGELO>

<LUCE>	<84%>
	Kneel to the duke before he pass the abbey.

</LUCE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Duke attended; Ægeon bare-headed; with the Headsman and other Officers.>
</STAGE DIR>
<DUKE>	<84%>
	Yet once again proclaim it publicly,
	If any friend will pay the sum for him,
	He shall not die; so much we tender him.
</DUKE>

<ADRIANA>	<84%>
	Justice, most sacred duke, against the abbess!
</ADRIANA>

<DUKE>	<84%>
	She is a virtuous and a reverend lady:
	It cannot be that she hath done thee wrong.
</DUKE>

<ADRIANA>	<84%>
	May it please your Grace, Antipholus, my husband,
	Whom I made lord of me and all I had,
	At your important letters, this ill day
	A most outrageous fit of madness took him,
	That desperately he hurried through the street,—
	With him his bondman, all as mad as he,—
	Doing displeasure to the citizens
	By rushing in their houses, bearing thence
	Rings, jewels, anything his rage did like.
	Once did I get him bound and sent him home,
	Whilst to take order for the wrongs I went
	That here and there his fury had committed.
	Anon, I wot not by what strong escape,
	He broke from those that had the guard of him,
	And with his mad attendant and himself,
	Each one with ireful passion, with drawn swords
	Met us again, and, madly bent on us
	Chas'd us away, till, raising of more aid
	We came again to bind them. Then they fled
	Into this abbey, whither we pursu'd them;
	And here the abbess shuts the gates on us,
	And will not suffer us to fetch him out,
	Nor send him forth that we may bear him hence.
	Therefore, most gracious duke, with thy command
	Let him be brought forth, and borne hence for help.
</ADRIANA>

<DUKE>	<85%>
	Long since thy husband serv'd me in my wars,
	And I to thee engag'd a prince's word,
	When thou didst make him master of thy bed,
	To do him all the grace and good I could.
	Go, some of you, knock at the abbey gate
	And bid the lady abbess come to me.
	I will determine this before I stir.

</DUKE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter a Servant.>
</STAGE DIR>
<SERVANT>	<86%>
	O mistress, mistress! shift and save yourself!
	My master and his man are both broke loose,
	Beaten the maids a-row and bound the doctor,
	Whose beard they have sing'd off with brands of fire;
	And ever as it blaz'd they threw on him
	Great pails of puddled mire to quench the hair.
	My master preaches patience to him, and the while
	His man with scissors nicks him like a fool;
	And sure, unless you send some present help,
	Between them they will kill the conjurer.
</SERVANT>

<ADRIANA>	<86%>
	Peace, fool! thy master and his man are here,
	And that is false thou dost report to us.
</ADRIANA>

<SERVANT>	<86%>
	Mistress, upon my life, I tell you true;
	I have not breath'd almost, since I did see it.
	He cries for you and vows, if he can take you,
	To scotch your face, and to disfigure you.
<STAGE DIR>
<Cry within.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Hark, hark! I hear him, mistress: fly, be gone!
</SERVANT>

<DUKE>	<87%>
	Come, stand by me; fear nothing. Guard with halberds!
</DUKE>

<ADRIANA>	<87%>
	Ay me, it is my husband! Witness you,
	That he is borne about invisible:
	Even now we hous'd him in the abbey here,
	And now he's here, past thought of human reason.

</ADRIANA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Antipholus of Ephesus and Dromio of Ephesus.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<87%>
	Justice, most gracious duke! O! grant me justice,
	Even for the service that long since I did thee,
	When I bestrid thee in the wars and took
	Deep scars to save thy life; even for the blood
	That then I lost for thee, now grant me justice.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ÆGEON>	<87%>
	Unless the fear of death doth make me dote,
	I see my son Antipholus and Dromio!
</ÆGEON>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<88%>
	Justice, sweet prince, against that woman there!
	She whom thou gav'st to me to be my wife,
	That hath abused and dishonour'd me,
	Even in the strength and height of injury!
	Beyond imagination is the wrong
	That she this day hath shameless thrown on me.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DUKE>	<88%>
	Discover how, and thou shalt find me just.
</DUKE>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<88%>
	This day, great duke, she shut the doors upon me,
	While she with harlots feasted in my house.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DUKE>	<88%>
	A grievous fault! Say, woman, didst thou so?
</DUKE>

<ADRIANA>	<88%>
	No, my good lord: myself, he, and my sister
	To-day did dine together. So befall my soul
	As this is false he burdens me withal!
</ADRIANA>

<LUCE>	<88%>
	Ne'er may I look on day, nor sleep on night,
	But she tells to your highness simple truth!
</LUCE>

<ANGELO>	<88%>
	O perjur'd woman! They are both forsworn:
	In this the madman justly chargeth them!
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<88%>
	My liege, I am advised what I say:
	Neither disturb'd with the effect of wine,
	Nor heady-rash, provok'd with raging ire,
	Albeit my wrongs might make one wiser mad.
	This woman lock'd me out this day from dinner:
	That goldsmith there, were he not pack'd with her,
	Could witness it, for he was with me then;
	Who parted with me to go fetch a chain,
	Promising to bring it to the Porpentine,
	Where Balthazar and I did dine together.
	Our dinner done, and he not coming thither,
	I went to seek him: in the street I met him,
	And in his company that gentleman.
	There did this perjur'd goldsmith swear me down
	That I this day of him receiv'd the chain,
	Which, God he knows, I saw not; for the which
	He did arrest me with an officer.
	I did obey, and sent my peasant home
	For certain ducats: he with none return'd.
	Then fairly I bespoke the officer
	To go in person with me to my house.
	By the way we met
	My wife, her sister, and a rabble more
	Of vile confederates: along with them
	They brought one Pinch, a hungry lean-fac'd villain,
	A mere anatomy, a mountebank,
	A threadbare juggler, and a fortune-teller,
	A needy, hollow-ey'd, sharp-looking wretch,
	A living-dead man. This pernicious slave,
	Forsooth, took on him as a conjurer,
	And, gazing in mine eyes, feeling my pulse,
	And with no face, as 'twere, out-facing me,
	Cries out, I was possess'd. Then, altogether
	They fell upon me, bound me, bore me thence,
	And in a dark and dankish vault at home
	There left me and my man, both bound together;
	Till, gnawing with my teeth my bonds in sunder,
	I gain'd my freedom, and immediately
	Ran hither to your Grace; whom I beseech
	To give me ample satisfaction
	For these deep shames and great indignities.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ANGELO>	<90%>
	My lord, in truth, thus far I witness with him,
	That he din'd not at home, but was lock'd out.
</ANGELO>

<DUKE>	<91%>
	But had he such a chain of thee, or no?
</DUKE>

<ANGELO>	<91%>
	He had, my lord; and when he ran in here,
	These people saw the chain about his neck.
</ANGELO>

<MERCHANT 2>	<91%>
	Besides, I will be sworn these ears of mine
	Heard you confess you had the chain of him
	After you first forswore it on the mart;
	And thereupon I drew my sword on you;
	And then you fled into this abbey here,
	From whence, I think, you are come by miracle.
</MERCHANT 2>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<91%>
	I never came within these abbey walls;
	Nor ever didst thou draw thy sword on me;
	I never saw the chain, so help me heaven!
	And this is false you burden me withal.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DUKE>	<91%>
	Why, what an intricate impeach is this!
	I think you all have drunk of Circe's cup.
	If here you hous'd him, here he would have been;
	If he were mad, he would not plead so coldly;
	You say he din'd at home; the goldsmith here
	Denies that saying. Sirrah, what say you?
</DUKE>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<92%>
	Sir, he din'd with her there, at the Porpentine.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<COURTIER>	<92%>
	He did, and from my finger snatch'd that ring.
</COURTIER>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<92%>
	'Tis true, my liege; this ring I had of her.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DUKE>	<92%>
	Saw'st thou him enter at the abbey here?
</DUKE>

<COURTIER>	<92%>
	As sure, my liege, as I do see your Grace.
</COURTIER>

<DUKE>	<92%>
	Why, this is strange. Go call the abbess hither.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit an Attendant.>
</STAGE DIR>
	I think you are all mated or stark mad.
</DUKE>

<ÆGEON>	<92%>
	Most mighty duke, vouchsafe me speak a word:
	Haply I see a friend will save my life,
	And pay the sum that may deliver me.
</ÆGEON>

<DUKE>	<92%>
	Speak freely, Syracusian, what thou wilt.
</DUKE>

<ÆGEON>	<92%>
	Is not your name, sir, called Antipholus?
	And is not that your bondman Dromio?
</ÆGEON>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<92%>
	Within this hour I was his bondman, sir;
	But he, I thank him, gnaw'd in two my cords:
	Now am I Dromio and his man, unbound.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ÆGEON>	<92%>
	I am sure you both of you remember me.
</ÆGEON>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<93%>
	Ourselves we do remember, sir, by you;
	For lately we were bound, as you are now.
	You are not Pinch's patient, are you, sir?
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ÆGEON>	<93%>
	Why look you strange on me? you know me well.
</ÆGEON>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<93%>
	I never saw you in my life till now.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ÆGEON>	<93%>
	O! grief hath chang'd me since you saw me last,
	And careful hours, with Time's deformed hand,
	Have written strange defeatures in my face:
	But tell me yet, dost thou not know my voice?
</ÆGEON>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<93%>
	Neither.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ÆGEON>	<93%>
	Dromio, nor thou?
</ÆGEON>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<93%>
	No, trust me, sir, not I.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ÆGEON>	<93%>
	I am sure thou dost.
</ÆGEON>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<93%>
	Ay, sir; but I am sure I do not; and whatsoever a man denies, you are now bound to believe him.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ÆGEON>	<93%>
	Not know my voice! O, time's extremity,
	Hast thou so crack'd and splitted my poor tongue
	In seven short years, that here my only son
	Knows not my feeble key of untun'd cares?
	Though now this grained face of mine be hid
	In sap-consuming winter's drizzled snow,
	And all the conduits of my blood froze up,
	Yet hath my night of life some memory,
	My wasting lamps some fading glimmer left,
	My dull deaf ears a little use to hear:
	All these old witnesses, I cannot err,
	Tell me thou art my son Antipholus.
</ÆGEON>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<94%>
	I never saw my father in my life.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ÆGEON>	<94%>
	But seven years since, in Syracusa, boy,
	Thou know'st we parted: but perhaps, my son,
	Thou sham'st to acknowledge me in misery.
</ÆGEON>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<94%>
	The duke and all that know me in the city
	Can witness with me that it is not so:
	I ne'er saw Syracusa in my life.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DUKE>	<94%>
	I tell thee, Syracusian, twenty years
	Have I been patron to Antipholus,
	During which time he ne'er saw Syracusa.
	I see thy age and dangers make thee dote.

</DUKE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Re-enter Abbess, with Antipholus of Syracuse and Dromio of Syracuse.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ABBESS>	<95%>
	Most mighty duke, behold a man much wrong'd.
</ABBESS>
<STAGE DIR>
<All gather to see him.>
</STAGE DIR>

<ADRIANA>	<95%>
	I see two husbands, or mine eyes deceive me!
</ADRIANA>

<DUKE>	<95%>
	One of these men is Genius to the other;
	And so of these: which is the natural man,
	And which the spirit? Who deciphers them?
</DUKE>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<95%>
	I, sir, am Dromio: command him away.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<95%>
	I, sir, am Dromio: pray let me stay.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<95%>
	Ægeon art thou not? or else his ghost?
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<95%>
	O! my old master; who hath bound him here?
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ABBESS>	<95%>
	Whoever bound him, I will loose his bonds,
	And gain a husband by his liberty.
	Speak, old Ægeon, if thou be'st the man
	That hadst a wife once call'd Æmilia,
	That bore thee at a burden two fair sons.
	O! if thou be'st the same Ægeon, speak,
	And speak unto the same Æmilia!
</ABBESS>

<ÆGEON>	<95%>
	If I dream not, thou art Æmilia:
	If thou art she, tell me where is that son
	That floated with thee on the fatal raft?
</ÆGEON>

<ABBESS>	<96%>
	By men of Epidamnum, he and I,
	And the twin Dromio, all were taken up:
	But by and by rude fishermen of Corinth
	By force took Dromio and my son from them,
	And me they left with those of Epidamnum.
	What then became of them, I cannot tell;
	I to this fortune that you see me in.
</ABBESS>

<DUKE>	<96%>
	Why, here begins his morning story right:
	These two Antipholus', these two so like,
	And these two Dromios, one in semblance,
	Besides her urging of her wrack at sea;
	These are the parents to these children,
	Which accidentally are met together.
	Antipholus, thou cam'st from Corinth first?
</DUKE>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<96%>
	No, sir, not I; I came from Syracuse.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<DUKE>	<96%>
	Stay, stand apart; I know not which is which.
</DUKE>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<96%>
	I came from Corinth, my most gracious lord,—
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<96%>
	And I with him.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<96%>
	Brought to this town by that most famous warrior,
	Duke Menaphon, your most renowned uncle.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ADRIANA>	<97%>
	Which of you two did dine with me to-day?
</ADRIANA>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<97%>
	I, gentle mistress.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<ADRIANA>	<97%>
	And are not you my husband?
</ADRIANA>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<97%>
	No; I say nay to that.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<97%>
	And so do I; yet did she call me so;
	And this fair gentlewoman, her sister here,
	Did call me brother. <STAGE DIR>
<To Luciana.>
</STAGE DIR> What I told you then,
	I hope I shall have leisure to make good,
	If this be not a dream I see and hear.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<ANGELO>	<97%>
	That is the chain, sir, which you had of me.
</ANGELO>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<97%>
	I think it be, sir; I deny it not.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<97%>
	And you, sir, for this chain arrested me.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ANGELO>	<97%>
	I think I did, sir; I deny it not.
</ANGELO>

<ADRIANA>	<97%>
	I sent you money, sir, to be your bail,
	By Dromio; but I think he brought it not.
</ADRIANA>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<97%>
	No, none by me.
</DROMIO EPH.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<97%>
	This purse of ducats I receiv'd from you,
	And Dromio, my man, did bring them me.
	I see we still did meet each other's man,
	And I was ta'en for him, and he for me,
	And thereupon these errors are arose.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<98%>
	These ducats pawn I for my father here.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DUKE>	<98%>
	It shall not need: thy father hath his life.
</DUKE>

<COURTIER>	<98%>
	Sir, I must have that diamond from you.
</COURTIER>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<98%>
	There, take it; and much thanks for my good cheer.
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<ABBESS>	<98%>
	Renowned duke, vouchsafe to take the pains
	To go with us into the abbey here,
	And hear at large discoursed all our fortunes;
	And all that are assembled in this place,
	That by this sympathized one day's error
	Have suffer'd wrong, go keep us company,
	And we shall make full satisfaction.
	Thirty-three years have I but gone in travail
	Of you, my sons; and, till this present hour
	My heavy burdens ne'er delivered.
	The duke, my husband, and my children both,
	And you the calendars of their nativity,
	Go to a gossip's feast, and joy with me:
	After so long grief such festivity!
</ABBESS>

<DUKE>	<99%>
	With all my heart I'll gossip at this feast.
</DUKE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Duke, Abbess, Ægeon, Courtezan, Merchant, Angelo, and Attendants.>
</STAGE DIR>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<99%>
	Master, shall I fetch your stuff from shipboard?
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>	<99%>
	Dromio, what stuff of mine hast thou embark'd?
</ANTIPHOLUS EPH.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<99%>
	Your goods that lay at host, sir, in the Centaur.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>	<99%>
	He speaks to me. I am your master, Dromio:
	Come, go with us; we'll look to that anon:
	Embrace thy brother there; rejoice with him.
</ANTIPHOLUS SYR.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Antipholus of Ephesus, Adriana and Luciana.>
</STAGE DIR>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<99%>
	There is a fat friend at your master's house,
	That kitchen'd me for you to-day at dinner:
	She now shall be my sister, not my wife.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<99%>
	Methinks you are my glass, and not my brother:
	I see by you I am a sweet-fac'd youth.
	Will you walk in to see their gossiping?
</DROMIO EPH.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<100%>
	Not I, sir; you are my elder.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<100%>
	That's a question: how shall we try it?
</DROMIO EPH.>

<DROMIO SYR.>	<100%>
	We'll draw cuts for the senior: till then lead thou first.
</DROMIO SYR.>

<DROMIO EPH.>	<100%>
	Nay, then, thus:
	We came into the world like brother and brother;
	And now let's go hand in hand, not one before another.
</DROMIO EPH.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>
</SCENE 1>
</ACT 5>
< Shakespeare -- THE MERCHANT OF VENICE >
< from Online Library of Liberty (http://oll.libertyfund.org) >
< Unicode .txt version by Mike Scott (http://www.lexically.net) >
< from "The Complete Works of William Shakespeare" >
< ed. with a glossary by W.J. Craig M.A. >
< (London: Oxford University Press, 1916) >
<SCENE.—PARTLY AT VENICE, AND PARTLY AT BELMONT, THE SEAT OF PORTIA, ON THE CONTINENT.>



<ACT 1>


<SCENE 1>
<Venice. A Street.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Antonio, Salarino, and Salanio.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ANTONIO>	<0%>
	In sooth, I know not why I am so sad:
	It wearies me; you say it wearies you;
	But how I caught it, found it, or came by it,
	What stuff 'tis made of, whereof it is born,
	I am to learn;
	And such a want-wit sadness makes of me,
	That I have much ado to know myself.
</ANTONIO>

<SALARINO>	<1%>
	Your mind is tossing on the ocean;
	There, where your argosies with portly sail,—
	Like signiors and rich burghers on the flood,
	Or, as it were, the pageants of the sea,—
	Do overpeer the petty traffickers,
	That curtsy to them, do them reverence,
	As they fly by them with their woven wings.
</SALARINO>

<SALANIO>	<1%>
	Believe me, sir, had I such venture forth,
	The better part of my affections would
	Be with my hopes abroad. I should be still
	Plucking the grass to know where sits the wind;
	Peering in maps for ports, and piers, and roads;
	And every object that might make me fear
	Misfortune to my ventures, out of doubt
	Would make me sad.
</SALANIO>

<SALARINO>	<1%>
	My wind, cooling my broth,
	Would blow me to an ague, when I thought
	What harm a wind too great might do at sea.
	I should not see the sandy hour-glass run
	But I should think of shallows and of flats,
	And see my wealthy Andrew dock'd in sand
	Vailing her high-top lower than her ribs
	To kiss her burial. Should I go to church
	And see the holy edifice of stone,
	And not bethink me straight of dangerous rocks,
	Which touching but my gentle vessel's side
	Would scatter all her spices on the stream,
	Enrobe the roaring waters with my silks;
	And, in a word, but even now worth this,
	And now worth nothing? Shall I have the thought
	To think on this, and shall I lack the thought
	That such a thing bechanc'd would make me sad?
	But tell not me: I know Antonio
	Is sad to think upon his merchandise.
</SALARINO>

<ANTONIO>	<2%>
	Believe me, no: I thank my fortune for it,
	My ventures are not in one bottom trusted,
	Nor to one place; nor is my whole estate
	Upon the fortune of this present year:
	Therefore, my merchandise makes me not sad.
</ANTONIO>

<SALARINO>	<2%>
	Why, then you are in love.
</SALARINO>

<ANTONIO>	<2%>
	Fie, fie!
</ANTONIO>

<SALARINO>	<2%>
	Not in love neither? Then let's say you are sad,
	Because you are not merry: and 'twere as easy
	For you to laugh and leap, and say you are merry,
	Because you are not sad. Now, by two-headed Janus,
	Nature hath fram'd strange fellows in her time:
	Some that will evermore peep through their eyes
	And laugh like parrots at a bag-piper,
	And other of such vinegar aspect
	That they'll not show their teeth in way of smile,
	Though Nestor swear the jest be laughable.

</SALARINO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Bassanio, Lorenzo, and Gratiano.>
</STAGE DIR>
<SALANIO>	<2%>
	Here comes Bassanio, your most noble kinsman,
	Gratiano, and Lorenzo. Fare ye well:
	We leave you now with better company.
</SALANIO>

<SALARINO>	<3%>
	I would have stay'd till I had made you merry,
	If worthier friends had not prevented me.
</SALARINO>

<ANTONIO>	<3%>
	Your worth is very dear in my regard.
	I take it, your own business calls on you,
	And you embrace the occasion to depart.
</ANTONIO>

<SALARINO>	<3%>
	Good morrow, my good lords.
</SALARINO>

<BASSANIO>	<3%>
	Good signiors both, when shall we laugh? say when?
	You grow exceeding strange: must it be so?
</BASSANIO>

<SALARINO>	<3%>
	We'll make our leisures to attend on yours.
</SALARINO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Salarino and Salanio.>
</STAGE DIR>

<LORENZO>	<3%>
	My Lord Bassanio, since you have found Antonio,
	We too will leave you; but, at dinner-time,
	I pray you, have in mind where we must meet.
</LORENZO>

<BASSANIO>	<3%>
	I will not fail you.
</BASSANIO>

<GRATIANO>	<3%>
	You look not well, Signior Antonio;
	You have too much respect upon the world:
	They lose it that do buy it with much care:
	Believe me, you are marvellously chang'd.
</GRATIANO>

<ANTONIO>	<3%>
	I hold the world but as the world, Gratiano;
	A stage where every man must play a part,
	And mine a sad one.
</ANTONIO>

<GRATIANO>	<3%>
	Let me play the fool:
	With mirth and laughter let old wrinkles come,
	And let my liver rather heat with wine
	Than my heart cool with mortifying groans.
	Why should a man, whose blood is warm within,
	Sit like his grandsire cut in alabaster?
	Sleep when he wakes, and creep into the jaundice
	By being peevish? I tell thee what, Antonio—
	I love thee, and it is my love that speaks—
	There are a sort of men whose visages
	Do cream and mantle like a standing pond,
	And do a wilful stillness entertain,
	With purpose to be dress'd in an opinion
	Of wisdom, gravity, profound conceit;
	As who should say, 'I am Sir Oracle,
	And when I ope my lips let no dog bark!'
	O, my Antonio, I do know of these,
	That therefore only are reputed wise
	For saying nothing; when, I am very sure,
	If they should speak, would almost damn those ears
	Which, hearing them, would call their brothers fools.
	I'll tell thee more of this another time:
	But fish not, with this melancholy bait,
	For this fool-gudgeon, this opinion.
	Come, good Lorenzo. Fare ye well awhile:
	I'll end my exhortation after dinner.
</GRATIANO>

<LORENZO>	<4%>
	Well, we will leave you then till dinner-time.
	I must be one of these same dumb-wise men,
	For Gratiano never lets me speak.
</LORENZO>

<GRATIANO>	<4%>
	Well, keep me company but two years moe,
	Thou shalt not know the sound of thine own tongue.
</GRATIANO>

<ANTONIO>	<4%>
	Farewell: I'll grow a talker for this gear.
</ANTONIO>

<GRATIANO>	<4%>
	Thanks, i' faith; for silence is only commendable
	In a neat's tongue dried and a maid not vendible.
</GRATIANO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Gratiano and Lorenzo.>
</STAGE DIR>

<ANTONIO>	<5%>
	Is that anything now?
</ANTONIO>

<BASSANIO>	<5%>
	Gratiano speaks an infinite deal of nothing, more than any man in all Venice. His reasons are as two grains of wheat hid in two bushels of chaff: you shall seek all day ere you find them, and, when you have them, they are not worth the search.
</BASSANIO>

<ANTONIO>	<5%>
	Well, tell me now, what lady is the same
	To whom you swore a secret pilgrimage,
	That you to-day promis'd to tell me of?
</ANTONIO>

<BASSANIO>	<5%>
	'Tis not unknown to you, Antonio,
	How much I have disabled mine estate,
	By something showing a more swelling port
	Than my faint means would grant continuance:
	Nor do I now make moan to be abridg'd
	From such a noble rate; but my chief care
	Is, to come fairly off from the great debts
	Wherein my time, something too prodigal,
	Hath left me gag'd. To you, Antonio,
	I owe the most, in money and in love;
	And from your love I have a warranty
	To unburthen all my plots and purposes
	How to get clear of all the debts I owe.
</BASSANIO>

<ANTONIO>	<5%>
	I pray you, good Bassanio, let me know it;
	And if it stand, as you yourself still do,
	Within the eye of honour, be assur'd,
	My purse, my person, my extremest means,
	Lie all unlock'd to your occasions.
</ANTONIO>

<BASSANIO>	<6%>
	In my school-days, when I had lost one shaft,
	I shot his fellow of the self-same flight
	The self-same way with more advised watch,
	To find the other forth, and by adventuring both,
	I oft found both. I urge this childhood proof,
	Because what follows is pure innocence.
	I owe you much, and, like a wilful youth,
	That which I owe is lost; but if you please
	To shoot another arrow that self way
	Which you did shoot the first, I do not doubt,
	As I will watch the aim, or to find both,
	Or bring your latter hazard back again,
	And thankfully rest debtor for the first.
</BASSANIO>

<ANTONIO>	<6%>
	You know me well, and herein spend but time
	To wind about my love with circumstance;
	And out of doubt you do me now more wrong
	In making question of my uttermost
	Than if you had made waste of all I have:
	Then do but say to me what I should do
	That in your knowledge may by me be done,
	And I am prest unto it: therefore speak.
</ANTONIO>

<BASSANIO>	<6%>
	In Belmont is a lady richly left,
	And she is fair, and, fairer than that word,
	Of wondrous virtues: sometimes from her eyes
	I did receive fair speechless messages:
	Her name is Portia; nothing undervalu'd
	To Cato's daughter, Brutus' Portia:
	Nor is the wide world ignorant of her worth,
	For the four winds blow in from every coast
	Renowned suitors; and her sunny locks
	Hang on her temples like a golden fleece;
	Which makes her seat of Belmont Colchos' strond,
	And many Jasons come in quest of her.
	O my Antonio! had I but the means
	To hold a rival place with one of them,
	I have a mind presages me such thrift,
	That I should questionless be fortunate.
</BASSANIO>

<ANTONIO>	<7%>
	Thou knowest that all my fortunes are at sea;
	Neither have I money, nor commodity
	To raise a present sum: therefore go forth;
	Try what my credit can in Venice do:
	That shall be rack'd, even to the uttermost,
	To furnish thee to Belmont, to fair Portia.
	Go, presently inquire, and so will I,
	Where money is, and I no question make
	To have it of my trust or for my sake.
</ANTONIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 1>


<SCENE 2>
<Belmont. A Room in Portia's House.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Portia and Nerissa.>
</STAGE DIR>
<PORTIA>	<7%>
	By my troth, Nerissa, my little body is aweary of this great world.
</PORTIA>

<NERISSA>	<7%>
	You would be, sweet madam, if your miseries were in the same abundance as your good fortunes are: and yet, for aught I see, they are as sick that surfeit with too much as they that starve with nothing. It is no mean happiness therefore, to be seated in the mean: superfluity comes sooner by white hairs, but competency lives longer.
</NERISSA>

<PORTIA>	<8%>
	Good sentences and well pronounced.
</PORTIA>

<NERISSA>	<8%>
	They would be better if well followed.
</NERISSA>

<PORTIA>	<8%>
	If to do were as easy as to know what were good to do, chapels had been churches, and poor men's cottages princes' palaces. It is a good divine that follows his own instructions: I can easier teach twenty what were good to be done, than be one of the twenty to follow mine own teaching. The brain may devise laws for the blood, but a hot temper leaps o'er a cold decree: such a hare is madness the youth, to skip o'er the meshes of good counsel the cripple. But this reasoning is not in the fashion to choose me a husband. O me, the word 'choose!' I may neither choose whom I would nor refuse whom I dislike; so is the will of a living daughter curbed by the will of a dead father. Is it not hard, Nerissa, that I cannot choose one nor refuse none?
</PORTIA>

<NERISSA>	<8%>
	Your father was ever virtuous, and holy men at their death have good inspirations; therefore, the lottery that he hath devised in these three chests of gold, silver, and lead, whereof who chooses his meaning chooses you, will, no doubt, never be chosen by any rightly but one who you shall rightly love. But what warmth is there in your affection towards any of these princely suitors that are already come?
</NERISSA>

<PORTIA>	<9%>
	I pray thee, over-name them, and as thou namest them, I will describe them; and, according to my description, level at my affection.
</PORTIA>

<NERISSA>	<9%>
	First, there is the Neapolitan prince.
</NERISSA>

<PORTIA>	<9%>
	Ay, that's a colt indeed, for he doth nothing but talk of his horse; and he makes it a great appropriation to his own good parts that he can shoe him himself. I am much afeard my lady his mother played false with a smith.
</PORTIA>

<NERISSA>	<9%>
	Then is there the County Palatine.
</NERISSA>

<PORTIA>	<9%>
	He doth nothing but frown, as who should say, 'An you will not have me, choose.' He hears merry tales, and smiles not: I fear he will prove the weeping philosopher when he grows old, being so full of unmannerly sadness in his youth. I had rather be married to a death's-head with a bone in his mouth than to either of these. God defend me from these two!
</PORTIA>

<NERISSA>	<9%>
	How say you by the French lord, Monsieur Le Bon?
</NERISSA>

<PORTIA>	<9%>
	God made him, and therefore let him pass for a man. In truth, I know it is a sin to be a mocker; but, he! why, he hath a horse better than the Neapolitan's, a better bad habit of frowning than the Count Palatine; he is every man in no man; if a throstle sing, he falls straight a-capering; he will fence with his own shadow: if I should marry him, I should marry twenty husbands. If he would despise me, I would forgive him, for if he love me to madness, I shall never requite him.
</PORTIA>

<NERISSA>	<10%>
	What say you, then, to Falconbridge, the young baron of England?
</NERISSA>

<PORTIA>	<10%>
	You know I say nothing to him, for he understands not me, nor I him: he hath neither Latin, French, nor Italian; and you will come into the court and swear that I have a poor pennyworth in the English. He is a proper man's picture, but, alas! who can converse with a dumb-show? How oddly he is suited! I think he bought his doublet in Italy, his round hose in France, his bonnet in Germany, and his behaviour every where.
</PORTIA>

<NERISSA>	<10%>
	What think you of the Scottish lord, his neighbour?
</NERISSA>

<PORTIA>	<10%>
	That he hath a neighbourly charity in him, for he borrowed a box of the ear of the Englishman, and swore he would pay him again when he was able: I think the Frenchman became his surety and sealed under for another.
</PORTIA>

<NERISSA>	<10%>
	How like you the young German, the Duke of Saxony's nephew?
</NERISSA>

<PORTIA>	<10%>
	Very vilely in the morning, when he is sober, and most vilely in the afternoon, when he is drunk: when he is best, he is a little worse than a man, and when he is worst, he is little better than a beast. An the worst fall that ever fell, I hope I shall make shift to go without him.
</PORTIA>

<NERISSA>	<11%>
	If he should offer to choose, and choose the right casket, you should refuse to perform your father's will, if you should refuse to accept him.
</NERISSA>

<PORTIA>	<11%>
	Therefore, for fear of the worst, I pray thee, set a deep glass of Rhenish wine on the contrary casket, for, if the devil be within and that temptation without, I know he will choose it. I will do anything, Nerissa, ere I will be married to a sponge.
</PORTIA>

<NERISSA>	<11%>
	You need not fear, lady, the having any of these lords: they have acquainted me with their determinations; which is, indeed, to return to their home and to trouble you with no more suit, unless you may be won by some other sort than your father's imposition depending on the caskets.
</NERISSA>

<PORTIA>	<11%>
	If I live to be as old as Sibylla, I will die as chaste as Diana, unless I be obtained by the manner of my father's will. I am glad this parcel of wooers are so reasonable, for there is not one among them but I dote on his very absence, and I pray God grant them a fair departure.
</PORTIA>

<NERISSA>	<11%>
	Do you not remember, lady, in your father's time, a Venetian, a scholar and a soldier, that came hither in the company of the Marquis of Montferrat?
</NERISSA>

<PORTIA>	<12%>
	Yes, yes: it was Bassanio; as I think, he was so called.
</PORTIA>

<NERISSA>	<12%>
	True, madam: he, of all the men that ever my foolish eyes looked upon, was the best deserving a fair lady.
</NERISSA>

<PORTIA>	<12%>
	I remember him well, and I remember him worthy of thy praise.

</PORTIA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter a Servant.>
</STAGE DIR>
	How now! what news?
<SERVANT>	<12%>
	The four strangers seek for you, madam, to take their leave; and there is a forerunner come from a fifth, the Prince of Morocco, who brings word the prince his master will be here to-night.
</SERVANT>

<PORTIA>	<12%>
	If I could bid the fifth welcome with so good heart as I can bid the other four farewell, I should be glad of his approach: if he have the condition of a saint and the complexion of a devil, I had rather he should shrive me than wive me. Come, Nerissa. Sirrah, go before.
	Whiles we shut the gate upon one wooer, another knocks at the door.
</PORTIA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 2>


<SCENE 3>
<Venice. A public Place.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Bassanio and Shylock.>
</STAGE DIR>
<SHYLOCK>	<12%>
	Three thousand ducats; well?
</SHYLOCK>

<BASSANIO>	<12%>
	Ay, sir, for three months.
</BASSANIO>

<SHYLOCK>	<12%>
	For three months; well?
</SHYLOCK>

<BASSANIO>	<12%>
	For the which, as I told you, Antonio shall be bound.
</BASSANIO>

<SHYLOCK>	<13%>
	Antonio shall become bound; well?
</SHYLOCK>

<BASSANIO>	<13%>
	May you stead me? Will you pleasure me? Shall I know your answer?
</BASSANIO>

<SHYLOCK>	<13%>
	Three thousand ducats, for three months, and Antonio bound.
</SHYLOCK>

<BASSANIO>	<13%>
	Your answer to that.
</BASSANIO>

<SHYLOCK>	<13%>
	Antonio is a good man.
</SHYLOCK>

<BASSANIO>	<13%>
	Have you heard any imputation to the contrary?
</BASSANIO>

<SHYLOCK>	<13%>
	Ho, no, no, no, no: my meaning in saying he is a good man is to have you understand me that he is sufficient. Yet his means are in supposition: he hath an argosy bound to Tripolis, another to the Indies; I understand moreover upon the Rialto, he hath a third at Mexico, a fourth for England, and other ventures he hath, squandered abroad. But ships are but boards, sailors but men: there be land-rats and water-rats, land-thieves, and water-thieves,—I mean pirates,—and then there is the peril of waters, winds, and rocks. The man is, notwithstanding, sufficient. Three thousand ducats; I think, I may take his bond.
</SHYLOCK>
