	Prithee, Kate, let's stand aside, and see the end of this controversy.
<STAGE DIR>
<They retire.>
</STAGE DIR>

</PETRUCHIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Re-enter Pedant below; Baptista, Tranio, and Servants.>
</STAGE DIR>
<TRANIO>	<89%>
	Sir, what are you that offer to beat my servant?
</TRANIO>

<VINCENTIO>	<89%>
	What am I, sir! nay, what are you, sir? O immortal gods! O fine villain! A silken doublet! a velvet hose! a scarlet cloak! and a copatain hat! O, I am undone! I am undone! while I play the good husband at home, my son and my servant spend all at the university.
</VINCENTIO>

<TRANIO>	<89%>
	How now! what's the matter?
</TRANIO>

<BAPTISTA>	<89%>
	What, is the man lunatic?
</BAPTISTA>

<TRANIO>	<89%>
	Sir, you seem a sober ancient gentleman by your habit, but your words show you a madman. Why, sir, what 'cerns it you if I wear pearl and gold? I thank my good father, I am able to maintain it.
</TRANIO>

<VINCENTIO>	<89%>
	Thy father! O villain! he is a sailmaker in Bergamo.
</VINCENTIO>

<BAPTISTA>	<89%>
	You mistake, sir, you mistake, sir. Pray, what do you think is his name?
</BAPTISTA>

<VINCENTIO>	<89%>
	His name! as if I knew not his name: I have brought him up ever since he was three years old, and his name is Tranio.
</VINCENTIO>

<PEDANT>	<90%>
	Away, away, mad ass! his name is Lucentio; and he is mine only son, and heir to the lands of me, Signior Vincentio.
</PEDANT>

<VINCENTIO>	<90%>
	Lucentio! O! he hath murdered his master. Lay hold on him, I charge you in the duke's name. O my son, my son! tell me, thou villain, where is my son Lucentio?
</VINCENTIO>

<TRANIO>	<90%>
	Call forth an officer.

</TRANIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter one with an Officer.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Carry this mad knave to the gaol. Father Baptista, I charge you see that he be forthcoming.
<VINCENTIO>	<90%>
	Carry me to the gaol!
</VINCENTIO>

<GREMIO>	<90%>
	Stay, officer: he shall not go to prison.
</GREMIO>

<BAPTISTA>	<90%>
	Talk not, Signior Gremio: I say he shall go to prison.
</BAPTISTA>

<GREMIO>	<90%>
	Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be cony-catched in this business: I dare swear this is the right Vincentio.
</GREMIO>

<PEDANT>	<90%>
	Swear, if thou darest.
</PEDANT>

<GREMIO>	<90%>
	Nay, I dare not swear it.
</GREMIO>

<TRANIO>	<90%>
	Then thou wert best say, that I am not Lucentio.
</TRANIO>

<GREMIO>	<90%>
	Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.
</GREMIO>

<BAPTISTA>	<90%>
	Away with the dotard! to the gaol with him!
</BAPTISTA>

<VINCENTIO>	<90%>
	Thus strangers may be haled and abused: O monstrous villain!

</VINCENTIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Re-enter Biondello, with Lucentio and Bianca.>
</STAGE DIR>
<BIONDELLO>	<90%>
	O! we are spoiled; and yonder he is: deny him, forswear him, or else we are all undone.
</BIONDELLO>

<LUCENTIO>	<90%>
<STAGE DIR>
<Kneeling.>
</STAGE DIR> Pardon, sweet father.
</LUCENTIO>

<VINCENTIO>	<91%>
	Lives my sweetest son?
</VINCENTIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Biondello, Tranio, and Pedant run out.>
</STAGE DIR>

<BIANCA>	<91%>
<STAGE DIR>
<Kneeling.>
</STAGE DIR> Pardon, dear father.
</BIANCA>

<BAPTISTA>	<91%>
	How hast thou offended?
	Where is Lucentio?
</BAPTISTA>

<LUCENTIO>	<91%>
	Here's Lucentio,
	Right son to the right Vincentio;
	That have by marriage made thy daughter mine,
	While counterfeit supposes blear'd thine eyne.
</LUCENTIO>

<GREMIO>	<91%>
	Here's packing, with a witness, to deceive us all!
</GREMIO>

<VINCENTIO>	<91%>
	Where is that damned villain Tranio,
	That fac'd and brav'd me in this matter so?
</VINCENTIO>

<BAPTISTA>	<91%>
	Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?
</BAPTISTA>

<BIANCA>	<91%>
	Cambio is chang'd into Lucentio.
</BIANCA>

<LUCENTIO>	<91%>
	Love wrought these miracles. Bianca's love
	Made me exchange my state with Tranio,
	While he did bear my countenance in the town;
	And happily I have arriv'd at last
	Unto the wished haven of my bliss.
	What Tranio did, myself enforc'd him to;
	Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.
</LUCENTIO>

<VINCENTIO>	<91%>
	I'll slit the villain's nose, that would have sent me to the gaol.
</VINCENTIO>

<BAPTISTA>	<91%>
<STAGE DIR>
<To Lucentio.>
</STAGE DIR> But do you hear, sir?
	Have you married my daughter without asking my good will?
</BAPTISTA>

<VINCENTIO>	<91%>
	Fear not, Baptista; we will content you, go to: but I will in, to be revenged for this villany.
</VINCENTIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

<BAPTISTA>	<92%>
	And I, to sound the depth of this knavery.
</BAPTISTA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

<LUCENTIO>	<92%>
	Look not pale, Bianca; thy father will not frown.
</LUCENTIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Lucentio and Bianca.>
</STAGE DIR>

<GREMIO>	<92%>
	My cake is dough; but I'll in among the rest,
	Out of hope of all, but my share of the feast.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

</GREMIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Petruchio and Katharina advance.>
</STAGE DIR>
<KATHARINA>	<92%>
	Husband, let's follow, to see the end of this ado.
</KATHARINA>

<PETRUCHIO>	<92%>
	First kiss me, Kate, and we will.
</PETRUCHIO>

<KATHARINA>	<92%>
	What! in the midst of the street?
</KATHARINA>

<PETRUCHIO>	<92%>
	What! art thou ashamed of me?
</PETRUCHIO>

<KATHARINA>	<92%>
	No, sir, God forbid; but ashamed to kiss.
</KATHARINA>

<PETRUCHIO>	<92%>
	Why, then let's home again. Come, sirrah, let's away.
</PETRUCHIO>

<KATHARINA>	<92%>
	Nay, I will give thee a kiss: now pray thee, love, stay.
</KATHARINA>

<PETRUCHIO>	<92%>
	Is not this well? Come, my sweet Kate:
	Better once than never, for never too late.
</PETRUCHIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 1>


<SCENE 2>
<A Room in Lucentio's House.>
<STAGE DIR>
<A Banquet set out. Enter Baptista, Vincentio, Gremio,...>
<... the Pedant, Lucentio, Bianca, Petruchio, Katharina,...>
<... Hortensio, and Widow. Tranio, Biondello, Grumio, and Others, attending.>
</STAGE DIR>
<LUCENTIO>	<92%>
	At last, though long, our jarring notes agree:
	And time it is, when raging war is done,
	To smile at 'scapes and perils overblown.
	My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome,
	While I with self-same kindness welcome thine.
	Brother Petruchio, sister Katharina,
	And thou, Hortensio, with thy loving widow,
	Feast with the best, and welcome to my house:
	My banquet is to close our stomachs up,
	After our great good cheer. Pray you, sit down;
	For now we sit to chat as well as eat.
</LUCENTIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<They sit at table.>
</STAGE DIR>

<PETRUCHIO>	<93%>
	Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!
</PETRUCHIO>

<BAPTISTA>	<93%>
	Padua affords this kindness, son Petruchio.
</BAPTISTA>

<PETRUCHIO>	<93%>
	Padua affords nothing but what is kind.
</PETRUCHIO>

<HORTENSIO>	<93%>
	For both our sakes I would that word were true.
</HORTENSIO>

<PETRUCHIO>	<93%>
	Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.
</PETRUCHIO>

<WIDOW>	<93%>
	Then never trust me, if I be afeard.
</WIDOW>

<PETRUCHIO>	<93%>
	You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense:
	I mean, Hortensio is afeard of you.
</PETRUCHIO>

<WIDOW>	<93%>
	He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.
</WIDOW>

<PETRUCHIO>	<93%>
	Roundly replied.
</PETRUCHIO>

<KATHARINA>	<93%>
	Mistress, how mean you that?
</KATHARINA>

<WIDOW>	<93%>
	Thus I conceive by him.
</WIDOW>

<PETRUCHIO>	<93%>
	Conceives by me! How likes Hortensio that?
</PETRUCHIO>

<HORTENSIO>	<93%>
	My widow says, thus she conceives her tale.
</HORTENSIO>

<PETRUCHIO>	<93%>
	Very well mended. Kiss him for that, good widow.
</PETRUCHIO>

<KATHARINA>	<93%>
	'He that is giddy thinks the world turns round:'
	I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.
</KATHARINA>

<WIDOW>	<94%>
	Your husband, being troubled with a shrew,
	Measures my husband's sorrow by his woe:
	And now you know my meaning.
</WIDOW>

<KATHARINA>	<94%>
	A very mean meaning.
</KATHARINA>

<WIDOW>	<94%>
	Right, I mean you.
</WIDOW>

<KATHARINA>	<94%>
	And I am mean, indeed, respecting you.
</KATHARINA>

<PETRUCHIO>	<94%>
	To her, Kate!
</PETRUCHIO>

<HORTENSIO>	<94%>
	To her, widow!
</HORTENSIO>

<PETRUCHIO>	<94%>
	A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.
</PETRUCHIO>

<HORTENSIO>	<94%>
	That's my office.
</HORTENSIO>

<PETRUCHIO>	<94%>
	Spoke like an officer: ha' to thee, lad.
</PETRUCHIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Drinks to Hortensio.>
</STAGE DIR>

<BAPTISTA>	<94%>
	How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?
</BAPTISTA>

<GREMIO>	<94%>
	Believe me, sir, they butt together well.
</GREMIO>

<BIANCA>	<94%>
	Head and butt! a hasty-witted body
	Would say your head and butt were head and horn.
</BIANCA>

<VINCENTIO>	<94%>
	Ay, mistress bride, hath that awaken'd you?
</VINCENTIO>

<BIANCA>	<94%>
	Ay, but not frighted me; therefore I'll sleep again.
</BIANCA>

<PETRUCHIO>	<94%>
	Nay, that you shall not; since you have begun,
	Have at you for a bitter jest or two.
</PETRUCHIO>

<BIANCA>	<94%>
	Am I your bird? I mean to shift my bush;
	And then pursue me as you draw your bow.
	You are welcome all.
</BIANCA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Bianca, Katharina, and Widow.>
</STAGE DIR>

<PETRUCHIO>	<94%>
	She hath prevented me. Here, Signior Tranio;
	This bird you aim'd at, though you hit her not:
	Therefore a health to all that shot and miss'd.
</PETRUCHIO>

<TRANIO>	<94%>
	O sir! Lucentio slipp'd me, like his greyhound,
	Which runs himself, and catches for his master.
</TRANIO>

<PETRUCHIO>	<95%>
	A good swift simile, but something currish.
</PETRUCHIO>

<TRANIO>	<95%>
	'Tis well, sir, that you hunted for yourself:
	'Tis thought your deer does hold you at a bay.
</TRANIO>

<BAPTISTA>	<95%>
	O ho, Petruchio! Tranio hits you now.
</BAPTISTA>

<LUCENTIO>	<95%>
	I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.
</LUCENTIO>

<HORTENSIO>	<95%>
	Confess, confess, hath he not hit you here?
</HORTENSIO>

<PETRUCHIO>	<95%>
	A' has a little gall'd me, I confess;
	And, as the jest did glance away from me,
	'Tis ten to one it maim'd you two outright.
</PETRUCHIO>

<BAPTISTA>	<95%>
	Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio,
	I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.
</BAPTISTA>

<PETRUCHIO>	<95%>
	Well, I say no: and therefore, for assurance,
	Let's each one send unto his wife;
	And he whose wife is most obedient
	To come at first when he doth send for her,
	Shall win the wager which we will propose.
</PETRUCHIO>

<HORTENSIO>	<95%>
	Content. What is the wager?
</HORTENSIO>

<LUCENTIO>	<95%>
	Twenty crowns.
</LUCENTIO>

<PETRUCHIO>	<95%>
	Twenty crowns!
	I'll venture so much of my hawk or hound,
	But twenty times so much upon my wife.
</PETRUCHIO>

<LUCENTIO>	<95%>
	A hundred then.
</LUCENTIO>

<HORTENSIO>	<95%>
	Content.
</HORTENSIO>

<PETRUCHIO>	<95%>
	A match! 'tis done.
</PETRUCHIO>

<HORTENSIO>	<95%>
	Who shall begin?
</HORTENSIO>

<LUCENTIO>	<95%>
	That will I.
	Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.
</LUCENTIO>

<BIONDELLO>	<95%>
	I go.
</BIONDELLO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

<BAPTISTA>	<95%>
	Son, I will be your half, Bianca comes.
</BAPTISTA>

<LUCENTIO>	<96%>
	I'll have no halves; I'll bear it all myself.

</LUCENTIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Re-enter Biondello.>
</STAGE DIR>
	How now! what news?
<BIONDELLO>	<96%>
	Sir, my mistress sends you word
	That she is busy and she cannot come.
</BIONDELLO>

<PETRUCHIO>	<96%>
	How! she is busy, and she cannot come!
	Is that an answer?
</PETRUCHIO>

<GREMIO>	<96%>
	Ay, and a kind one too:
	Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.
</GREMIO>

<PETRUCHIO>	<96%>
	I hope, better.
</PETRUCHIO>

<HORTENSIO>	<96%>
	Sirrah Biondello, go and entreat my wife
	To come to me forthwith.
</HORTENSIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit Biondello.>
</STAGE DIR>

<PETRUCHIO>	<96%>
	O ho! entreat her!
	Nay, then she must needs come.
</PETRUCHIO>

<HORTENSIO>	<96%>
	I am afraid, sir,
	Do what you can, yours will not be entreated.

</HORTENSIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Re-enter Biondello.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Now, where's my wife?
<BIONDELLO>	<96%>
	She says you have some goodly jest in hand:
	She will not come: she bids you come to her.
</BIONDELLO>

<PETRUCHIO>	<96%>
	Worse and worse; she will not come! O vile,
	Intolerable, not to be endur'd!
	Sirrah Grumio, go to your mistress; say,
	I command her come to me.
</PETRUCHIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit Grumio.>
</STAGE DIR>

<HORTENSIO>	<96%>
	I know her answer.
</HORTENSIO>

<PETRUCHIO>	<96%>
	What?
</PETRUCHIO>

<HORTENSIO>	<96%>
	She will not.
</HORTENSIO>

<PETRUCHIO>	<96%>
	The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.

</PETRUCHIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Re-enter Katharina.>
</STAGE DIR>
<BAPTISTA>	<96%>
	Now, by my holidame, here comes Katharina!
</BAPTISTA>

<KATHARINA>	<96%>
	What is your will, sir, that you send for me?
</KATHARINA>

<PETRUCHIO>	<97%>
	Where is your sister, and Hortensio's wife?
</PETRUCHIO>

<KATHARINA>	<97%>
	They sit conferring by the parlour fire.
</KATHARINA>

<PETRUCHIO>	<97%>
	Go, fetch them hither: if they deny to come,
	Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands.
	Away, I say, and bring them hither straight.
</PETRUCHIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit Katharina.>
</STAGE DIR>

<LUCENTIO>	<97%>
	Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.
</LUCENTIO>

<HORTENSIO>	<97%>
	And so it is. I wonder what it bodes.
</HORTENSIO>

<PETRUCHIO>	<97%>
	Marry, peace it bodes, and love, and quiet life,
	An awful rule and right supremacy;
	And, to be short, what not that's sweet and happy.
</PETRUCHIO>

<BAPTISTA>	<97%>
	Now fair befall thee, good Petruchio!
	The wager thou hast won; and I will add
	Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns;
	Another dowry to another daughter,
	For she is chang'd, as she had never been.
</BAPTISTA>

<PETRUCHIO>	<97%>
	Nay, I will win my wager better yet,
	And show more sign of her obedience,
	Her new-built virtue and obedience.
	See where she comes, and brings your froward wives
	As prisoners to her womanly persuasion.

<STAGE DIR>
<Re-enter Katharina, with Bianca and Widow.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Katharine, that cap of yours becomes you not:
	Off with that bauble, throw it under foot.
</PETRUCHIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Katharina pulls off her cap, and throws it down.>
</STAGE DIR>
<WIDOW>	<97%>
	Lord! let me never have a cause to sigh,
	Till I be brought to such a silly pass!
</WIDOW>

<BIANCA>	<98%>
	Fie! what a foolish duty call you this?
</BIANCA>

<LUCENTIO>	<98%>
	I would your duty were as foolish too:
	The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca,
	Hath cost me an hundred crowns since supper-time.
</LUCENTIO>

<BIANCA>	<98%>
	The more fool you for laying on my duty.
</BIANCA>

<PETRUCHIO>	<98%>
	Katharine, I charge thee, tell these headstrong women
	What duty they do owe their lords and husbands.
</PETRUCHIO>

<WIDOW>	<98%>
	Come, come, you're mocking: we will have no telling.
</WIDOW>

<PETRUCHIO>	<98%>
	Come on, I say; and first begin with her.
</PETRUCHIO>

<WIDOW>	<98%>
	She shall not.
</WIDOW>

<PETRUCHIO>	<98%>
	I say she shall: and first begin with her.
</PETRUCHIO>

<KATHARINA>	<98%>
	Fie, fie! unknit that threatening unkind brow,
	And dart not scornful glances from those eyes,
	To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor:
	It blots thy beauty as frosts do bite the meads,
	Confounds thy fame as whirlwinds shake fair buds,
	And in no sense is meet or amiable.
	A woman mov'd is like a fountain troubled,
	Muddy, ill-seeming, thick, bereft of beauty;
	And while it is so, none so dry or thirsty
	Will deign to sip or touch one drop of it.
	Thy husband is thy lord, thy life, thy keeper,
	Thy head, thy sovereign; one that cares for thee,
	And for thy maintenance commits his body
	To painful labour both by sea and land,
	To watch the night in storms, the day in cold,
	Whilst thou liest warm at home, secure and safe;
	And craves no other tribute at thy hands
	But love, fair looks, and true obedience;
	Too little payment for so great a debt.
	Such duty as the subject owes the prince,
	Even such a woman oweth to her husband;
	And when she's froward, peevish, sullen, sour,
	And not obedient to his honest will,
	What is she but a foul contending rebel,
	And graceless traitor to her loving lord?—
	I am asham'd that women are so simple
	To offer war where they should kneel for peace,
	Or seek for rule, supremacy, and sway,
	When they are bound to serve, love, and obey.
	Why are our bodies soft, and weak, and smooth,
	Unapt to toil and trouble in the world,
	But that our soft conditions and our hearts
	Should well agree with our external parts?
	Come, come, you froward and unable worms!
	My mind hath been as big as one of yours,
	My heart as great, my reason haply more,
	To bandy word for word and frown for frown;
	But now I see our lances are but straws,
	Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare,
	That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.
	Then vail your stomachs, for it is no boot,
	And place your hands below your husband's foot:
	In token of which duty, if he please,
	My hand is ready; may it do him ease.
</KATHARINA>

<PETRUCHIO>	<99%>
	Why, there's a wench! Come on, and kiss me, Kate.
</PETRUCHIO>

<LUCENTIO>	<100%>
	Well, go thy ways, old lad, for thou shalt ha't.
</LUCENTIO>

<VINCENTIO>	<100%>
	'Tis a good hearing when children are toward.
</VINCENTIO>

<LUCENTIO>	<100%>
	But a harsh hearing when women are froward.
</LUCENTIO>

<PETRUCHIO>	<100%>
	Come, Kate, we'll to bed.
	We three are married, but you two are sped.
	'Twas I won the wager, <STAGE DIR>
<To Lucentio.>
</STAGE DIR> though you hit the white;
	And, being a winner, God give you good night!
</PETRUCHIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Petruchio and Katharina.>
</STAGE DIR>

<HORTENSIO>	<100%>
	Now, go thy ways; thou hast tam'd a curst shrew.
</HORTENSIO>

<LUCENTIO>	<100%>
	'Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tam'd so.
</LUCENTIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>
</SCENE 2>
</ACT 5>
< Shakespeare -- THE TEMPEST >
< from Online Library of Liberty (http://oll.libertyfund.org) >
< Unicode .txt version by Mike Scott (http://www.lexically.net) >
< from "The Complete Works of William Shakespeare" >
< ed. with a glossary by W.J. Craig M.A. >
< (London: Oxford University Press, 1916) >
<STAGE DIR>
<Scene.—The Sea, with a Ship; afterwards an Island.>
</STAGE DIR>


<ACT 1>


<SCENE 1>
<On a Ship at Sea. A tempestuous noise of thunder and lightning heard.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter a Shipmaster and a Boatswain severally.>
</STAGE DIR>
<MASTER>	<1%>
	Boatswain!
</MASTER>

<BOATSWAIN>	<1%>
	Here, master: what cheer?
</BOATSWAIN>

<MASTER>	<1%>
	Good, speak to the mariners: fall to't yarely, or we run ourselves aground: bestir, bestir.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

</MASTER>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Mariners.>
</STAGE DIR>
<BOATSWAIN>	<1%>
	Heigh, my hearts! cheerly, cheerly, my hearts! yare, yare! Take in the topsail. Tend to the master's whistle.—Blow, till thou burst thy wind, if room enough!

</BOATSWAIN>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Alonso, Sebastian, Antonio, Ferdinand, Gonzalo, and others.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ALONSO>	<1%>
	Good boatswain, have care. Where's the master? Play the men.
</ALONSO>

<BOATSWAIN>	<1%>
	I pray now, keep below.
</BOATSWAIN>

<ANTONIO>	<1%>
	Where is the master, boson?
</ANTONIO>

<BOATSWAIN>	<1%>
	Do you not hear him? You mar our labour: keep your cabins: you do assist the storm.
</BOATSWAIN>

<GONZALO>	<1%>
	Nay, good, be patient.
</GONZALO>

<BOATSWAIN>	<1%>
	When the sea is. Hence! What cares these roarers for the name of king? To cabin: silence! trouble us not.
</BOATSWAIN>

<GONZALO>	<1%>
	Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.
</GONZALO>

<BOATSWAIN>	<1%>
	None that I more love than myself. You are a counsellor: if you can command these elements to silence, and work the peace of the present, we will not hand a rope more; use your authority: if you cannot, give thanks you have lived so long, and make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of the hour, if it so hap.—Cheerly, good hearts!—Out of our way, I say.
</BOATSWAIN>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

<GONZALO>	<2%>
	I have great comfort from this fellow: methinks he hath no drowning mark upon him; his complexion is perfect gallows. Stand fast, good Fate, to his hanging! make the rope of his destiny our cable, for our own doth little advantage! If he be not born to be hanged, our case is miserable.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</GONZALO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Re-enter Boatswain.>
</STAGE DIR>
<BOATSWAIN>	<2%>
	Down with the topmast! yare! lower, lower! Bring her to try with main-course. <STAGE DIR>
<A cry within.>
</STAGE DIR> A plague upon this howling! they are louder than the weather, or our office.—

</BOATSWAIN>
<STAGE DIR>
<Re-enter Sebastian, Antonio, and Gonzalo.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Yet again? what do you here? Shall we give o'er, and drown? Have you a mind to sink?
<SEBASTIAN>	<3%>
	A pox o' your throat, you bawling, blasphemous, incharitable dog!
</SEBASTIAN>

<BOATSWAIN>	<3%>
	Work you, then.
</BOATSWAIN>

<ANTONIO>	<3%>
	Hang, cur, hang! you whoreson, insolent noisemaker, we are less afraid to be drowned than thou art.
</ANTONIO>

<GONZALO>	<3%>
	I'll warrant him for drowning; though the ship were no stronger than a nutshell, and as leaky as an unstanched wench.
</GONZALO>

<BOATSWAIN>	<3%>
	Lay her a-hold, a-hold! Set her two courses; off to sea again; lay her off.

</BOATSWAIN>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Mariners, wet.>
</STAGE DIR>
<MIRANDA>	<3%>
	All lost! to prayers, to prayers! all lost!
</MIRANDA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

<BOATSWAIN>	<3%>
	What, must our mouths be cold?
</BOATSWAIN>

<GONZALO>	<3%>
	The king and prince at prayers! let us assist them,
	For our case is as theirs.
</GONZALO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<3%>
	I am out of patience.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<3%>
	We are merely cheated of our lives by drunkards.—
	This wide-chapp'd rascal,—would thou might'st lie drowning,
	The washing of ten tides!
</ANTONIO>

<GONZALO>	<3%>
	He'll be hang'd yet,
	Though every drop of water swear against it,
	And gape at wid'st to glut him.
<STAGE DIR>
<A confused noise within,—'Mercy on us!'—>
</STAGE DIR>
	'We split, we split!'—'Farewell, my wife and children!'—
	'Farewell, brother!'—'We split, we split, we split!'—]
</GONZALO>

<ANTONIO>	<4%>
	Let's all sink wi' the king.
</ANTONIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

<SEBASTIAN>	<4%>
	Let's take leave of him.
</SEBASTIAN>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

<GONZALO>	<4%>
	Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an acre of barren ground; long heath, brown furze, any thing. The wills above be done! but I would fain die a dry death.
</GONZALO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 1>


<SCENE 2>
<The Island: before the Cell of Prospero.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Prospero and Miranda.>
</STAGE DIR>
<MIRANDA>	<4%>
	If by your art, my dearest father, you have
	Put the wild waters in this roar, allay them.
	The sky, it seems, would pour down stinking pitch,
	But that the sea, mounting to th' welkin's cheek,
	Dashes the fire out. O! I have suffer'd
	With those that I saw suffer: a brave vessel,
	Who had, no doubt, some noble creatures in her,
	Dash'd all to pieces. O! the cry did knock
	Against my very heart. Poor souls, they perish'd.
	Had I been any god of power, I would
	Have sunk the sea within the earth, or e'er
	It should the good ship so have swallow'd and
	The fraughting souls within her.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<5%>
	Be collected:
	No more amazement. Tell your piteous heart
	There's no harm done.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<5%>
	O, woe the day!
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<5%>
	No harm.
	I have done nothing but in care of thee,—
	Of thee, my dear one! thee, my daughter!—who
	Art ignorant of what thou art, nought knowing
	Of whence I am: nor that I am more better
	Than Prospero, master of a full poor cell,
	And thy no greater father.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<5%>
	More to know
	Did never meddle with my thoughts.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<5%>
	'Tis time
	I should inform thee further. Lend thy hand,
	And pluck my magic garment from me.—So:
<STAGE DIR>
<Lays down his mantle.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Lie there, my art.—Wipe thou thine eyes; have comfort.
	The direful spectacle of the wrack, which touch'd
	The very virtue of compassion in thee,
	I have with such provision in mine art
	So safely order'd, that there is no soul—
	No, not so much perdition as an hair,
	Betid to any creature in the vessel
	Which thou heard'st cry, which thou saw'st sink. Sit down;
	For thou must now know further.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<6%>
	You have often
	Begun to tell me what I am, but stopp'd,
	And left me to a bootless inquisition,
	Concluding, 'Stay; not yet.'
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<6%>
	The hour's now come,
	The very minute bids thee ope thine ear;
	Obey and be attentive. Canst thou remember
	A time before we came unto this cell?
	I do not think thou canst, for then thou wast not
	Out three years old.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<6%>
	Certainly, sir, I can.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<6%>
	By what? by any other house or person?
	Of anything the image tell me, that
	Hath kept with thy remembrance.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<6%>
	'Tis far off;
	And rather like a dream than an assurance
	That my remembrance warrants. Had I not
	Four or five women once that tended me?
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<6%>
	Thou hadst, and more, Miranda. But how is it
	That this lives in thy mind? What seest thou else
	In the dark backward and abysm of time?
	If thou remember'st aught ere thou cam'st here,
	How thou cam'st here, thou may'st.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<7%>
	But that I do not.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<7%>
	Twelve year since, Miranda, twelve year since,
	Thy father was the Duke of Milan and
	A prince of power.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<7%>
	Sir, are not you my father?
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<7%>
	Thy mother was a piece of virtue, and
	She said thou wast my daughter; and thy father
	Was Duke of Milan, and his only heir
	A princess,—no worse issued.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<7%>
	O, the heavens!
	What foul play had we that we came from thence?
	Or blessed was't we did?
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<7%>
	Both, both, my girl:
	By foul play, as thou say'st, were we heav'd thence;
	But blessedly holp hither.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<7%>
	O! my heart bleeds
	To think o' the teen that I have turn'd you to,
	Which is from my remembrance. Please you, further.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<7%>
	My brother and thy uncle, call'd Antonio,—
	I pray thee, mark me,—that a brother should
	Be so perfidious!—he whom next thyself,
	Of all the world I lov'd, and to him put
	The manage of my state; as at that time,
	Through all the signiories it was the first,
	And Prospero the prime duke; being so reputed
	In dignity, and for the liberal arts,
	Without a parallel: those being all my study,
	The government I cast upon my brother,
	And to my state grew stranger, being transported
	And rapt in secret studies. Thy false uncle—
	Dost thou attend me?
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<8%>
	Sir, most heedfully.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<8%>
	Being once perfected how to grant suits,
	How to deny them, who t'advance, and who
	To trash for over-topping; new created
	The creatures that were mine, I say, or chang'd 'em,
	Or else new form'd 'em: having both the key
	Of officer and office, set all hearts i' the state
	To what tune pleas'd his ear; that now he was
	The ivy which had hid my princely trunk,
	And suck'd my verdure out on't.—Thou attend'st not.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<8%>
	O, good sir! I do.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<8%>
	I pray thee, mark me.
	I, thus neglecting worldly ends, all dedicated
	To closeness and the bettering of my mind
	With that, which, but by being so retir'd,
	O'erpriz'd all popular rate, in my false brother
	Awak'd an evil nature; and my trust,
	Like a good parent, did beget of him
	A falsehood in its contrary as great
	As my trust was; which had, indeed no limit,
	A confidence sans bound. He being thus lorded,
	Not only with what my revenue yielded,
	But what my power might else exact,—like one,
	Who having, into truth, by telling of it,
	Made such a sinner of his memory,
	To credit his own lie,—he did believe
	He was indeed the duke; out o' the substitution,
	And executing th' outward face of royalty,
	With all prerogative:—Hence his ambition growing,—
	Dost thou hear?
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<9%>
	Your tale, sir, would cure deafness.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<9%>
	To have no screen between this part he play'd
	And him he play'd it for, he needs will be
	Absolute Milan. Me, poor man,—my library
	Was dukedom large enough: of temporal royalties
	He thinks me now incapable; confederates,—
	So dry he was for sway,—wi' the king of Naples
	To give him annual tribute, do him homage;
	Subject his coronet to his crown, and bend
	The dukedom, yet unbow'd,—alas, poor Milan!—
	To most ignoble stooping.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<10%>
	O the heavens!
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<10%>
	Mark his condition and the event; then tell me
	If this might be a brother.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<10%>
	I should sin
	To think but nobly of my grandmother:
	Good wombs have borne bad sons.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<10%>
	Now the condition.
	This King of Naples, being an enemy
	To me inveterate, hearkens my brother's suit;
	Which was, that he, in lieu o' the premises
	Of homage and I know not how much tribute,
	Should presently extirpate me and mine
	Out of the dukedom, and confer fair Milan,
	With all the honours on my brother: whereon,
	A treacherous army levied, one midnight
	Fated to the purpose did Antonio open
	The gates of Milan; and, i' the dead of darkness,
	The ministers for the purpose hurried thence
	Me and thy crying self.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<10%>
	Alack, for pity!
	I, not rememb'ring how I cried out then,
	Will cry it o'er again: it is a hint,
	That wrings mine eyes to 't.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<10%>
	Hear a little further,
	And then I'll bring thee to the present business
	Which now's upon us; without the which this story
	Were most impertinent.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<11%>
	Wherefore did they not
	That hour destroy us?
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<11%>
	Well demanded, wench:
	My tale provokes that question. Dear, they durst not,
	So dear the love my people bore me, nor set
	A mark so bloody on the business; but
	With colours fairer painted their foul ends.
	In few, they hurried us aboard a bark,
	Bore us some leagues to sea; where they prepar'd
	A rotten carcass of a boat, not rigg'd,
	Nor tackle, sail, nor mast; the very rats
	Instinctively have quit it: there they hoist us,
	To cry to the sea that roar'd to us; to sigh
	To the winds whose pity, sighing back again,
	Did us but loving wrong.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<11%>
	Alack! what trouble
	Was I then to you!
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<11%>
	O, a cherubin
	Thou wast, that did preserve me! Thou didst smile,
	Infused with a fortitude from heaven,
	When I have deck'd the sea with drops full salt,
	Under my burden groan'd; which rais'd in me
	An undergoing stomach, to bear up
	Against what should ensue.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<11%>
	How came we ashore?
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<12%>
	By Providence divine.
	Some food we had and some fresh water that
	A noble Neapolitan, Gonzalo,
	Out of his charity,—who being then appointed
	Master of this design,—did give us; with
	Rich garments, linens, stuffs, and necessaries,
	Which since have steaded much; so, of his gentleness,
	Knowing I lov'd my books, he furnish'd me,
	From mine own library with volumes that
	I prize above my dukedom.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<12%>
	Would I might
	But ever see that man!
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<12%>
	Now I arise:—
<STAGE DIR>
<Resumes his mantle.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Sit still, and hear the last of our sea-sorrow.
	Here in this island we arriv'd; and here
	Have I, thy schoolmaster, made thee more profit
	Than other princes can, that have more time
	For vainer hours and tutors not so careful.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<12%>
	Heavens thank you for't! And now, I pray you, sir,—
	For still 'tis beating in my mind,—your reason
	For raising this sea-storm?
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<12%>
	Know thus far forth.
	By accident most strange, bountiful Fortune,
	Now my dear lady, hath mine enemies
	Brought to this shore; and by my prescience
	I find my zenith doth depend upon
	A most auspicious star, whose influence
	If now I court not but omit, my fortunes
	Will ever after droop. Here cease more questions;
	Thou art inclin'd to sleep; 'tis a good dulness,
	And give it way;—I know thou canst not choose.—
<STAGE DIR>
<Miranda sleeps.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Come away, servant, come! I'm ready now.
	Approach, my Ariel; come!

</PROSPERO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Ariel.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ARIEL>	<13%>
	All hail, great master! grave sir, hail! I come
	To answer thy best pleasure; be't to fly,
	To swim, to dive into the fire, to ride
	On the curl'd clouds: to thy strong bidding task
	Ariel and all his quality.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<13%>
	Hast thou, spirit,
	Perform'd to point the tempest that I bade thee?
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<13%>
	To every article.
	I boarded the king's ship; now on the beak,
	Now in the waist, the deck, in every cabin,
	I flam'd amazement: sometime I'd divide
	And burn in many places; on the topmast,
	The yards, and boresprit, would I flame distinctly,
	Then meet, and join: Jove's lightnings, the precursors
	O' the dreadful thunder-claps, more momentary
	And sight-outrunning were not: the fire and cracks
	Of sulphurous roaring the most mighty Neptune
	Seem to besiege and make his bold waves tremble,
	Yea, his dread trident shake.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<14%>
	My brave spirit!
	Who was so firm, so constant, that this coil
	Would not infect his reason?
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<14%>
	Not a soul
	But felt a fever of the mad and play'd
	Some tricks of desperation. All but mariners,
	Plunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel,
	Then all a-fire with me: the king's son, Ferdinand,
	With hair up-staring,—then like reeds, not hair,—
	Was the first man that leap'd; cried, 'Hell is empty,
	And all the devils are here.'
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<14%>
	Why, that's my spirit!
	But was not this nigh shore?
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<14%>
	Close by, my master.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<14%>
	But are they, Ariel, safe?
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<14%>
	Not a hair perish'd;
	On their sustaining garments not a blemish,
	But fresher than before: and, as thou bad'st me,
	In troops I have dispers'd them 'bout the isle.
	The king's son have I landed by himself;
	Whom I left cooling of the air with sighs
	In an odd angle of the isle and sitting,
	His arms in this sad knot.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<15%>
	Of the king's ship
	The mariners, say how thou hast dispos'd,
	And all the rest o' the fleet.
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<15%>
	Safely in harbour
	Is the king's ship; in the deep nook, where once
	Thou call'dst me up at midnight to fetch dew
	From the still-vex'd Bermoothes; there she's hid:
	The mariners all under hatches stow'd;
	Who, with a charm join'd to their suffer'd labour,
	I have left asleep: and for the rest o' the fleet
	Which I dispers'd, they all have met again,
	And are upon the Mediterranean flote,
	Bound sadly home for Naples,
	Supposing that they saw the king's ship wrack'd,
	And his great person perish.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<15%>
	Ariel, thy charge
	Exactly is perform'd: but there's more work:
	What is the time o' th' day?
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<15%>
	Past the mid season.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<15%>
	At least two glasses. The time 'twixt six and now
	Must by us both be spent most preciously.
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<15%>
	Is there more toil? Since thou dost give me pains,
	Let me remember thee what thou hast promis'd
	Which is not yet perform'd me.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<16%>
	How now! moody?
	What is't thou canst demand?
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<16%>
	My liberty.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<16%>
	Before the time be out? no more!
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<16%>
	I prithee
	Remember, I have done thee worthy service;
	Told thee no lies, made no mistakings, serv'd
	Without or grudge or grumblings: thou didst promise
	To bate me a full year.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<16%>
	Dost thou forget
	From what a torment I did free thee?
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<16%>
	No.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<16%>
	Thou dost; and think'st it much to tread the ooze
	Of the salt deep,
	To run upon the sharp wind of the north,
	To do me business in the veins o' th' earth
	When it is bak'd with frost.
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<16%>
	I do not, sir.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<16%>
	Thou liest, malignant thing! Hast thou forgot
	The foul witch Sycorax, who with age and envy
	Was grown into a hoop? hast thou forgot her?
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<16%>
	No, sir.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<16%>
	Thou hast. Where was she born? speak; tell me.
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<16%>
	Sir, in Argier.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<16%>
	O! was she so? I must,
	Once in a month, recount what thou hast been,
	Which thou forget'st. This damn'd witch, Sycorax,
	For mischiefs manifold and sorceries terrible
	To enter human hearing, from Argier,
	Thou know'st, was banish'd: for one thing she did
	They would not take her life. Is not this true?
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<17%>
	Ay, sir.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<17%>
	This blue-ey'd hag was hither brought with child
	And here was left by the sailors. Thou, my slave,
	As thou report'st thyself, wast then her servant:
	And, for thou wast a spirit too delicate
	To act her earthy and abhorr'd commands,
	Refusing her grand hests, she did confine thee,
	By help of her more potent ministers,
	And in her most unmitigable rage,
	Into a cloven pine; within which rift
	Imprison'd, thou didst painfully remain
	A dozen years; within which space she died
	And left thee there, where thou didst vent thy groans
	As fast as mill-wheels strike. Then was this island,—
	Save for the son that she did litter here,
	A freckled whelp hag-born,—not honour'd with
	A human shape.
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<17%>
	Yes; Caliban her son.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<17%>
	Dull thing, I say so; he that Caliban,
	Whom now I keep in service. Thou best know'st
	What torment I did find thee in; thy groans
	Did make wolves howl and penetrate the breasts
	Of ever-angry bears: it was a torment
	To lay upon the damn'd, which Sycorax
	Could not again undo; it was mine art,
	When I arriv'd and heard thee, that made gape
	The pine, and let thee out.
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<18%>
	I thank thee, master.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<18%>
	If thou more murmur'st, I will rend an oak
	And peg thee in his knotty entrails till
	Thou hast howl'd away twelve winters.
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<18%>
	Pardon, master;
	I will be correspondent to command,
	And do my spiriting gently.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<18%>
	Do so; and after two days
	I will discharge thee.
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<18%>
	That's my noble master!
	What shall I do? say what? what shall I do?
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<18%>
	Go make thyself like a nymph of the sea: be subject
	To no sight but thine and mine; invisible
	To every eyeball else. Go, take this shape,
	And hither come in't: go, hence with diligence!
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit Ariel.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Awake, dear heart, awake! thou hast slept well;
	Awake!
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<19%>
<STAGE DIR>
<Waking.>
</STAGE DIR> The strangeness of your story put
	Heaviness in me.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<19%>
	Shake it off. Come on;
	We'll visit Caliban my slave, who never
	Yields us kind answer.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<19%>
	'Tis a villain, sir,
	I do not love to look on.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<19%>
	But, as 'tis,
	We cannot miss him: he does make our fire,
	Fetch in our wood; and serves in offices
	That profit us.—What ho! slave! Caliban!
	Thou earth, thou! speak.
</PROSPERO>

<CALIBAN>	<19%>
<STAGE DIR>
<Within.>
</STAGE DIR> There's wood enough within.
</CALIBAN>

<PROSPERO>	<19%>
	Come forth, I say; there's other business for thee:
	Come, thou tortoise! when?

<STAGE DIR>
<Re-enter Ariel, like a water-nymph.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Fine apparition! My quaint Ariel,
</PROSPERO>
	Hark in thine ear.
<ARIEL>	<19%>
	My lord, it shall be done.
</ARIEL>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

<PROSPERO>	<19%>
	Thou poisonous slave, got by the devil himself
	Upon thy wicked dam, come forth!

</PROSPERO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Caliban.>
</STAGE DIR>
<CALIBAN>	<19%>
	As wicked dew as e'er my mother brush'd
	With raven's feather from unwholesome fen
	Drop on you both! a south-west blow on ye,
	And blister you all o'er!
</CALIBAN>

<PROSPERO>	<20%>
	For this, be sure, to-night thou shalt have cramps,
	Side-stitches that shall pen thy breath up; urchins
	Shall forth at vast of night, that they may work
	All exercise on thee: thou shalt be pinch'd
	As thick as honeycomb, each pinch more stinging
	Than bees that made them.
</PROSPERO>

<CALIBAN>	<20%>
	I must eat my dinner.
	This island's mine, by Sycorax my mother,
	Which thou tak'st from me. When thou camest first,
	Thou strok'dst me, and mad'st much of me; wouldst give me
	Water with berries in't; and teach me how
	To name the bigger light, and how the less,
	That burn by day and night: and then I lov'd thee
	And show'd thee all the qualities o' th' isle,
	The fresh springs, brine-pits, barren place, and fertile.
	Cursed be I that did so!—All the charms
	Of Sycorax, toads, beetles, bats, light on you!
	For I am all the subjects that you have,
	Which first was mine own king; and here you sty me
	In this hard rock, whiles you do keep from me
	The rest o' th' island.
</CALIBAN>

<PROSPERO>	<21%>
	Thou most lying slave,
	Whom stripes may move, not kindness! I have us'd thee,
	Filth as thou art, with human care; and lodg'd thee
	In mine own cell, till thou didst seek to violate
	The honour of my child.
</PROSPERO>

<CALIBAN>	<21%>
	Oh ho! Oh ho!—would it had been done!
	Thou didst prevent me; I had peopled else
	This isle with Calibans.
</CALIBAN>

<PROSPERO>	<21%>
	Abhorred slave,
	Which any print of goodness will not take,
	Being capable of all ill! I pitied thee,
	Took pains to make thee speak, taught thee each hour
	One thing or other: when thou didst not, savage,
	Know thine own meaning, but wouldst gabble like
	A thing most brutish, I endow'd thy purposes
	With words that made them known: but thy vile race,
	Though thou didst learn, had that in't which good natures
	Could not abide to be with; therefore wast thou
	Deservedly confin'd into this rock,
	Who hadst deserv'd more than a prison.
</PROSPERO>

<CALIBAN>	<21%>
	You taught me language: and my profit on't
	Is, I know how to curse: the red plague rid you,
	For learning me your language!
</CALIBAN>

<PROSPERO>	<22%>
	Hag-seed, hence!
	Fetch us in fuel; and be quick, thou'rt best,
	To answer other business. Shrug'st thou, malice?
	If thou neglect'st, or dost unwillingly
	What I command, I'll rack thee with old cramps,
	Fill all thy bones with aches; make thee roar,
	That beasts shall tremble at thy din.
</PROSPERO>

<CALIBAN>	<22%>
	No, pray thee!—
<STAGE DIR>
<Aside.>
</STAGE DIR> I must obey: his art is of such power,
	It would control my dam's god, Setebos,
	And make a vassal of him.
</CALIBAN>

<PROSPERO>	<22%>
	So, slave; hence!
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit Caliban.>
</STAGE DIR>

<STAGE DIR>
<Re-enter Ariel invisible, playing and singing; Ferdinand following.>
</STAGE DIR>


<Ariel's Song.>

	Come unto these yellow sands,
	And then take hands:
	Curtsied when you have, and kiss'd,—
	The wild waves whist,—
	Foot it featly here and there;
	And, sweet sprites, the burden bear.
	Hark, hark!
<STAGE DIR>
<Burden Bow, wow, dispersedly.>
</STAGE DIR>
	The watch-dogs bark:
<STAGE DIR>
<Burden Bow, wow, dispersedly.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Hark, hark! I hear
	The strain of strutting Chanticleer
<STAGE DIR>
<Cry, Cock-a-diddle-dow.>
</STAGE DIR>

</PROSPERO>

<FERDINAND>	<23%>
	Where should this music be? i' th' air, or th' earth?
	It sounds no more;—and sure, it waits upon
	Some god o' th' island. Sitting on a bank,
	Weeping again the king my father's wrack,
	This music crept by me upon the waters,
	Allaying both their fury, and my passion,
	With its sweet air: thence I have follow'd it,—
	Or it hath drawn me rather,—but 'tis gone.
	No, it begins again.

<ARIEL SINGS.>Full fathom five thy father lies;
	Of his bones are coral made
	Those are pearls that were his eyes:
	Nothing of him that doth fade,
	But doth suffer a sea-change
	Into something rich and strange.
	Sea-nymphs hourly ring his knell:
<STAGE DIR>
<Burden ding-dong.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Hark! now I hear them,—ding-dong, bell.

</FERDINAND>

<FERDINAND>	<23%>
	The ditty does remember my drown'd father.
	This is no mortal business, nor no sound
	That the earth owes:—I hear it now above me.
</FERDINAND>

<PROSPERO>	<23%>
	The fringed curtains of thine eye advance,
	And say what thou seest yond.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<24%>
	What is't? a spirit?
	Lord, how it looks about! Believe me, sir,
	It carries a brave form:—but 'tis a spirit.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<24%>
	No, wench; it eats and sleeps, and hath such senses
	As we have, such; this gallant which thou see'st,
	Was in the wrack; and, but he's something stain'd
	With grief,—that's beauty's canker,—thou might'st call him
	A goodly person: he hath lost his fellows
	And strays about to find 'em.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<24%>
	I might call him
	A thing divine; for nothing natural
	I ever saw so noble.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<24%>
<STAGE DIR>
<Aside.>
</STAGE DIR> It goes on, I see,
	As my soul prompts it.—Spirit, fine spirit! I'll free thee
	Within two days for this.
</PROSPERO>

<FERDINAND>	<24%>
	Most sure, the goddess
	On whom these airs attend!—Vouchsafe, my prayer
	May know if you remain upon this island;
	And that you will some good instruction give
	How I may bear me here: my prime request,
	Which I do last pronounce, is,—O you wonder!—
	If you be maid or no?
</FERDINAND>

<MIRANDA>	<24%>
	No wonder, sir;
	But certainly a maid.
</MIRANDA>

<FERDINAND>	<24%>
	My language! heavens!—
	I am the best of them that speak this speech,
	Were I but where 'tis spoken.
</FERDINAND>

<PROSPERO>	<25%>
	How! the best?
	What wert thou, if the King of Naples heard thee?
</PROSPERO>

<FERDINAND>	<25%>
	A single thing, as I am now, that wonders
	To hear thee speak of Naples. He does hear me;
	And, that he does, I weep: myself am Naples,
	Who with mine eyes,—ne'er since at ebb,—beheld
	The king, my father wrack'd.
</FERDINAND>

<MIRANDA>	<25%>
	Alack, for mercy!
</MIRANDA>

<FERDINAND>	<25%>
	Yes, faith, and all his lords; the Duke of Milan,
	And his brave son being twain.
</FERDINAND>

<PROSPERO>	<25%>
<STAGE DIR>
<Aside.>
</STAGE DIR> The Duke of Milan,
	And his more braver daughter could control thee,
	If now 'twere fit to do't.—At the first sight
<STAGE DIR>
<Aside.>
</STAGE DIR>
	They have changed eyes:—delicate Ariel,
	I'll set thee free for this!—<STAGE DIR>
<To Fer.>
</STAGE DIR> A word, good sir;
	I fear you have done yourself some wrong: a word.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<25%>
<STAGE DIR>
<Aside.>
</STAGE DIR> Why speaks my father so ungently? This
	Is the third man that e'er I saw; the first
	That e'er I sigh'd for: pity move my father
	To be inclin'd my way!
</MIRANDA>

<FERDINAND>	<26%>
<STAGE DIR>
<Aside.>
</STAGE DIR> O! if a virgin,
	And your affection not gone forth, I'll make you
	The Queen of Naples.
</FERDINAND>

<PROSPERO>	<26%>
	Soft, sir: one word more—
<STAGE DIR>
<Aside.>
</STAGE DIR> They are both in either's powers: but this swift business
	I must uneasy make, lest too light winning
	Make the prize light.—<STAGE DIR>
<To Fer.>
</STAGE DIR> One word more: I charge thee
	That thou attend me. Thou dost here usurp
	The name thou ow'st not; and hast put thyself
	Upon this island as a spy, to win it
	From me, the lord on't.
</PROSPERO>

<FERDINAND>	<26%>
	No, as I am a man.
</FERDINAND>

<MIRANDA>	<26%>
	There's nothing ill can dwell in such a temple:
	If the ill spirit have so fair a house,
	Good things will strive to dwell with't.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<26%>
<STAGE DIR>
<To Fer.>
</STAGE DIR> Follow me.—
<STAGE DIR>
<To Mira.> 
</STAGE DIR>
	Speak not you for him; he's a traitor.—
<STAGE DIR>
<To Fer.>
</STAGE DIR> 
	Come;
	I'll manacle thy neck and feet together:
	Sea-water shalt thou drink; thy food shall be
	The fresh-brook muscles, wither'd roots and husks
	Wherein the acorn cradled. Follow.
</PROSPERO>

<FERDINAND>	<27%>
	No;
	I will resist such entertainment till
	Mine enemy has more power.
</FERDINAND>
<STAGE DIR>
<He draws, and is charmed from moving.>
</STAGE DIR>

<MIRANDA>	<27%>
	O dear father!
	Make not too rash a trial of him, for
	He's gentle, and not fearful.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<27%>
	What! I say,
	My foot my tutor?—Put thy sword up, traitor;
	Who mak'st a show, but dar'st not strike, thy conscience
	Is so possess'd with guilt: come from thy ward,
	For I can here disarm thee with this stick
	And make thy weapon drop.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<27%>
	Beseech you, father!
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<27%>
	Hence! hang not on my garments.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<27%>
	Sir, have pity:
	I'll be his surety.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<27%>
	Silence! one word more
	Shall make me chide thee, if not hate thee. What!
	An advocate for an impostor? hush!
	Thou think'st there is no more such shapes as he,
	Having seen but him and Caliban: foolish wench!
	To the most of men this is a Caliban
	And they to him are angels.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<27%>
	My affections
	Are then most humble; I have no ambition
	To see a goodlier man.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<28%>
<STAGE DIR>
<To Fer.>
</STAGE DIR> Come on; obey:
	Thy nerves are in their infancy again,
	And have no vigour in them.
</PROSPERO>

<FERDINAND>	<28%>
	So they are:
	My spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up.
	My father's loss, the weakness which I feel,
	The wrack of all my friends, or this man's threats,
	To whom I am subdued, are but light to me,
	Might I but through my prison once a day
	Behold this maid: all corners else o' th' earth
	Let liberty make use of; space enough
	Have I in such a prison.
</FERDINAND>

<PROSPERO>	<28%>
<STAGE DIR>
<Aside.] It works.—[To Fer.>
</STAGE DIR> Come on.—
	Thou hast done well, fine Ariel!—<STAGE DIR>
<To Fer.>
</STAGE DIR> Follow me.—
<STAGE DIR>
<To Ariel.>
</STAGE DIR> Hark, what thou else shalt do me.
</PROSPERO>

<MIRANDA>	<28%>
	Be of comfort;
	My father's of a better nature, sir,
	Than he appears by speech: this is unwonted,
	Which now came from him.
</MIRANDA>

<PROSPERO>	<28%>
	Thou shalt be as free
	As mountain winds; but then exactly do
	All points of my command.
</PROSPERO>

<ARIEL>	<28%>
	To the syllable.
</ARIEL>

<PROSPERO>	<28%>
<STAGE DIR>
<To Fer.>
</STAGE DIR> Come, follow.—Speak not for him.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</PROSPERO>

</SCENE 2>

</ACT 1>

<ACT 2>


<SCENE 1>
<Another Part of the Island.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Alonso, Sebastian, Antonio, Gonzalo, Adrian, Francisco, and others.>
</STAGE DIR>
<GONZALO>	<29%>
	Beseech you, sir, be merry: you have cause,
	So have we all, of joy; for our escape
	Is much beyond our loss. Our hint of woe
	Is common: every day some sailor's wife,
	The masters of some merchant and the merchant,
	Have just our theme of woe; but for the miracle,
	I mean our preservation, few in millions
	Can speak like us: then wisely, good sir, weigh
	Our sorrow with our comfort.
</GONZALO>

<ALONSO>	<29%>
	Prithee, peace.
</ALONSO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<29%>
	He receives comfort like cold porridge.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<29%>
	The visitor will not give him o'er so.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<29%>
	Look, he's winding up the watch of his wit; by and by it will strike.
</SEBASTIAN>

<GONZALO>	<29%>
	Sir,—
</GONZALO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<29%>
	One: tell.
</SEBASTIAN>

<GONZALO>	<29%>
	When every grief is entertain'd that's offer'd,
	Comes to the entertainer—
</GONZALO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<29%>
	A dollar.
</SEBASTIAN>

<GONZALO>	<29%>
	Dolour comes to him, indeed: you have spoken truer than you purposed.
</GONZALO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<30%>
	You have taken it wiselier than I meant you should.
</SEBASTIAN>

<GONZALO>	<30%>
	Therefore, my lord,—
</GONZALO>

<ANTONIO>	<30%>
	Fie, what a spendthrift is he of his tongue!
</ANTONIO>

<ALONSO>	<30%>
	I prithee, spare.
</ALONSO>

<GONZALO>	<30%>
	Well, I have done: but yet—
</GONZALO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<30%>
	He will be talking.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<30%>
	Which, of he or Adrian, for a good wager, first begins to crow?
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<30%>
	The old cock.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<30%>
	The cockerel.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<30%>
	Done. The wager?
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<30%>
	A laughter.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<30%>
	A match!
</SEBASTIAN>

<ADRIAN>	<30%>
	Though this island seem to be desert,—
</ADRIAN>

<SEBASTIAN>	<30%>
	Ha, ha, ha! So you're paid.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ADRIAN>	<30%>
	Uninhabitable, and almost inaccessible,—
</ADRIAN>

<SEBASTIAN>	<30%>
	Yet—
</SEBASTIAN>

<ADRIAN>	<30%>
	Yet—
</ADRIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<30%>
	He could not miss it.
</ANTONIO>

<ADRIAN>	<30%>
	It must needs be of subtle, tender, and delicate temperance.
</ADRIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<30%>
	Temperance was a delicate wench.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<30%>
	Ay, and a subtle; as he most learnedly delivered.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ADRIAN>	<30%>
	The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.
</ADRIAN>

<SEBASTIAN>	<30%>
	As if it had lungs, and rotten ones.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<30%>
	Or as 'twere perfumed by a fen.
</ANTONIO>

<GONZALO>	<31%>
	Here is everything advantageous to life.
</GONZALO>

<ANTONIO>	<31%>
	True; save means to live.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<31%>
	Of that there's none, or little.
</SEBASTIAN>

<GONZALO>	<31%>
	How lush and lusty the grass looks! how green!
</GONZALO>

<ANTONIO>	<31%>
	The ground indeed is tawny.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<31%>
	With an eye of green in't.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<31%>
	He misses not much.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<31%>
	No; he doth but mistake the truth totally.
</SEBASTIAN>

<GONZALO>	<31%>
	But the rarity of it is,—which is indeed almost beyond credit,—
</GONZALO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<31%>
	As many vouch'd rarities are.
</SEBASTIAN>

<GONZALO>	<31%>
	That our garments, being, as they were, drenched in the sea, hold notwithstanding their freshness and glosses; being rather new-dyed than stain'd with salt water.
</GONZALO>

<ANTONIO>	<31%>
	If but one of his pockets could speak, would it not say he lies?
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<31%>
	Ay, or very falsely pocket up his report.
</SEBASTIAN>

<GONZALO>	<31%>
	Methinks, our garments are now as fresh as when we put them on first in Afric, at the marriage of the king's fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.
</GONZALO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<31%>
	'Twas a sweet marriage, and we prosper well in our return.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ADRIAN>	<31%>
	Tunis was never graced before with such a paragon to their queen.
</ADRIAN>

<GONZALO>	<32%>
	Not since widow Dido's time.
</GONZALO>

<ANTONIO>	<32%>
	Widow! a pox o' that! How came that widow in? Widow Dido!
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<32%>
	What if he had said, widower Æneas too? Good Lord, how you take it!
</SEBASTIAN>

<ADRIAN>	<32%>
	Widow Dido, said you? you make me study of that: she was of Carthage, not of Tunis.
</ADRIAN>

<GONZALO>	<32%>
	This Tunis, sir, was Carthage.
</GONZALO>

<ADRIAN>	<32%>
	Carthage?
</ADRIAN>

<GONZALO>	<32%>
	I assure you, Carthage.
</GONZALO>

<ANTONIO>	<32%>
	His word is more than the miraculous harp.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<32%>
	He hath rais'd the wall, and houses too.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<32%>
	What impossible matter will he make easy next?
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<32%>
	I think he will carry this island home in his pocket, and give it his son for an apple.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<32%>
	And, sowing the kernels of it in the sea, bring forth more islands.
</ANTONIO>

<ALONSO>	<32%>
	Ay?
</ALONSO>

<ANTONIO>	<32%>
	Why, in good time.
</ANTONIO>

<GONZALO>	<32%>
<STAGE DIR>
<To Alon.>
</STAGE DIR> Sir, we were talking that our garments seem now as fresh as when we were at Tunis at the marriage of your daughter, who is now queen.
</GONZALO>

<ANTONIO>	<32%>
	And the rarest that e'er came there.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<33%>
	Bate, I beseech you, widow Dido.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<33%>
	O! widow Dido; ay, widow Dido.
</ANTONIO>

<GONZALO>	<33%>
	Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as the first day I wore it? I mean, in a sort.
</GONZALO>

<ANTONIO>	<33%>
	That sort was well fish'd for.
</ANTONIO>

<GONZALO>	<33%>
	When I wore it at your daughter's marriage?
</GONZALO>

<ALONSO>	<33%>
	You cram these words into mine ears, against
	The stomach of my sense. Would I had never
	Married my daughter there! for, coming thence,
	My son is lost; and, in my rate, she too,
	Who is so far from Italy remov'd,
	I ne'er again shall see her. O thou, mine heir
	Of Naples and of Milan! what strange fish
	Hath made his meal on thee?
</ALONSO>

<FRANCISCO>	<33%>
	Sir, he may live:
	I saw him beat the surges under him,
	And ride upon their backs: he trod the water,
	Whose enmity he flung aside, and breasted
	The surge most swoln that met him: his bold head
	'Bove the contentious waves he kept, and oar'd
	Himself with his good arms in lusty stroke
	To the shore, that o'er his wave-worn basis bow'd,
	As stooping to relieve him. I not doubt
	He came alive to land.
</FRANCISCO>

<ALONSO>	<34%>
	No, no; he's gone.
</ALONSO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<34%>
	Sir, you may thank yourself for this great loss,
	That would not bless our Europe with your daughter,
	But rather lose her to an African;
	Where she at least is banish'd from your eye,
	Who hath cause to wet the grief on't.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ALONSO>	<34%>
	Prithee, peace.
</ALONSO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<34%>
	You were kneel'd to and importun'd otherwise
	By all of us; and the fair soul herself
	Weigh'd between loathness and obedience, at
	Which end o' the beam should bow. We have lost your son,
	I fear, for ever: Milan and Naples have
	More widows in them of this business' making,
	Than we bring men to comfort them: the fault's
	Your own.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ALONSO>	<34%>
	So is the dearest of the loss.
</ALONSO>

<GONZALO>	<34%>
	My lord Sebastian,
	The truth you speak doth lack some gentleness
	And time to speak it in; you rub the sore,
	When you should bring the plaster.
</GONZALO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<34%>
	Very well.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<34%>
	And most chirurgeonly.
</ANTONIO>

<GONZALO>	<34%>
	It is foul weather in us all, good sir,
	When you are cloudy.
</GONZALO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<34%>
	Foul weather?
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<34%>
	Very foul.
</ANTONIO>

<GONZALO>	<34%>
	Had I plantation of this isle, my lord,—
</GONZALO>

<ANTONIO>	<35%>
	He'd sow't with nettle-seed.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<35%>
	Or docks, or mallows.
</SEBASTIAN>

<GONZALO>	<35%>
	'And were the king on't, what would I do?
</GONZALO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<35%>
	'Scape being drunk for want of wine.
</SEBASTIAN>

<GONZALO>	<35%>
	I' the commonwealth I would by contraries
	Execute all things; for no kind of traffic
	Would I admit; no name of magistrate;
	Letters should not be known; riches, poverty,
	And use of service, none; contract, succession,
	Bourn, bound of land, tilth, vineyard, none;
	No use of metal, corn, or wine, or oil;
	No occupation; all men idle, all;
	And women too, but innocent and pure;
	No sovereignty,—
</GONZALO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<35%>
	Yet he would be king on't.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<35%>
	The latter end of his commonwealth forgets the beginning.
</ANTONIO>

<GONZALO>	<35%>
	All things in common nature should produce
	Without sweat or endeavour: treason, felony,
	Sword, pike, knife, gun, or need of any engine,
	Would I not have; but nature should bring forth,
	Of its own kind, all foison, all abundance,
	To feed my innocent people.
</GONZALO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<35%>
	No marrying 'mong his subjects?
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<36%>
	None, man; all idle; whores and knaves.
</ANTONIO>

<GONZALO>	<36%>
	I would with such perfection govern, sir,
	To excel the golden age
</GONZALO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<36%>
	Save his majesty!
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<36%>
	Long live Gonzalo!
</ANTONIO>

<GONZALO>	<36%>
	And,—do you mark me, sir?
</GONZALO>

<ALONSO>	<36%>
	Prithee, no more: thou dost talk nothing to me.
</ALONSO>

<GONZALO>	<36%>
	I do well believe your highness; and did it to minister occasion to these gentlemen, who are of such sensible and nimble lungs that they always use to laugh at nothing.
</GONZALO>

<ANTONIO>	<36%>
	'Twas you we laugh'd at.
</ANTONIO>

<GONZALO>	<36%>
	Who in this kind of merry fooling am nothing to you; so you may continue and laugh at nothing still.
</GONZALO>

<ANTONIO>	<36%>
	What a blow was there given!
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<36%>
	An it had not fallen flat-long.
</SEBASTIAN>

<GONZALO>	<36%>
	You are gentlemen of brave mettle: you would lift the moon out of her sphere, if she would continue in it five weeks without changing.

</GONZALO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Ariel, invisible, playing solemn music.>
</STAGE DIR>
<SEBASTIAN>	<36%>
	We would so, and then go a-bat-fowling.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<36%>
	Nay, good my lord, be not angry.
</ANTONIO>

<GONZALO>	<36%>
	No, I warrant you; I will not adventure my discretion so weakly. Will you laugh me asleep, for I am very heavy?
</GONZALO>

<ANTONIO>	<37%>
	Go sleep, and hear us.
</ANTONIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<All sleep but Alon., Seb., and Ant.>
</STAGE DIR>

<ALONSO>	<37%>
	What! all so soon asleep! I wish mine eyes
	Would, with themselves, shut up my thoughts: I find
	They are inclin'd to do so.
</ALONSO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<37%>
	Please you, sir,
	Do not omit the heavy offer of it:
	It seldom visits sorrow; when it doth
	It is a comforter.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<37%>
	We two, my lord,
	Will guard your person while you take your rest,
	And watch your safety.
</ANTONIO>

<ALONSO>	<37%>
	Thank you. Wondrous heavy.
</ALONSO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Alonson sleeps. Exit Ariel.>
</STAGE DIR>

<SEBASTIAN>	<37%>
	What a strange drowsiness possesses them!
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<37%>
	It is the quality o' the climate.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<37%>
	Why
	Doth it not then our eyelids sink? I find not
	Myself dispos'd to sleep.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<37%>
	Nor I: my spirits are nimble.
	They fell together all, as by consent;
	They dropp'd, as by a thunder-stroke. What might,
	Worthy Sebastian? O! what might?—No more:—
	And yet methinks I see it in thy face,
	What thou should'st be. The occasion speaks thee; and
	My strong imagination sees a crown
	Dropping upon thy head.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<38%>
	What! art thou waking?
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<38%>
	Do you not hear me speak?
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<38%>
	I do; and surely,
	It is a sleepy language, and thou speak'st
	Out of thy sleep. What is it thou didst say?
	This is a strange repose, to be asleep
	With eyes wide open; standing, speaking, moving,
	And yet so fast asleep.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<38%>
	Noble Sebastian,
	Thou let'st thy fortune sleep—die rather; wink'st
	Whiles thou art waking.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<38%>
	Thou dost snore distinctly:
	There's meaning in thy snores.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<38%>
	I am more serious than my custom: you
	Must be so too, if heed me; which to do
	Trebles thee o'er.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<38%>
	Well; I am standing water.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<38%>
	I'll teach you how to flow.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<38%>
	Do so: to ebb,
	Hereditary sloth instructs me.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<38%>
	O!
	If you but knew how you the purpose cherish
	Whiles thus you mock it! how, in stripping it,
	You more invest it! Ebbing men, indeed,
	Most often do so near the bottom run
	By their own fear or sloth.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<39%>
	Prithee, say on:
	The setting of thine eye and cheek proclaim
	A matter from thee, and a birth indeed
	Which throes thee much to yield.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<39%>
	Thus, sir:
	Although this lord of weak remembrance, this
	Who shall be of as little memory
	When he is earth'd, hath here almost persuaded,—
	For he's a spirit of persuasion, only
	Professes to persuade,—the king, his son's alive,
	'Tis as impossible that he's undrown'd
	As he that sleeps here swims.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<39%>
	I have no hope
	That he's undrown'd.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<39%>
	O! out of that 'no hope
	What great hope have you! no hope that way is
	Another way so high a hope that even
	Ambition cannot pierce a wink beyond,
	But doubts discovery there. Will you grant with me
	That Ferdinand is drown'd?
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<39%>
	He's gone.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<39%>
	Then tell me
	Who's the next heir of Naples?
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<39%>
	Claribel.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<39%>
	She that is Queen of Tums; she that dwells
	Ten leagues beyond man's life; she that from Naples
	Can have no note, unless the sun were post—
	The man i' th' moon's too slow—till new-born chins
	Be rough and razorable: she that, from whom?
	We all were sea-swallow'd, though some cast again,
	And by that destiny to perform an act
	Whereof what's past is prologue, what to come
	In yours and my discharge.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<40%>
	What stuff is this!—How say you?
	'Tis true my brother's daughter's Queen of Tunis;
	So is she heir of Naples; 'twixt which regions
	There is some space.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<40%>
	A space whose every cubit
	Seems to cry out, 'How shall that Claribel
	Measure us back to Naples?—Keep in Tunis,
	And let Sebastian wake!'—Say, this were death
	That now hath seiz'd them; why, they were no worse
	Than now they are. There be that can rule Naples
	As well as he that sleeps; lords that can prate
	As amply and unnecessarily
	As this Gonzalo; I myself could make
	A chough of as deep chat. O, that you bore
	The mind that I do! what a sleep were this
	For your advancement! Do you understand me?
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<40%>
	Methinks I do.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<40%>
	And how does your content
	Tender your own good fortune?
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<41%>
	I remember
	You did supplant your brother Prospero.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<41%>
	True:
	And look how well my garments sit upon me;
	Much feater than before; my brother's servants
	Were then my fellows; now they are my men.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<41%>
	But, for your conscience,—
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<41%>
	Ay, sir; where lies that? if it were a kibe,
	'Twould put me to my slipper; but I feel not
	This deity in my bosom: twenty consciences,
	That stand 'twixt me and Milan, candied be they,
	And melt ere they molest! Here lies your brother,
	No better than the earth he lies upon,
	If he were that which now he's like, that's dead;
	Whom I, with this obedient steel,—three inches of it,—
	Can lay to bed for ever; whiles you, doing thus,
	To the perpetual wink for aye might put
	This ancient morsel, this Sir Prudence, who
	Should not upbraid our course. For all the rest,
	They'll take suggestion as a cat laps milk;
	They'll tell the clock to any business that
	We say befits the hour.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<41%>
	Thy case, dear friend,
	Shall be my precedent: as thou got'st Milan,
	I'll come by Naples. Draw thy sword: one stroke
	Shall free thee from the tribute which thou pay'st,
	And I the king shall love thee.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ANTONIO>	<42%>
	Draw together;
	And when I rear my hand, do you the like,
	To fall it on Gonzalo.
</ANTONIO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<42%>
	O! but one word.
<STAGE DIR>
<They converse apart.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SEBASTIAN>
<STAGE DIR>
<Music. Re-enter Ariel, invisible.>
</STAGE DIR>
<ARIEL>	<42%>
	My master through his art foresees the danger
	That you, his friend, are in; and sends me forth—
	For else his project dies—to keep thee living.
<STAGE DIR>
<Sings in Gonzalo's ear.>
</STAGE DIR>

	While you here do snoring lie,
	Open-ey'd Conspiracy
	His time doth take.
	If of life you keep a care,
	Shake off slumber, and beware
	Awake! awake!

</ARIEL>

<ANTONIO>	<42%>
	Then let us both be sudden.
</ANTONIO>

<GONZALO>	<42%>
	Now, good angels
	Preserve the king!
</GONZALO>
<STAGE DIR>
<They wake.>
</STAGE DIR>

<ALONSO>	<42%>
	Why, how now! ho, awake! Why are you drawn?
	Wherefore this ghastly looking?
</ALONSO>

<GONZALO>	<42%>
	What's the matter?
</GONZALO>

<SEBASTIAN>	<42%>
	Whiles we stood here securing your repose,
	Even now, we heard a hollow burst of bellowing
	Like bulls, or rather hons; did't not wake you?
	It struck mine ear most terribly.
</SEBASTIAN>

<ALONSO>	<43%>
	I heard nothing.
</ALONSO>

<ANTONIO>	<43%>
	O! 'twas a din to fright a monster's ear,
	To make an earthquake: sure it was the roar
	Of a whole herd of lions.
</ANTONIO>

<ALONSO>	<43%>
	Heard you this, Gonzalo?
</ALONSO>

<GONZALO>	<43%>
	Upon mine honour, sir, I heard a humming,
	And that a strange one too, which did awake me.
	I shak'd you, sir, and cry'd; as mine eyes open'd,
	I saw their weapons drawn:—there was a noise,
	That's verily. 'Tis best we stand upon our guard,
	Or that we quit this place: let's draw our weapons.
</GONZALO>

<ALONSO>	<43%>
	Lead off this ground, and let's make further search
	For my poor son.
</ALONSO>

<GONZALO>	<43%>
	Heavens keep him from these beasts!
	For he is, sure, i' the island.
</GONZALO>

<ALONSO>	<43%>
	Lead away.
</ALONSO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit with the others.>
</STAGE DIR>

<ARIEL>	<43%>
	Prospero my lord shall know what I have done:
	So, king, go safely on to seek thy son.
</ARIEL>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 1>


<SCENE 2>
<Another Part of the Island.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Caliban, with a burden of wood. A noise of thunder heard.>
</STAGE DIR>
<CALIBAN>	<44%>
	All the infections that the sun sucks up
	From bogs, fens, flats, on Prosper fall, and make him
	By inch-meal a disease! His spirits hear me,
	And yet I needs must curse. But they'll nor pinch,
	Fright me with urchin-shows, pitch me i' the mire,
	Nor lead me, like a firebrand, in the dark
	Out of my way, unless he bid 'em; but
	For every trifle are they set upon me:
	Sometime like apes, that mow and chatter at me
	And after bite me; then like hedge-hogs, which
	Lie tumbling in my bare-foot way and mount
	Their pricks at my foot-fall; sometime am I
	All wound with adders, who with cloven tongues
	Do hiss me into madness.—

<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Trinculo.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Lo now! lo!
	Here comes a spirit of his, and to torment me
	For bringing wood in slowly: I'll fall flat;
</CALIBAN>
	Perchance he will not mind me.
<TRINCULO>	<44%>
	Here's neither bush nor shrub to bear off any weather at all, and another storm brewing; I hear it sing i' the wind: yond same black cloud, yond huge one, looks like a foul bombard that would shed his liquor. If it should thunder as it did before, I know not where to hide my head: yond same cloud cannot choose but fall by pailfuls.—What have we here? a man or a fish? Dead or alive? A fish: he smells like a fish; a very ancient and fish-like smell; a kind of not of the newest Poor-John. A strange fish! Were I in England now,—as once I was,—and had but this fish painted, not a holiday fool there but would give a piece of silver: there would this monster make a man; any strange beast there makes a man. When they will not give a doit to relieve a lame beggar, they will lay out ten to see a dead Indian. Legg'd like a man! and his fins like arms! Warm, o' my troth! I do now let loose my opinion, hold it no longer; this is no fish, but an islander, that hath lately suffered by a thunderbolt. <STAGE DIR>
<Thunder.>
</STAGE DIR> Alas! the storm is come again: my best way is to creep under his gaberdine; there is no other shelter hereabout: misery acquaints a man with strange bedfellows. I will here shroud till the dregs of the storm be past.

</TRINCULO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Stephano, singing; a bottle in his hand.>
</STAGE DIR>
<STEPHANO>	<46%>

	I shall no more to sea, to sea,
	Here shall I die a-shore:—

	This is a very scurvy tune to sing at a man's funeral:
	Well, here's my comfort.
<STAGE DIR>
<Drinks.>
</STAGE DIR>

	The master, the swabber, the boatswain and I,
	The gunner and his mate,
	Lov'd Mall, Meg, and Marian and Margery,
	But none of us car'd for Kate;
	For she had a tongue with a tang,
	Would cry to a sailor, 'Go hang!'
	She lov'd not the savour of tar nor of pitch,
	Yet a tailor might scratch her where-e'er she did itch:
	Then to sea, boys, and let her go hang.

	This is a scurvy tune too: but here's my comfort.
</STEPHANO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Drinks.>
</STAGE DIR>

<CALIBAN>	<46%>
	Do not torment me: O!
</CALIBAN>

<STEPHANO>	<46%>
	What's the matter? Have we devils here? Do you put tricks upon us with savages and men of Ind? Ha! I have not 'scaped drowning, to be afeard now of your four legs; for it hath been said, As proper a man as ever went on four legs cannot make him give ground: and it shall be said so again while Stephano breathes at's nostrils.
</STEPHANO>

<CALIBAN>	<47%>
	The spirit torments me: O!
</CALIBAN>

<STEPHANO>	<47%>
	This is some monster of the isle with four legs, who hath got, as I take it, an ague. Where the devil should he learn our language? I will give him some relief, if it be but for that: if I can recover him and keep him tame and get to Naples with him, he's a present for any emperor that ever trod on neat's-leather.
</STEPHANO>

<CALIBAN>	<47%>
	Do not torment me, prithee: I'll bring my wood home faster.
</CALIBAN>

<STEPHANO>	<47%>
	He's in his fit now and does not talk after the wisest. He shall taste of my bottle: if he have never drunk wine afore it will go near to remove his fit. If I can recover him, and keep him tame, I will not take too much for him: he shall pay for him that hath him, and that soundly.
</STEPHANO>

<CALIBAN>	<47%>
	Thou dost me yet but little hurt; thou wilt anon, I know it by thy trembling: now Prosper works upon thee.
</CALIBAN>

<STEPHANO>	<47%>
	Come on your ways: open your mouth; here is that which will give language to you, cat. Open your mouth: this will shake your shaking, I can tell you, and that soundly <STAGE DIR>
<gives Caliban drink>
</STAGE DIR>: you cannot tell who's your friend; open your chaps again.
</STEPHANO>

<TRINCULO>	<48%>
	I should know that voice: it should be—but he is drowned, and these are devils. O! defend me.
</TRINCULO>

<STEPHANO>	<48%>
	Four legs and two voices; a most delicate monster! His forward voice now is to speak well of his friend; his backward voice is to utter foul speeches, and to detract. If all the wine in my bottle will recover him, I will help his ague. Come. Amen! I will pour some in thy other mouth.
</STEPHANO>

<TRINCULO>	<48%>
	Stephano!
</TRINCULO>

<STEPHANO>	<48%>
	Doth thy other mouth call me? Mercy! mercy! This is a devil, and no monster: I will leave him; I have no long spoon.
</STEPHANO>

<TRINCULO>	<48%>
	Stephano!—if thou beest Stephano, touch me, and speak to me; for I am Trinculo:—be not afeard—thy good friend Trinculo.
</TRINCULO>

<STEPHANO>	<48%>
	If thou beest Trinculo, come forth. I'll pull thee by the lesser legs: if any be Trinculo's legs, these are they. Thou art very Trinculo indeed! How cam'st thou to be the siege of this moon-calf? Can he vent Trinculos?
</STEPHANO>

<TRINCULO>	<49%>
	I took him to be killed with a thunderstroke. But art thou not drowned, Stephano? I hope now thou art not drowned. Is the storm overblown? I hid me under the dead mooncalf's gaberdine for fear of the storm. And art thou living, Stephano? O Stephano! two Neapolitans 'scaped!
</TRINCULO>

<STEPHANO>	<49%>
	Prithee, do not turn me about: my stomach is not constant.
</STEPHANO>

<CALIBAN>	<49%>
<STAGE DIR>
<Aside.>
</STAGE DIR> These be fine things an if they be not sprites.
	That's a brave god and bears celestial liquor:
	I will kneel to him.
</CALIBAN>

<STEPHANO>	<49%>
	How didst thou 'scape? How cam'st thou hither? swear by this bottle, how thou cam'st hither. I escaped upon a butt of sack, which the sailors heaved overboard, by this bottle! which I made of the bark of a tree with mine own hands, since I was cast ashore.
</STEPHANO>

<CALIBAN>	<49%>
	I'll swear upon that bottle, to be thy true subject; for the liquor is not earthly.
</CALIBAN>

<STEPHANO>	<49%>
	Here: swear then, how thou escapedst.
</STEPHANO>

<TRINCULO>	<50%>
	Swam ashore, man, like a duck: I can swim like a duck, I'll be sworn.
</TRINCULO>

<STEPHANO>	<50%>
	Here, kiss the book <STAGE DIR>
<gives Trinculo drink>
</STAGE DIR>. Though thou canst swim like a duck, thou art made like a goose.
</STEPHANO>

<TRINCULO>	<50%>
	O Stephano! hast any more of this?
</TRINCULO>

<STEPHANO>	<50%>
	The whole butt, man: my cellar is in a rock by the seaside, where my wine is hid. How now, moon-calf! how does thine ague?
</STEPHANO>

<CALIBAN>	<50%>
	Hast thou not dropped from heaven?
</CALIBAN>

<STEPHANO>	<50%>
	Out o the moon, I do assure thee: I was the man in the moon, when time was.
</STEPHANO>

<CALIBAN>	<50%>
	I have seen thee in her, and I do adore thee; my mistress showed me thee, and thy dog, and thy bush.
</CALIBAN>

<STEPHANO>	<50%>
	Come, swear to that; kiss the book; I will furnish it anon with new contents; swear.
</STEPHANO>

<TRINCULO>	<50%>
	By this good light, this is a very shallow monster.—I afeard of him!—a very weak monster.—The man i' the moon! a most poor credulous monster!—Well drawn, monster, in good sooth.
</TRINCULO>

<CALIBAN>	<50%>
	I'll show thee every fertile inch o' the island;
	And I will kiss thy foot. I prithee, be my god.
</CALIBAN>

<TRINCULO>	<51%>
	By this light, a most perfidious and drunken monster: when his god's asleep, he'll rob his bottle.
</TRINCULO>

<CALIBAN>	<51%>
	I'll kiss thy foot: I'll swear myself thy subject.
</CALIBAN>

<STEPHANO>	<51%>
	Come on then; down, and swear.
</STEPHANO>

<TRINCULO>	<51%>
	I shall laugh myself to death at this puppy-headed monster. A most scurvy monster! I could find in my heart to beat him,—
</TRINCULO>

<STEPHANO>	<51%>
	Come, kiss.
</STEPHANO>

<TRINCULO>	<51%>
	But that the poor monster's in drink: an abominable monster!
</TRINCULO>

<CALIBAN>	<51%>
	I'll shew thee the best springs; I'll pluck thee berries;
	I'll fish for thee, and get thee wood enough.
	A plague upon the tyrant that I serve!
	I'll bear him no more sticks, but follow thee,
	Thou wondrous man.
</CALIBAN>

<TRINCULO>	<51%>
	A most ridiculous monster, to make a wonder of a poor drunkard!
</TRINCULO>

<CALIBAN>	<51%>
	I prithee, let me bring thee where crabs grow;
	And I with my long nails will dig thee pig-nuts;
	Show thee a jay's nest and instruct thee how
	To snare the nimble marmozet; I'll bring thee
	To clust'ring filberts, and sometimes I'll get thee
	Young scamels from the rock. Wilt thou go with me?
</CALIBAN>

<STEPHANO>	<52%>
	I prithee now, lead the way, without any more talking.—Trinculo, the king and all our company else being drowned, we will inherit here.—Here; bear my bottle.—Fellow Trinculo, we'll fill him by and by again.
</STEPHANO>

<CALIBAN>	<52%>
	Farewell, master; farewell, farewell
</CALIBAN>
<STAGE DIR>
<Sings drunkenly.>
</STAGE DIR>

<TRINCULO>	<52%>
	A howling monster, a drunken monster.
</TRINCULO>

<CALIBAN>	<52%>

	No more dams I'll make for fish,
	Nor fetch in firing
	At requiring,
	Nor scrape trenchering, nor wash dish,
	'Ban, 'Ban, Ca—Caliban,
	Has a new master—Get a new man.

	Freedom, high-day! high-day, freedom! freedom! high-day, freedom!
</CALIBAN>

<STEPHANO>	<52%>
	O brave monster! lead the way.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</STEPHANO>

</SCENE 2>

</ACT 2>

<ACT 3>


<SCENE 1>
<Before Prospero's Cell.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Ferdinand, bearing a log.>
</STAGE DIR>
<FERDINAND>	<52%>
	There be some sports are painful, and their labour
	Delight in them sets off: some kinds of baseness
	Are nobly undergone, and most poor matters
	Point to rich ends. This my mean task
	Would be as heavy to me as odious; but
	The mistress which I serve quickens what's dead
	And makes my labours pleasures: O! she is
	Ten times more gentle than her father's crabbed,
	And he's compos'd of harshness. I must remove
	Some thousands of these logs and pile them up,
	Upon a sore injunction: my sweet mistress
	Weeps when she sees me work, and says such baseness
	Had never like executor. I forget:
	But these sweet thoughts do even refresh my labours,
	Most busiest when I do it.

</FERDINAND>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Miranda; and Prospero behind.>
</STAGE DIR>
<MIRANDA>	<53%>
	Alas! now, pray you,
	Work not so hard: I would the lightning had
	Burnt up those logs that you are enjoin'd to pile!
	Pray, set it down and rest you: when this burns,
	'Twill weep for having wearied you. My father
	Is hard at study; pray now, rest yourself:
	He's safe for these three hours.
</MIRANDA>

<FERDINAND>	<53%>
	O most dear mistress,
	The sun will set, before I shall discharge
	What I must strive to do.
</FERDINAND>

<MIRANDA>	<53%>
	If you'll sit down,
	I'll bear your logs the while. Pray, give me that;
	I'll carry it to the pile.
</MIRANDA>

<FERDINAND>	<54%>
	No, precious creature:
	I had rather crack my sinews, break my back,
	Than you should such dishonour undergo,
