<VALENTINE>	<22%>
	As you enjoin'd me, I have writ your letter
	Unto the secret nameless friend of yours;
	Which I was much unwilling to proceed in
	But for my duty to your ladyship.
</VALENTINE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Gives a letter.>
</STAGE DIR>

<SILVIA>	<22%>
	I thank you, gentle servant. 'Tis very clerkly done.
</SILVIA>

<VALENTINE>	<22%>
	Now, trust me, madam, it came hardly off;
	For, being ignorant to whom it goes
	I writ at random, very doubtfully.
</VALENTINE>

<SILVIA>	<22%>
	Perchance you think too much of so much pains?
</SILVIA>

<VALENTINE>	<22%>
	No, madam; so it stead you, I will write,
	Please you command, a thousand times as much.
	And yet—
</VALENTINE>

<SILVIA>	<23%>
	A pretty period! Well, I guess the sequel;
	And yet I will not name it; and yet I care not;
	And yet take this again; and yet I thank you,
	Meaning henceforth to trouble you no more.
</SILVIA>

<SPEED>	<23%>
<STAGE DIR>
<Aside.>
</STAGE DIR> And yet you will; and yet another yet.
</SPEED>

<VALENTINE>	<23%>
	What means your ladyship? do you not like it?
</VALENTINE>

<SILVIA>	<23%>
	Yes, yes: the lines are very quaintly writ,
	But since unwillingly, take them again:
	Nay, take them.
</SILVIA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Gives back the letter.>
</STAGE DIR>

<VALENTINE>	<23%>
	Madam, they are for you.
</VALENTINE>

<SILVIA>	<23%>
	Ay, ay; you writ them, sir, at my request,
	But I will none of them; they are for you.
	I would have had them writ more movingly.
</SILVIA>

<VALENTINE>	<23%>
	Please you, I'll write your ladyship another.
</VALENTINE>

<SILVIA>	<23%>
	And when it's writ, for my sake read it over:
	And if it please you, so; if not, why, so.
</SILVIA>

<VALENTINE>	<23%>
	If it please me, madam, what then?
</VALENTINE>

<SILVIA>	<23%>
	Why, if it please you, take it for your labour:
	And so, good morrow, servant.
</SILVIA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

<SPEED>	<24%>
	O jest unseen, inscrutable, invisible,
	As a nose on a man's face, or a weathercock on a steeple!
	My master sues to her, and she hath taught her suitor,
	He being her pupil, to become her tutor.
	O excellent device! was there ever heard a better,
	That my master, being scribe, to himself should write the letter?
</SPEED>

<VALENTINE>	<24%>
	How now, sir! what are you reasoning with yourself?
</VALENTINE>

<SPEED>	<24%>
	Nay, I was riming: 'tis you that have the reason.
</SPEED>

<VALENTINE>	<24%>
	To do what?
</VALENTINE>

<SPEED>	<24%>
	To be a spokesman from Madam Silvia.
</SPEED>

<VALENTINE>	<24%>
	To whom?
</VALENTINE>

<SPEED>	<24%>
	To yourself. Why, she wooes you by a figure.
</SPEED>

<VALENTINE>	<24%>
	What figure?
</VALENTINE>

<SPEED>	<24%>
	By a letter, I should say.
</SPEED>

<VALENTINE>	<24%>
	Why, she hath not writ to me?
</VALENTINE>

<SPEED>	<24%>
	What need she, when she hath made you write to yourself? Why, do you not perceive the jest?
</SPEED>

<VALENTINE>	<24%>
	No, believe me.
</VALENTINE>

<SPEED>	<24%>
	No believing you, indeed, sir. But did you perceive her earnest?
</SPEED>

<VALENTINE>	<24%>
	She gave me none, except an angry word.
</VALENTINE>

<SPEED>	<24%>
	Why, she hath given you a letter.
</SPEED>

<VALENTINE>	<24%>
	That's the letter I writ to her friend.
</VALENTINE>

<SPEED>	<25%>
	And that letter hath she delivered, and there an end.
</SPEED>

<VALENTINE>	<25%>
	I would it were no worse.
</VALENTINE>

<SPEED>	<25%>
	I'll warrant you, 'tis as well:
	'For often have you writ to her, and she, in modesty,
	Or else for want of idle time, could not again reply;
	Or fearing else some messenger that might her mind discover,
	Herself hath taught her love himself to write unto her lover.'
	All this I speak in print, for in print I found it.
	Why muse you, sir? 'tis dinner-time.
</SPEED>

<VALENTINE>	<25%>
	I have dined.
</VALENTINE>

<SPEED>	<25%>
	Ay, but hearken, sir: though the chameleon Love can feed on the air, I am one that am nourished by my victuals and would fain have meat. O! be not like your mistress: be moved, be moved.
</SPEED>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 1>


<SCENE 2>
<Verona. A Room in Julia's House.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Proteus and Julia.>
</STAGE DIR>
<PROTEUS>	<25%>
	Have patience, gentle Julia.
</PROTEUS>

<JULIA>	<25%>
	I must, where is no remedy.
</JULIA>

<PROTEUS>	<25%>
	When possibly I can, I will return.
</PROTEUS>

<JULIA>	<25%>
	If you turn not, you will return the sooner.
	Keep this remembrance for thy Julia's sake.
</JULIA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Gives him a ring.>
</STAGE DIR>

<PROTEUS>	<26%>
	Why, then, we'll make exchange: here, take you this.
</PROTEUS>
<STAGE DIR>
<Gives her another.>
</STAGE DIR>

<JULIA>	<26%>
	And seal the bargain with a holy kiss.
</JULIA>

<PROTEUS>	<26%>
	Here is my hand for my true constancy;
	And when that hour o'erslips me in the day
	Wherein I sigh not, Julia, for thy sake,
	The next ensuing hour some foul mischance
	Torment me for my love's forgetfulness!
	My father stays my coming; answer not.
	The tide is now: nay, not thy tide of tears;
	That tide will stay me longer than I should.
	Julia, farewell.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit Julia.>
</STAGE DIR>
	What! gone without a word?
	Ay, so true love should do: it cannot speak;
	For truth hath better deeds than words to grace it.

</PROTEUS>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Panthino.>
</STAGE DIR>
<PANTHINO>	<26%>
	Sir Proteus, you are stay'd for.
</PANTHINO>

<PROTEUS>	<26%>
	Go; I come, I come.
	Alas! this parting strikes poor lovers dumb.
</PROTEUS>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 2>


<SCENE 3>
<The Same. A Street.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Launce, leading a dog.>
</STAGE DIR>
<LAUNCE>	<27%>
	Nay, 'twill be this hour ere I have done weeping: all the kind of the Launces have this very fault. I have received my proportion, like the prodigious son, and am going with Sir Proteus to the imperial's court. I think Crab my dog be the sourest-natured dog that lives: my mother weeping, my father wailing, my sister crying, our maid howling, our cat wringing her hands, and all our house in a great perplexity, yet did not this cruel-hearted cur shed one tear. He is a stone, a very pebble stone, and has no more pity in him than a dog; a Jew would have wept to have seen our parting: why, my grandam, having no eyes, look you, wept herself blind at my parting. Nay, I'll show you the manner of it. This shoe is my father; no, this left shoe is my father: no, no, this left shoe is my mother; nay, that cannot be so neither:—yes, it is so; it is so; it hath the worser sole. This shoe, with the hole in, is my mother, and this my father. A vengeance on't! there 'tis: now, sir, this staff is my sister; for, look you, she is as white as a lily and as small as a wand: this hat is Nan, our maid: I am the dog; no, the dog is himself, and I am the dog,—O! the dog is me, and I am myself: ay, so, so. Now come I to my father; 'Father, your blessing;' now should not the shoe speak a word for weeping: now should I kiss my father; well, he weeps on. Now come I to my mother;—O, that she could speak now like a wood woman! Well, I kiss her; why, there 'tis; here's my mother's breath up and down. Now come I to my sister; mark the moan she makes: Now the dog all this while sheds not a tear nor speaks a word; but see how I lay the dust with my tears.

</LAUNCE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Panthino.>
</STAGE DIR>
<PANTHINO>	<28%>
	Launce, away, away, aboard! thy master is shipped, and thou art to post after with oars. What's the matter? why weepest thou, man? Away, ass! you'll lose the tide if you tarry any longer.
</PANTHINO>

<LAUNCE>	<28%>
	It is no matter if the tied were lost; for it is the unkindest tied that ever any man tied.
</LAUNCE>

<PANTHINO>	<28%>
	What's the unkindest tide?
</PANTHINO>

<LAUNCE>	<28%>
	Why, he that's tied here, Crab, my dog.
</LAUNCE>

<PANTHINO>	<28%>
	Tut, man, I mean thou'lt lose the flood; and, in losing the flood, lose thy voyage, and, in losing thy voyage, lose thy master; and, in losing thy master, lose thy service; and, in losing thy service,—Why dost thou stop my mouth?
</PANTHINO>

<LAUNCE>	<29%>
	For fear thou shouldst lose thy tongue.
</LAUNCE>

<PANTHINO>	<29%>
	Where should I lose my tongue?
</PANTHINO>

<LAUNCE>	<29%>
	In thy tale.
</LAUNCE>

<PANTHINO>	<29%>
	In thy tail!
</PANTHINO>

<LAUNCE>	<29%>
	Lose the tide, and the voyage, and the master, and the service, and the tied! Why, man, if the river were dry, I am able to fill it with my tears; if the wind were down, I could drive the boat with my sighs.
</LAUNCE>

<PANTHINO>	<29%>
	Come, come away, man; I was sent to call thee.
</PANTHINO>

<LAUNCE>	<29%>
	Sir, call me what thou darest.
</LAUNCE>

<PANTHINO>	<29%>
	Wilt thou go?
</PANTHINO>

<LAUNCE>	<29%>
	Well, I will go.
</LAUNCE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 3>


<SCENE 4>
<Milan. A Room in the Duke's Palace.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Valentine, Silvia, Thurio, and Speed.>
</STAGE DIR>
<SILVIA>	<29%>
	Servant!
</SILVIA>

<VALENTINE>	<29%>
	Mistress?
</VALENTINE>

<SPEED>	<29%>
	Master, Sir Thurio frowns on you.
</SPEED>

<VALENTINE>	<29%>
	Ay, boy, it's for love.
</VALENTINE>

<SPEED>	<29%>
	Not of you.
</SPEED>

<VALENTINE>	<29%>
	Of my mistress, then.
</VALENTINE>

<SPEED>	<30%>
	'Twere good you knock'd him.
</SPEED>

<SILVIA>	<30%>
	Servant, you are sad.
</SILVIA>

<VALENTINE>	<30%>
	Indeed, madam, I seem so.
</VALENTINE>

<THURIO>	<30%>
	Seem you that you are not?
</THURIO>

<VALENTINE>	<30%>
	Haply I do.
</VALENTINE>

<THURIO>	<30%>
	So do counterfeits.
</THURIO>

<VALENTINE>	<30%>
	So do you.
</VALENTINE>

<THURIO>	<30%>
	What seem I that I am not?
</THURIO>

<VALENTINE>	<30%>
	Wise.
</VALENTINE>

<THURIO>	<30%>
	What instance of the contrary?
</THURIO>

<VALENTINE>	<30%>
	Your folly.
</VALENTINE>

<THURIO>	<30%>
	And how quote you my folly?
</THURIO>

<VALENTINE>	<30%>
	I quote it in your jerkin.
</VALENTINE>

<THURIO>	<30%>
	My jerkin is a doublet.
</THURIO>

<VALENTINE>	<30%>
	Well, then, I'll double your folly.
</VALENTINE>

<THURIO>	<30%>
	How?
</THURIO>

<SILVIA>	<30%>
	What, angry, Sir Thurio! do you change colour?
</SILVIA>

<VALENTINE>	<30%>
	Give him leave, madam; he is a kind of chameleon.
</VALENTINE>

<THURIO>	<30%>
	That hath more mind to feed on your blood than live in your air.
</THURIO>

<VALENTINE>	<30%>
	You have said, sir.
</VALENTINE>

<THURIO>	<30%>
	Ay, sir, and done too, for this time.
</THURIO>

<VALENTINE>	<30%>
	I know it well, sir: you always end ere you begin.
</VALENTINE>

<SILVIA>	<30%>
	A fine volley of words, gentlemen, and quickly shot off.
</SILVIA>

<VALENTINE>	<30%>
	'Tis indeed, madam; we thank the giver.
</VALENTINE>

<SILVIA>	<30%>
	Who is that, servant?
</SILVIA>

<VALENTINE>	<30%>
	Yourself, sweet lady; for you gave the fire. Sir Thurio borrows his wit from your ladyship's looks, and spends what he borrows kindly in your company.
</VALENTINE>

<THURIO>	<31%>
	Sir, if you spend word for word with me, I shall make your wit bankrupt.
</THURIO>

<VALENTINE>	<31%>
	I know it well, sir: you have an exchequer of words, and, I think, no other treasure to give your followers; for it appears by their bare liveries that they live by your bare words.
</VALENTINE>

<SILVIA>	<31%>
	No more, gentlemen, no more. Here comes my father.

</SILVIA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Duke.>
</STAGE DIR>
<DUKE>	<31%>
	Now, daughter Silvia, you are hard beset.
	Sir Valentine, your father's in good health:
	What say you to a letter from your friends
	Of much good news?
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<31%>
	My lord, I will be thankful
	To any happy messenger from thence.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<31%>
	Know ye Don Antonio, your countryman?
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<31%>
	Ay, my good lord; I know the gentleman
	To be of worth and worthy estimation,
	And not without desert so well reputed.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<31%>
	Hath he not a son?
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<31%>
	Ay, my good lord; a son that well deserves
	The honour and regard of such a father.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<31%>
	You know him well?
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<32%>
	I know him as myself; for from our infancy
	We have convers'd and spent our hours together:
	And though myself have been an idle truant,
	Omitting the sweet benefit of time
	To clothe mine age with angel-like perfection,
	Yet hath Sir Proteus,—for that's his name,—
	Made use and fair advantage of his days:
	His years but young, but his experience old;
	His head unmellow'd, but his judgment ripe;
	And, in a word,—for far behind his worth
	Come all the praises that I now bestow,—
	He is complete in feature and in mind
	With all good grace to grace a gentleman.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<32%>
	Beshrew me, sir, but if he make this good,
	He is as worthy for an empress' love
	As meet to be an emperor's counsellor.
	Well, sir, this gentleman is come to me
	With commendation from great potentates;
	And here he means to spend his time awhile:
	I think, 'tis no unwelcome news to you.
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<32%>
	Should I have wish'd a thing, it had been he.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<32%>
	Welcome him then according to his worth.
	Silvia, I speak to you; and you, Sir Thurio:—
	For Valentine, I need not cite him to it.
	I'll send him hither to you presently.
</DUKE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

<VALENTINE>	<33%>
	This is the gentleman I told your ladyship
	Had come along with me, but that his mistress
	Did hold his eyes lock'd in her crystal looks.
</VALENTINE>

<SILVIA>	<33%>
	Belike that now she hath enfranchis'd them
	Upon some other pawn for fealty.
</SILVIA>

<VALENTINE>	<33%>
	Nay, sure, I think she holds them prisoners still.
</VALENTINE>

<SILVIA>	<33%>
	Nay, then he should be blind; and, being blind,
	How could he see his way to seek out you?
</SILVIA>

<VALENTINE>	<33%>
	Why, lady, Love hath twenty pairs of eyes.
</VALENTINE>

<THURIO>	<33%>
	They say that Love hath not an eye at all.
</THURIO>

<VALENTINE>	<33%>
	To see such lovers, Thurio, as yourself:
	Upon a homely object Love can wink.
</VALENTINE>

<SILVIA>	<33%>
	Have done, have done. Here comes the gentleman.

</SILVIA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Proteus.>
</STAGE DIR>
<VALENTINE>	<33%>
	Welcome, dear Proteus! Mistress, I beseech you,
	Confirm his welcome with some special favour.
</VALENTINE>

<SILVIA>	<33%>
	His worth is warrant for his welcome hither,
	If this be he you oft have wish'd to hear from.
</SILVIA>

<VALENTINE>	<33%>
	Mistress, it is: sweet lady, entertain him
	To be my fellow-servant to your ladyship.
</VALENTINE>

<SILVIA>	<34%>
	Too low a mistress for so high a servant.
</SILVIA>

<PROTEUS>	<34%>
	Not so, sweet lady; but too mean a servant
	To have a look of such a worthy mistress.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<34%>
	Leave off discourse of disability:
	Sweet lady, entertain him for your servant.
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<34%>
	My duty will I boast of, nothing else.
</PROTEUS>

<SILVIA>	<34%>
	And duty never yet did want his meed.
	Servant, you are welcome to a worthless mistress.
</SILVIA>

<PROTEUS>	<34%>
	I'll die on him that says so but yourself.
</PROTEUS>

<SILVIA>	<34%>
	That you are welcome?
</SILVIA>

<PROTEUS>	<34%>
	That you are worthless.

</PROTEUS>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter a Servant.>
</STAGE DIR>
<SERVANT>	<34%>
	Madam, my lord your father would speak with you.
</SERVANT>

<SILVIA>	<34%>
	I wait upon his pleasure. <STAGE DIR>
<Exit Servant.>
</STAGE DIR> Come, Sir Thurio,
	Go with me. Once more, new servant, welcome:
	I'll leave you to confer of home-affairs;
	When you have done, we look to hear from you.
</SILVIA>

<PROTEUS>	<34%>
	We'll both attend upon your ladyship.
</PROTEUS>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Silvia, Thurio, and Speed.>
</STAGE DIR>

<VALENTINE>	<34%>
	Now, tell me, how do all from whence you came?
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<34%>
	Your friends are well and have them much commended.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<35%>
	And how do yours?
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<35%>
	I left them all in health.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<35%>
	How does your lady and how thrives your love?
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<35%>
	My tales of love were wont to weary you;
	I know you joy not in a love-discourse.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<35%>
	Ay, Proteus, but that life is alter'd now:
	I have done penance for contemning love;
	Whose high imperious thoughts have punish'd me
	With bitter fasts, with penitential groans,
	With nightly tears and daily heart-sore sighs;
	For, in revenge of my contempt of love,
	Love hath chas'd sleep from my enthralled eyes,
	And made them watchers of mine own heart's sorrow.
	O, gentle Proteus! Love's a mighty lord,
	And hath so humbled me as I confess,
	There is no woe to his correction,
	Nor to his service no such joy on earth.
	Now no discourse, except it be of love;
	Now can I break my fast, dine, sup and sleep,
	Upon the very naked name of love.
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<35%>
	Enough; I read your fortune in your eye.
	Was this the idol that you worship so?
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<35%>
	Even she; and is she not a heavenly saint?
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<35%>
	No; but she is an earthly paragon.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<36%>
	Call her divine.
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<36%>
	I will not flatter her.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<36%>
	O! flatter me, for love delights in praises.
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<36%>
	When I was sick you gave me bitter pills,
	And I must minister the like to you.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<36%>
	Then speak the truth by her; if not divine,
	Yet let her be a principality,
	Sovereign to all the creatures on the earth.
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<36%>
	Except my mistress.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<36%>
	Sweet, except not any,
	Except thou wilt except against my love.
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<36%>
	Have I not reason to prefer mine own?
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<36%>
	And I will help thee to prefer her too:
	She shall be dignified with this high honour,—
	To bear my lady's train, lest the base earth
	Should from her vesture chance to steal a kiss,
	And, of so great a favour growing proud,
	Disdain to root the summer-swelling flower,
	And make rough winter everlastingly.
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<36%>
	Why, Valentine, what braggardism is this?
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<36%>
	Pardon me, Proteus: all I can is nothing
	To her whose worth makes other worthies nothing.
	She is alone.
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<36%>
	Then, let her alone.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<36%>
	Not for the world: why, man, she is mine own,
	And I as rich in having such a jewel
	As twenty seas, if all their sand were pearl,
	The water nectar, and the rocks pure gold.
	Forgive me that I do not dream on thee,
	Because thou see'st me dote upon my love.
	My foolish rival, that her father likes
	Only for his possessions are so huge,
	Is gone with her along, and I must after,
	For love, thou know'st, is full of jealousy.
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<37%>
	But she loves you?
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<37%>
	Ay, and we are betroth'd: nay, more, our marriage-hour,
	With all the cunning manner of our flight,
	Determin'd of: how I must climb her window,
	The ladder made of cords, and all the means
	Plotted and 'greed on for my happiness.
	Good Proteus, go with me to my chamber,
	In these affairs to aid me with thy counsel.
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<37%>
	Go on before, I shall inquire you forth:
	I must unto the road, to disembark
	Some necessaries that I needs must use,
	And then I'll presently attend you.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<37%>
	Will you make haste?
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<37%>
	I will.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit Valentine.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Even as one heat another heat expels,
	Or as one nail by strength drives out another,
	So the remembrance of my former love
	Is by a newer object quite forgotten.
	Is it mine eye, or Valentinus' praise,
	Her true perfection, or my false transgression,
	That makes me reasonless to reason thus?
	She's fair; and so is Julia that I love,—
	That I did love, for now my love is thaw'd,
	Which, like a waxen image 'gainst a fire,
	Bears no impression of the thing it was.
	Methinks my zeal to Valentine is cold,
	And that I love him not as I was wont:
	O! but I love his lady too-too much;
	And that's the reason I love him so little.
	How shall I dote on her with more advice,
	That thus without advice begin to love her?
	'Tis but her picture I have yet beheld,
	And that hath dazzled my reason's light;
	But when I look on her perfections,
	There is no reason but I shall be blind.
	If I can check my erring love, I will;
	If not, to compass her I'll use my skill.
</PROTEUS>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 4>


<SCENE 5>
<The Same. A Street.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Speed and Launce.>
</STAGE DIR>
<SPEED>	<38%>
	Launce! by mine honesty, welcome to Milan!
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<39%>
	Forswear not thyself, sweet youth, for I am not welcome. I reckon this always that a man is never undone till he be hanged; nor never welcome to a place till some certain shot be paid and the hostess say, 'Welcome!'
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<39%>
	Come on, you madcap, I'll to the alehouse with you presently; where, for one shot of five pence, thou shalt have five thousand welcomes. But, sirrah, how did thy master part with Madam Julia?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<39%>
	Marry, after they closed in earnest, they parted very fairly in jest.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<39%>
	But shall she marry him?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<39%>
	No.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<39%>
	How then? Shall he marry her?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<39%>
	No, neither.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<39%>
	What, are they broken?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<39%>
	No, they are both as whole as a fish.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<39%>
	Why then, how stands the matter with them?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<39%>
	Marry, thus; when it stands well with him, it stands well with her.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<39%>
	What an ass art thou! I understand thee not.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<39%>
	What a block art thou, that thou canst not! My staff understands me.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<39%>
	What thou sayest?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<40%>
	Ay, and what I do too: look thee, I'll but lean, and my staff understands me.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<40%>
	It stands under thee, indeed.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<40%>
	Why, stand-under and under-stand is all one.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<40%>
	But tell me true, will't be a match?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<40%>
	Ask my dog: if he say ay, it will; if he say no, it will; if he shake his tail and say nothing, it will.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<40%>
	The conclusion is, then, that it will.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<40%>
	Thou shalt never get such a secret from me but by a parable.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<40%>
	'Tis well that I get it so. But, Launce, how sayest thou, that my master is become a notable lover?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<40%>
	I never knew him otherwise.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<40%>
	Than how?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<40%>
	A notable lubber, as thou reportest him to be.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<40%>
	Why, thou whoreson ass, thou mistakest me.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<40%>
	Why, fool, I meant not thee; I meant thy master.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<40%>
	I tell thee, my master is become a hot lover.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<40%>
	Why, I tell thee, I care not though he burn himself in love. If thou wilt go with me to the alehouse so; if not, thou art a Hebrew, a Jew, and not worth the name of a Christian.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<41%>
	Why?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<41%>
	Because thou hast not so much charity in thee as to go to the ale with a Christian. Wilt thou go?
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<41%>
	At thy service.
</SPEED>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 5>


<SCENE 6>
<The Same. A Room in the Duke's Palace.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Proteus.>
</STAGE DIR>
<PROTEUS>	<41%>
	To leave my Julia, shall I be forsworn;
	To love fair Silvia, shall I be forsworn;
	To wrong my friend, I shall be much forsworn;
	And even that power which gave me first my oath
	Provokes me to this threefold perjury:
	Love bade me swear, and Love bids me forswear.
	O sweet-suggesting Love! if thou hast sinn'd,
	Teach me, thy tempted subject, to excuse it.
	At first I did adore a twinkling star,
	But now I worship a celestial sun.
	Unheedful vows may heedfully be broken;
	And he wants wit that wants resolved will
	To learn his wit to exchange the bad for better.
	Fie, fie, unreverend tongue! to call her bad,
	Whose sovereignty so oft thou hast preferr'd
	With twenty thousand soul-confirming oaths.
	I cannot leave to love, and yet I do;
	But there I leave to love where I should love.
	Julia I lose and Valentine I lose:
	If I keep them, I needs must lose myself;
	If I lose them, thus find I by their loss,
	For Valentine, myself; for Julia, Silvia.
	I to myself am dearer than a friend,
	For love is still most precious in itself;
	And Silvia—witness heaven that made her fair!—
	Shows Julia but a swarthy Ethiope.
	I will forget that Julia is alive,
	Remembering that my love to her is dead;
	And Valentine I'll hold an enemy,
	Aiming at Silvia as a sweeter friend.
	I cannot now prove constant to myself
	Without some treachery us'd to Valentine:
	This night he meaneth with a corded ladder
	To climb celestial Silvia's chamber-window,
	Myself in counsel, his competitor.
	Now presently, I'll give her father notice
	Of their disguising and pretended flight;
	Who, all enrag'd, will banish Valentine;
	For Thurio, he intends, shall wed his daughter;
	But, Valentine being gone, I'll quickly cross,
	By some sly trick blunt Thurio's dull proceeding.
	Love, lend me wings to make my purpose swift,
	As thou hast lent me wit to plot this drift!
</PROTEUS>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 6>


<SCENE 7>
<Verona. A Room in Julia's House>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Julia and Lucetta.>
</STAGE DIR>
<JULIA>	<43%>
	Counsel, Lucetta; gentle girl, assist me:
	And e'en in kind love I do conjure thee,
	Who art the table wherein all my thoughts
	Are visibly character'd and engrav'd,
	To lesson me and tell me some good mean
	How, with my honour, I may undertake
	A journey to my loving Proteus.
</JULIA>

<LUCETTA>	<43%>
	Alas! the way is wearisome and long.
</LUCETTA>

<JULIA>	<43%>
	A true-devoted pilgrim is not weary
	To measure kingdoms with his feeble steps;
	Much less shall she that hath Love's wings to fly,
	And when the flight is made to one so dear,
	Of such divine perfection, as Sir Proteus.
</JULIA>

<LUCETTA>	<43%>
	Better forbear till Proteus make return.
</LUCETTA>

<JULIA>	<43%>
	O! know'st thou not his looks are my soul's food?
	Pity the dearth that I have pined in,
	By longing for that food so long a time.
	Didst thou but know the inly touch of love,
	Thou wouldst as soon go kindle fire with snow
	As seek to quench the fire of love with words.
</JULIA>

<LUCETTA>	<44%>
	I do not seek to quench your love's hot fire,
	But qualify the fire's extreme rage,
	Lest it should burn above the bounds of reason.
</LUCETTA>

<JULIA>	<44%>
	The more thou damm'st it up, the more it burns.
	The current that with gentle murmur glides,
	Thou know'st, being stopp'd, impatiently doth rage;
	But when his fair course is not hindered,
	He makes sweet music with th' enamell'd stones,
	Giving a gentle kiss to every sedge
	He overtaketh in his pilgrimage;
	And so by many winding nooks he strays
	With willing sport, to the wild ocean.
	Then let me go and hinder not my course:
	I'll be as patient as a gentle stream
	And make a pastime of each weary step,
	Till the last step have brought me to my love;
	And there I'll rest, as after much turmoil
	A blessed soul doth in Elysium.
</JULIA>

<LUCETTA>	<44%>
	But in what habit will you go along?
</LUCETTA>

<JULIA>	<44%>
	Not like a woman; for I would prevent
	The loose encounters of lascivious men.
	Gentle Lucetta, fit me with such weeds
	As may beseem some well-reputed page.
</JULIA>

<LUCETTA>	<44%>
	Why, then, your ladyship must cut your hair.
</LUCETTA>

<JULIA>	<45%>
	No, girl; I'll knit it up in silken strings
	With twenty odd-conceited true-love knots:
	To be fantastic may become a youth
	Of greater time than I shall show to be.
</JULIA>

<LUCETTA>	<45%>
	What fashion, madam, shall I make your breeches?
</LUCETTA>

<JULIA>	<45%>
	That fits as well as 'Tell me, good my lord,
	What compass will you wear your farthingale?'
	Why, even what fashion thou best lik'st, Lucetta.
</JULIA>

<LUCETTA>	<45%>
	You must needs have them with a cod-piece, madam.
</LUCETTA>

<JULIA>	<45%>
	Out, out, Lucetta! that will be ill-favour'd.
</JULIA>

<LUCETTA>	<45%>
	A round hose, madam, now's not worth a pin,
	Unless you have a cod-piece to stick pins on.
</LUCETTA>

<JULIA>	<45%>
	Lucetta, as thou lov'st me, let me have
	What thou think'st meet and is most mannerly.
	But tell me, wench, how will the world repute me
	For undertaking so unstaid a journey?
	I fear me, it will make me scandaliz'd.
</JULIA>

<LUCETTA>	<45%>
	If you think so, then stay at home and go not.
</LUCETTA>

<JULIA>	<45%>
	Nay, that I will not.
</JULIA>

<LUCETTA>	<45%>
	Then never dream on infamy, but go.
	If Proteus like your journey when you come,
	No matter who's displeas'd when you are gone.
	I fear me, he will scarce be pleas'd withal.
</LUCETTA>

<JULIA>	<46%>
	That is the least, Lucetta, of my fear:
	A thousand oaths, an ocean of his tears,
	And instances of infinite of love
	Warrant me welcome to my Proteus.
</JULIA>

<LUCETTA>	<46%>
	All these are servants to deceitful men.
</LUCETTA>

<JULIA>	<46%>
	Base men, that use them to so base effect;
	But truer stars did govern Proteus' birth:
	His words are bonds, his oaths are oracles,
	His love sincere, his thoughts immaculate,
	His tears pure messengers sent from his heart,
	His heart as far from fraud as heaven from earth.
</JULIA>

<LUCETTA>	<46%>
	Pray heaven he prove so when you come to him!
</LUCETTA>

<JULIA>	<46%>
	Now, as thou lov'st me, do him not that wrong
	To bear a hard opinion of his truth:
	Only deserve my love by loving him,
	And presently go with me to my chamber,
	To take a note of what I stand in need of
	To furnish me upon my longing journey.
	All that is mine I leave at thy dispose,
	My goods, my lands, my reputation;
	Only, in lieu thereof, dispatch me hence.
	Come, answer not, but to it presently!
	I am impatient of my tarriance.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</JULIA>

</SCENE 7>

</ACT 2>

<ACT 3>


<SCENE 1>
<Milan. An anteroom in the Duke's Palace.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Duke, Thurio, and Proteus.>
</STAGE DIR>
<DUKE>	<47%>
	Sir Thurio, give us leave, I pray, awhile;
	We have some secrets to confer about.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit Thurio.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Now tell me, Proteus, what's your will with me?
</DUKE>

<PROTEUS>	<47%>
	My gracious lord, that which I would discover
	The law of friendship bids me to conceal;
	But when I call to mind your gracious favours
	Done to me, undeserving as I am,
	My duty pricks me on to utter that
	Which else no worldly good should draw from me.
	Know, worthy prince, Sir Valentine, my friend,
	This night intends to steal away your daughter:
	Myself am one made privy to the plot.
	I know you have determin'd to bestow her
	On Thurio, whom your gentle daughter hates;
	And should she thus be stol'n away from you
	It would be much vexation to your age.
	Thus, for my duty's sake, I rather chose
	To cross my friend in his intended drift,
	Than, by concealing it, heap on your head
	A pack of sorrows which would press you down,
	Being unprevented, to your timeless grave.
</PROTEUS>

<DUKE>	<48%>
	Proteus, I thank thee for thine honest care,
	Which to requite, command me while I live.
	This love of theirs myself have often seen,
	Haply, when they have judg'd me fast asleep,
	And oftentimes have purpos'd to forbid
	Sir Valentine her company and my court;
	But fearing lest my jealous aim might err
	And so unworthily disgrace the man,—
	A rashness that I ever yet have shunn'd,—
	I gave him gentle looks, thereby to find
	That which thyself hast now disclos'd to me.
	And, that thou mayst perceive my fear of this,
	Knowing that tender youth is soon suggested,
	I nightly lodge her in an upper tower,
	The key whereof myself have ever kept;
	And thence she cannot be convey'd away.
</DUKE>

<PROTEUS>	<48%>
	Know, noble lord, they have devis'd a mean
	How he her chamber-window will ascend
	And with a corded ladder fetch her down;
	For which the youthful lover now is gone
	And this way comes he with it presently;
	Where, if it please you, you may intercept him.
	But, good my lord, do it so cunningly
	That my discovery be not aimed at;
	For love of you, not hate unto my friend,
	Hath made me publisher of this pretence.
</PROTEUS>

<DUKE>	<49%>
	Upon mine honour, he shall never know
	That I had any light from thee of this.
</DUKE>

<PROTEUS>	<49%>
	Adieu, my lord: Sir Valentine is coming.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

</PROTEUS>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Valentine.>
</STAGE DIR>
<DUKE>	<49%>
	Sir Valentine, whither away so fast?
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<49%>
	Please it your Grace, there is a messenger
	That stays to bear my letters to my friends,
	And I am going to deliver them.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<49%>
	Be they of much import?
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<49%>
	The tenour of them doth but signify
	My health and happy being at your court.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<49%>
	Nay then, no matter: stay with me awhile;
	I am to break with thee of some affairs
	That touch me near, wherein thou must be secret.
	'Tis not unknown to thee that I have sought
	To match my friend Sir Thurio to my daughter.
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<49%>
	I know it well, my lord; and sure, the match
	Were rich and honourable; besides, the gentleman
	Is full of virtue, bounty, worth, and qualities
	Beseeming such a wife as your fair daughter.
	Cannot your Grace win her to fancy him?
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<50%>
	No, trust me: she is peevish, sullen, froward,
	Proud, disobedient, stubborn, lacking duty;
	Neither regarding that she is my child,
	Nor fearing me as if I were her father:
	And, may I say to thee this pride of hers,
	Upon advice, hath drawn my love from her;
	And, where I thought the remnant of mine age
	Should have been cherish'd by her child-like duty,
	I now am full resolv'd to take a wife
	And turn her out to who will take her in:
	Then let her beauty be her wedding-dower;
	For me and my possessions she esteems not.
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<50%>
	What would your Grace have me to do in this?
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<50%>
	There is a lady of Verona here,
	Whom I affect; but she is nice and coy
	And nought esteems my aged eloquence:
	Now therefore, would I have thee to my tutor,
	For long agone I have forgot to court;
	Besides, the fashion of the time is chang'd,
	How and which way I may bestow myself
	To be regarded in her sun-bright eye.
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<50%>
	Win her with gifts, if she respect not words:
	Dumb jewels often in their silent kind
	More than quick words do move a woman's mind.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<51%>
	But she did scorn a present that I sent her.
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<51%>
	A woman sometime scorns what best contents her.
	Send her another; never give her o'er,
	For scorn at first makes after-love the more.
	If she do frown, 'tis not in hate of you,
	But rather to beget more love in you;
	If she do chide, 'tis not to have you gone;
	For why the fools are mad if left alone.
	Take no repulse, whatever she doth say;
	For, 'get you gone,' she doth not mean, 'away!'
	Flatter and praise, commend, extol their graces;
	Though ne'er so black, say they have angels' faces.
	That man that hath a tongue, I say, is no man,
	If with his tongue he cannot win a woman.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<51%>
	But she I mean is promis'd by her friends
	Unto a youthful gentleman of worth,
	And kept severely from resort of men,
	That no man hath access by day to her.
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<51%>
	Why then, I would resort to her by night.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<51%>
	Ay, but the doors be lock'd and keys kept safe,
	That no man hath recourse to her by night.
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<51%>
	What lets but one may enter at her window?
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<52%>
	Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground,
	And built so shelving that one cannot climb it
	Without apparent hazard of his life.
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<52%>
	Why then, a ladder quaintly made of cords,
	To cast up, with a pair of anchoring hooks,
	Would serve to scale another Hero's tower,
	So bold Leander would adventure it.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<52%>
	Now, as thou art a gentleman of blood,
	Advise me where I may have such a ladder.
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<52%>
	When would you use it? pray, sir, tell me that.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<52%>
	This very night; for Love is like a child,
	That longs for every thing that he can come by.
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<52%>
	By seven o'clock I'll get you such a ladder.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<52%>
	But hark thee; I will go to her alone:
	How shall I best convey the ladder thither?
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<52%>
	It will be light, my lord, that you may bear it
	Under a cloak that is of any length.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<52%>
	A cloak as long as thine will serve the turn?
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<52%>
	Ay, my good lord.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<52%>
	Then let me see thy cloak:
	I'll get me one of such another length.
</DUKE>

<VALENTINE>	<52%>
	Why, any cloak will serve the turn, my lord.
</VALENTINE>

<DUKE>	<53%>
	How shall I fashion me to wear a cloak?
	I pray thee, let me feel thy cloak upon me.
<STAGE DIR>
<Pulls open Valentine's cloak.>
</STAGE DIR>
	What letter is this same? What's here?—To Silvia!
	And here an engine fit for my proceeding!
	I'll be so bold to break the seal for once.

	My thoughts do harbour with my Silvia nightly;
	And slaves they are to me that send them flying
	O! could their master come and go as lightly,
	Himself would lodge where senseless they are lying!
	My herald thoughts in thy pure bosom rest them;
	While I, their king, that thither them importune,
	Do curse the grace that with such grace hath bless'd them,
	Because myself do want my servants' fortune:
	I curse myself, for they are sent by me,
	That they should harbour where their lord would be.

	What's here?

	Silvia, this night I will enfranchise thee

	'Tis so; and here's the ladder for the purpose.
	Why, Phaethon,—for thou art Merops' son,—
	Wilt thou aspire to guide the heavenly car
	And with thy daring folly burn the world?
	Wilt thou reach stars, because they shine on thee?
	Go, basc intruder! overweening slave!
	Bestow thy fawning smiles on equal mates,
	And think my patience, more than thy desert,
	Is privilege for thy departure hence.
	Thank me for this more than for all the favours
	Which all too much I have bestow'd on thee.
	But if thou linger in my territories
	Longer than swiftest expedition
	Will give thee time to leave our royal court,
	By heaven! my wrath shall far exceed the love
	I ever borc my daughter or thyself.
	Be gone! I will not hear thy vain excuse;
	But, as thou lov'st thy life, make speed from hence.
</DUKE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

<VALENTINE>	<54%>
	And why not death rather than living torment?
	To die is to be banish'd from myself;
	And Silvia is myself: banish'd from her
	Is self from self,—a deadly banishment!
	What light is light, if Silvia be not seen?
	What joy is joy, if Silvia be not by?
	Unless it be to think that she is by
	And feed upon the shadow of perfection.
	Except I be by Silvia in the night,
	There is no music in the nightingale;
	Unless I look on Silvia in the day,
	There is no day for me to look upon.
	She is my essence; and I leave to be,
	If I be not by her fair influence
	Foster'd, illumin'd, cherish'd, kept alive.
	I fly not death, to fly his deadly doom:
	Tarry I here, I but attend on death;
	But, fly I hence, I fly away from life.

</VALENTINE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Proteus and Launce.>
</STAGE DIR>
<PROTEUS>	<55%>
	Run, boy; run, run, and seek him out.
</PROTEUS>

<LAUNCE>	<55%>
	Soho! soho!
</LAUNCE>

<PROTEUS>	<55%>
	What seest thou?
</PROTEUS>

<LAUNCE>	<55%>
	Him we go to find: there's not a hair on's head but 'tis a Valentine.
</LAUNCE>

<PROTEUS>	<55%>
	Valentine?
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<55%>
	No.
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<55%>
	Who then? his spirit?
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<55%>
	Neither.
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<55%>
	What then?
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<55%>
	Nothing.
</VALENTINE>

<LAUNCE>	<55%>
	Can nothing speak? Master, shall I strike?
</LAUNCE>

<PROTEUS>	<55%>
	Who would'st thou strike?
</PROTEUS>

<LAUNCE>	<55%>
	Nothing.
</LAUNCE>

<PROTEUS>	<55%>
	Villain, forbear.
</PROTEUS>

<LAUNCE>	<55%>
	Why, sir, I'll strike nothing: I pray you,—
</LAUNCE>

<PROTEUS>	<55%>
	Sirrah, I say, forbear.—Friend Valentine, a word.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<55%>
	My ears are stopp'd and cannot hear good news,
	So much of bad already hath possess'd them.
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<55%>
	Then in dumb silence will I bury mine,
	For they are harsh, untuneable and bad.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<56%>
	Is Silvia dead?
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<56%>
	No, Valentine.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<56%>
	No Valentine, indeed, for sacred Silvia!
	Hath she forsworn me?
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<56%>
	No, Valentine.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<56%>
	No Valentine, if Silvia have forsworn me!
	What is your news?
</VALENTINE>

<LAUNCE>	<56%>
	Sir, there is a proclamation that you are vanished.
</LAUNCE>

<PROTEUS>	<56%>
	That thou art banished, O, that's the news,
	From hence, from Silvia, and from me thy friend.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<56%>
	O, I have fed upon this woe already,
	And now excess of it will make me surfeit.
	Doth Silvia know that I am banished?
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<56%>
	Ay, ay; and she hath offer'd to the doom—
	Which, unrevers'd, stands in effectual force—
	A sea of melting pearl, which some call tears:
	Those at her father's churlish feet she tender'd;
	With them, upon her knees, her humble self;
	Wringing her hands, whose whiteness so became them
	As if but now they waxed pale for woe:
	But neither bended knees, pure hands held up,
	Sad sighs, deep groans, nor silver-shedding tears,
	Could penetrate her uncompassionate sire;
	But Valentine, if he be ta'en, must die.
	Besides, her intercession chaf'd him so,
	When she for thy repeal was suppliant,
	That to close prison he commanded her,
	With many bitter threats of biding there.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<57%>
	No more; unless the next word that thou speak'st
	Have some malignant power upon my life:
	If so, I pray thee, breathe it in mine ear,
	As ending anthem of my endless dolour.
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<57%>
	Cease to lament for that thou canst not help,
	And study help for that which thou lament'st.
	Time is the nurse and breeder of all good.
	Here if thou stay, thou canst not see thy love;
	Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life.
	Hope is a lover's staff; walk hence with that
	And manage it against despairing thoughts.
	Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence;
	Which, being writ to me, shall be deliver'd
	Even in the milk-white bosom of thy love.
	The time now serves not to expostulate:
	Come, I'll convey thee through the city-gate,
	And, ere I part with thee, confer at large
	Of all that may concern thy love-affairs.
	As thou lov'st Silvia, though not for thyself,
	Regard thy danger, and along with me!
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<58%>
	I pray thee, Launce, and if thou seest my boy,
	Bid him make haste and meet me at the North-gate.
</VALENTINE>

<PROTEUS>	<58%>
	Go, sirrah, find him out. Come, Valentine.
</PROTEUS>

<VALENTINE>	<58%>
	O my dear Silvia! hapless Valentine!
</VALENTINE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Valentine and Proteus.>
</STAGE DIR>

<LAUNCE>	<58%>
	I am but a fool, look you; and yet I have the wit to think my master is a kind of a knave: but that's all one, if he be but one knave. He lives not now that knows me to be in love: yet I am in love; but a team of horse shall not pluck that from me, nor who 'tis I love; and yet 'tis a woman; but what woman, I will not tell myself; and yet 'tis a milkmaid; yet 'tis not a maid, for she hath had gossips; yet 'tis a maid, for she is her master's maid, and serves for wages. She hath more qualities than a water-spaniel,—which is much in a bare Christian. <STAGE DIR>
<Pulling out a paper.>
</STAGE DIR> Here is the catelog of her condition. Imprimis, She can fetch and carry. Why, a horse can do no more: nay, a horse cannot fetch, but only carry; therefore, is she better than a jade. Item, She can milk; look you, a sweet virtue in a maid with clean hands.

</LAUNCE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Speed.>
</STAGE DIR>
<SPEED>	<59%>
	How now, Signior Launce! what news with your mastership?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<59%>
	With my master's ship? why, it is at sea.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<59%>
	Well, your old vice still; mistake the word. What news, then, in your paper?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<59%>
	The blackest news that ever thou heardest.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<59%>
	Why, man, how black?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<59%>
	Why, as black as ink.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<59%>
	Let me read them.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<59%>
	Fie on thee, jolthead! thou canst not read.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<59%>
	Thou liest; I can.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<59%>
	I will try thee. Tell me this: who begot thee?
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<59%>
	Marry, the son of my grandfather.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<59%>
	O, illiterate loiterer! it was the son of thy grandmother. This proves that thou canst not read.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<59%>
	Come, fool, come: try me in thy paper.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<59%>
	There; and Saint Nicholas be thy speed!
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<59%>
	Imprimis, She can milk.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<59%>
	Ay, that she can.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<59%>
	Item, She brews good ale.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<59%>
	And thereof comes the proverb, 'Blessing of your heart, you brew good ale.'
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<60%>
	Item, She can sew.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<60%>
	That's as much as to say, Can she so?
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<60%>
	Item, She can knit.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<60%>
	What need a man care for a stock with a wench, when she can knit him a stock?
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<60%>
	Item, She can wash and scour.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<60%>
	A special virtue; for then she need not be washed and scoured.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<60%>
	Item, She can spin.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<60%>
	Then may I set the world on wheels, when she can spin for her living.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<60%>
	Item, She hath many nameless virtues.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<60%>
	That's as much as to say, bastard virtues; that, indeed, know not their fathers, and therefore have no names.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<60%>
	Here follow her vices.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<60%>
	Close at the heels of her virtues.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<60%>
	Item, She is not to be kissed fasting, in respect of her breath.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<60%>
	Well, that fault may be mended with a breakfast. Read on.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<60%>
	Item, She hath a sweet mouth.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<60%>
	That makes amends for her sour breath.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<60%>
	Item, She doth talk in her sleep.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<60%>
	It's no matter for that, so she sleep not in her talk.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<61%>
	Item, She is slow in words.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<61%>
	O villain, that set this down among her vices! To be slow in words is a woman's only virtue: I pray thee, out with't, and place it for her chief virtue.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<61%>
	Item, She is proud.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<61%>
	Out with that too: it was Eve's legacy, and cannot be ta'en from her.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<61%>
	Item, She hath no teeth.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<61%>
	I care not for that neither, because I love crusts.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<61%>
	Item, She is curst.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<61%>
	Well; the best is, she hath no teeth to bite.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<61%>
	Item, She will often praise her liquor.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<61%>
	If her liquor be good, she shall: if she will not, I will; for good things should be praised.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<61%>
	Item, She is too liberal.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<61%>
	Of her tongue she cannot, for that's writ down she is slow of: of her purse she shall not, for that I'll keep shut: now, of another thing she may, and that cannot I help. Well, proceed.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<61%>
	Item, She hath more hair than wit, and more faults than hairs, and more wealth than faults.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<62%>
	Stop there; I'll have her: she was mine, and not mine, twice or thrice in that last article. Rehearse that once more.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<62%>
	Item, She hath more hair than wit.—
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<62%>
	More hair than wit it may be; I'll prove it: the cover of the salt hides the salt, and therefore it is more than the salt; the hair, that covers the wit is more than the wit, for the greater hides the less. What's next?
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<62%>
	And more faults than hairs.—
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<62%>
	That's monstrous! O, that that were out!
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<62%>
	And more wealth than faults.
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<62%>
	Why, that word makes the faults gracious. Well, I'll have her; and if it be a match, as nothing is impossible,—
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<62%>
	What then?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<62%>
	Why, then will I tell thee,—that thy master stays for thee at the North-gate.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<62%>
	For me?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<62%>
	For thee! ay; who art thou? he hath stayed for a better man than thee.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<62%>
	And must I go to him?
</SPEED>

<LAUNCE>	<62%>
	Thou must run to him, for thou hast stayed so long that going will scarce serve the turn.
</LAUNCE>

<SPEED>	<62%>
	Why didst not tell me sooner? pox of your love-letters!
</SPEED>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

<LAUNCE>	<63%>
	Now will he be swing'd for reading my letter. An unmannerly slave, that will thrust himself into secrets. I'll after, to rejoice in the boy's correction.
</LAUNCE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 1>


<SCENE 2>
<The Same. A Room in the Duke's Palace.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Duke and Thurio.>
</STAGE DIR>
<DUKE>	<63%>
	Sir Thurio, fear not but that she will love you,
	Now Valentine is banish'd from her sight.
</DUKE>

<THURIO>	<63%>
	Since his exile she hath despis'd me most,
	Forsworn my company and rail'd at me,
	That I am desperate of obtaining her.
</THURIO>

<DUKE>	<63%>
	This weak impress of love is as a figure
	Trenched in ice, which with an hour's heat
	Dissolves to water and doth lose his form.
	A little time will melt her frozen thoughts,
	And worthless Valentine shall be forgot.

<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Proteus.>
</STAGE DIR>
	How now, Sir Proteus! Is your countryman
</DUKE>
	According to our proclamation gone?
<PROTEUS>	<63%>
	Gone, my good lord.
</PROTEUS>

<DUKE>	<63%>
	My daughter takes his going grievously.
</DUKE>

<PROTEUS>	<63%>
	A little time, my lord, will kill that grief.
</PROTEUS>

<DUKE>	<64%>
	So I believe; but Thurio thinks not so.
	Proteus, the good conceit I hold of thee,—
	For thou hast shown some sign of good desert,—
	Makes me the better to confer with thee.
</DUKE>

<PROTEUS>	<64%>
	Longer than I prove loyal to your Grace
	Let me not live to look upon your Grace.
</PROTEUS>

<DUKE>	<64%>
	Thou know'st how willingly I would effect
	The match between Sir Thurio and my daughter.
</DUKE>

<PROTEUS>	<64%>
	I do, my lord.
</PROTEUS>

<DUKE>	<64%>
	And also, I think, thou art not ignorant
	How she opposes her against my will.
</DUKE>

<PROTEUS>	<64%>
	She did, my lord, when Valentine was here.
</PROTEUS>

<DUKE>	<64%>
	Ay, and perversely she persevers so.
	What might we do to make the girl forget
	The love of Valentine, and love Sir Thurio?
</DUKE>

<PROTEUS>	<64%>
	The best way is to slander Valentine
	With falsehood, cowardice, and poor descent,
	Three things that women highly hold in hate.
</PROTEUS>

<DUKE>	<64%>
	Ay, but she'll think that it is spoke in hate.
</DUKE>

<PROTEUS>	<64%>
	Ay, if his enemy deliver it:
	Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken
	By one whom she esteemeth as his friend.
</PROTEUS>

<DUKE>	<64%>
	Then you must undertake to slander him.
</DUKE>

<PROTEUS>	<65%>
	And that, my lord, I shall be loath to do:
	'Tis an ill office for a gentleman,
	Especially against his very friend.
</PROTEUS>

<DUKE>	<65%>
	Where your good word cannot advantage him,
	Your slander never can endamage him:
	Therefore the office is indifferent,
	Being entreated to it by your friend.
</DUKE>

<PROTEUS>	<65%>
	You have prevail'd, my lord. If I can do it,
	By aught that I can speak in his dispraise,
	She shall not long continue love to him.
	But say this weed her love from Valentine,
	It follows not that she will love Sir Thurio.
</PROTEUS>

<THURIO>	<65%>
	Therefore, as you unwind her love from him,
	Lest it should ravel and be good to none,
	You must provide to bottom it on me;
	Which must be done by praising me as much
	As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine.
</THURIO>

<DUKE>	<65%>
	And, Proteus, we dare trust you in this kind,
	Because we know, on Valentine's report,
	You are already Love's firm votary
	And cannot soon revolt and change your mind.
	Upon this warrant shall you have access
	Where you with Silvia may confer at large;
	For she is lumpish, heavy, melancholy,
	And, for your friend's sake, will be glad of you;
	Where you may temper her, by your persuasion
	To hate young Valentine and love my friend.
</DUKE>

<PROTEUS>	<66%>
	As much as I can do I will effect.
	But you, Sir Thurio, are not sharp enough;
	You must lay lime to tangle her desires
	By wailful sonnets, whose composed rimes
	Should be full-fraught with serviceable vows.
</PROTEUS>

<DUKE>	<66%>
	Ay,
	Much is the force of heaven-bred poesy.
</DUKE>

<PROTEUS>	<66%>
	Say that upon the altar of her beauty
	You sacrifice your tears, your sighs, your heart.
	Write till your ink be dry, and with your tears
	Moist it again, and frame some feeling line
	That may discover such integrity:
	For Orpheus' lute was strung with poets' sinews,
	Whose golden touch could soften steel and stones,
	Make tigers tame and huge leviathans
	Forsake unsounded deeps to dance on sands.
	After your dire-lamenting elegies,
	Visit by night your lady's chamber-window
	With some sweet consort: to their instruments
	Tune a deploring dump; the night's dead silence
	Will well become such sweet-complaining grievance.
	This, or else nothing, will inherit her.
</PROTEUS>

<DUKE>	<67%>
	This discipline shows thou hast been in love.
</DUKE>

<THURIO>	<67%>
	And thy advice this night I'll put in practice.
	Therefore, sweet Proteus, my direction-giver,
	Let us into the city presently
	To sort some gentlemen well skill'd in music.
	I have a sonnet that will serve the turn
	To give the onset to thy good advice.
</THURIO>

<DUKE>	<67%>
	About it, gentlemen!
</DUKE>

<PROTEUS>	<67%>
	We'll wait upon your grace till aftersupper,
	And afterward determine our proceedings.
</PROTEUS>

<DUKE>	<67%>
	Even now about it! I will pardon you.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</DUKE>

</SCENE 2>

</ACT 3>

<ACT 4>


<SCENE 1>
<A Forest between Milan and Verona.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter certain Outlaws.>
</STAGE DIR>
<OUTLAW 1>	<67%>
	Fellows, stand fast; I see a passenger.
</OUTLAW 1>

<OUTLAW 2>	<67%>
	If there be ten, shrink not, but down with 'em.

</OUTLAW 2>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Valentine and Speed.>
</STAGE DIR>
<OUTLAW 3>	<67%>
	Stand, sir, and throw us that you have about ye;
	If not, we'll make you sit and rifle you.
</OUTLAW 3>

<SPEED>	<67%>
	Sir, we are undone: these are the villains
	That all the travellers do fear so much.
</SPEED>

<VALENTINE>	<68%>
	My friends,—
</VALENTINE>

<OUTLAW 1>	<68%>
	That's not so, sir; we are your enemies.
</OUTLAW 1>

<OUTLAW 2>	<68%>
	Peace! we'll hear him.
</OUTLAW 2>

<OUTLAW 3>	<68%>
	Ay, by my beard, will we, for he is a proper man.
</OUTLAW 3>

<VALENTINE>	<68%>
	Then know, that I have little wealth to lose.
	A man I am cross'd with adversity:
	My riches are these poor habiliments,
	Of which if you should here disfurnish me,
	You take the sum and substance that I have.
</VALENTINE>

<OUTLAW 2>	<68%>
	Whither travel you?
</OUTLAW 2>

<VALENTINE>	<68%>
	To Verona.
</VALENTINE>

<OUTLAW 1>	<68%>
	Whence came you?
</OUTLAW 1>

<VALENTINE>	<68%>
	From Milan.
</VALENTINE>

<OUTLAW 3>	<68%>
	Have you long sojourn'd there?
</OUTLAW 3>

<VALENTINE>	<68%>
	Some sixteen months; and longer might have stay'd
	If crooked fortune had not thwarted me.
</VALENTINE>

<OUTLAW 2>	<68%>
	What! were you banish'd thence?
</OUTLAW 2>

<VALENTINE>	<68%>
	I was.
</VALENTINE>

<OUTLAW 2>	<68%>
	For what offence?
</OUTLAW 2>

<VALENTINE>	<68%>
	For that which now torments me to rehearse.
	I kill'd a man, whose death I much repent;
	But yet I slew him manfully, in fight,
	Without false vantage or base treachery.
</VALENTINE>

<OUTLAW 1>	<68%>
	Why, ne'er repent it, if it were done so.
	But were you banish'd for so small a fault?
</OUTLAW 1>

<VALENTINE>	<69%>
	I was, and held me glad of such a doom.
</VALENTINE>

<OUTLAW 2>	<69%>
	Have you the tongues?
</OUTLAW 2>

<VALENTINE>	<69%>
	My youthful travel therein made me happy,
	Or else I often had been miserable.
</VALENTINE>

<OUTLAW 3>	<69%>
	By the bare scalp of Robin Hood's fat friar,
	This fellow were a king for our wild faction!
</OUTLAW 3>

<OUTLAW 1>	<69%>
	We'll have him: Sirs, a word.
</OUTLAW 1>

<SPEED>	<69%>
	Master, be one of them;
	It is an honourable kind of thievery.
</SPEED>

<VALENTINE>	<69%>
	Peace, villain!
</VALENTINE>

<OUTLAW 2>	<69%>
	Tell us this: have you anything to take to?
</OUTLAW 2>

<VALENTINE>	<69%>
	Nothing, but my fortune.
</VALENTINE>

<OUTLAW 3>	<69%>
	Know then, that some of us are gentlemen,
	Such as the fury of ungovern'd youth
	Thrust from the company of awful men:
	Myself was from Verona banished
	For practising to steal away a lady,
	An heir, and near allied unto the duke.
</OUTLAW 3>

<OUTLAW 2>	<69%>
	And I from Mantua, for a gentleman,
	Who, in my mood, I stabb'd unto the heart.
</OUTLAW 2>

<OUTLAW 1>	<69%>
	And I for such like petty crimes as these.
	But to the purpose; for we cite our faults,
	That they may hold excus'd our lawless lives;
	And, partly, seeing you are beautified
	With goodly shape, and by your own report
	A linguist, and a man of such perfection
	As we do in our quality much want—
</OUTLAW 1>

<OUTLAW 2>	<70%>
	Indeed, because you are a banish'd man,
	Therefore, above the rest, we parley to you.
	Are you content to be our general?
	To make a virtue of necessity
	And live, as we do, in this wilderness?
</OUTLAW 2>

<OUTLAW 3>	<70%>
	What say'st thou? wilt thou be of our consort?
	Say 'ay,' and be the captain of us all:
	We'll do thee homage and be rul'd by thee,
	Love thee as our commander and our king.
</OUTLAW 3>

<OUTLAW 1>	<70%>
	But if thou scorn our courtesy, thou diest.
</OUTLAW 1>

<OUTLAW 2>	<70%>
	Thou shalt not live to brag what we have offer'd.
</OUTLAW 2>

<VALENTINE>	<70%>
	I take your offer and will live with you,
	Provided that you do no outrages
	On silly women, or poor passengers.
</VALENTINE>

<OUTLAW 3>	<70%>
	No; we detest such vile, base practices.
	Come, go with us; we'll bring thee to our crews,
	And show thee all the treasure we have got,
	Which, with ourselves, all rest at thy dispose.
</OUTLAW 3>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 1>


<SCENE 2>
<Milan. The Court of the Duke's Palace.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Proteus.>
</STAGE DIR>
<PROTEUS>	<71%>
	Already have I been false to Valentine,
	And now I must be as unjust to Thurio.
	Under the colour of commending him,
	I have access my own love to prefer:
	But Silvia is too fair, too true, too holy,
	To be corrupted with my worthless gifts.
	When I protest true loyalty to her,
	She twits me with my falsehood to my friend;
	When to her beauty I commend my vows,
	She bids me think how I have been forsworn
	In breaking faith with Julia whom I lov'd:
	And notwithstanding all her sudden quips,
	The least whereof would quell a lover's hope,
	Yet, spaniel-like, the more she spurns my love,
	The more it grows, and fawneth on her still.
	But here comes Thurio: now must we to her window,
	And give some evening music to her ear.

</PROTEUS>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Thurio, and Musicians.>
</STAGE DIR>
<THURIO>	<71%>
	How now, Sir Proteus! are you crept before us?
</THURIO>

<PROTEUS>	<71%>
	Ay, gentle Thurio; for you know that love
	Will creep in service where it cannot go.
</PROTEUS>

<THURIO>	<71%>
	Ay; but I hope, sir, that you love not here.
</THURIO>

<PROTEUS>	<72%>
	Sir, but I do; or else I would be hence.
</PROTEUS>

<THURIO>	<72%>
	Who? Silvia?
</THURIO>

<PROTEUS>	<72%>
	Ay, Silvia, for your sake.
</PROTEUS>

<THURIO>	<72%>
	I thank you for your own. Now, gentlemen,
	Let's tune, and to it lustily a while.

</THURIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Host and Julia behind. Julia in boy's clothes.>
</STAGE DIR>
<HOST>	<72%>
	Now, my young guest, methinks you're allycholly: I pray you, why is it?
</HOST>

<JULIA>	<72%>
	Marry, mine host, because I cannot be merry.
</JULIA>

<HOST>	<72%>
	Come, we'll have you merry. I'll bring you where you shall hear music and see the gentleman that you asked for.
</HOST>

<JULIA>	<72%>
	But shall I hear him speak?
</JULIA>

<HOST>	<72%>
	Ay, that you shall.
</HOST>

<JULIA>	<72%>
	That will be music.
</JULIA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Music plays.>
</STAGE DIR>

<HOST>	<72%>
	Hark! hark!
</HOST>

<JULIA>	<72%>
	Is he among these?
</JULIA>

<HOST>	<72%>
	Ay; but peace! let's hear 'em.

<SONG.>
	Who is Silvia? what is she?
	That all our swains commend her?
	Holy, fair, and wise is she;
	The heaven such grace did lend her,
	That she might admired be.
	Is she kind as she is fair?
	For beauty lives with kindness:
	Love doth to her eyes repair,
	To help him of his blindness;
	And, being help'd, inhabits there.
	Then to Silvia let us sing,
	That Silvia is excelling;
	She excels each mortal thing
	Upon the dull earth dwelling;
	To her let us garlands bring.
</HOST>

<HOST>	<73%>
	How now! are you sadder than you were before? How do you, man? the music likes you not.
</HOST>

<JULIA>	<73%>
	You mistake; the musician likes me not.
</JULIA>

<HOST>	<73%>
	Why, my pretty youth?
</HOST>

<JULIA>	<73%>
	He plays false, father.
</JULIA>

<HOST>	<73%>
	How? out of tune on the strings?
</HOST>

<JULIA>	<73%>
	Not so; but yet so false that he grieves my very heart-strings.
</JULIA>

<HOST>	<73%>
	You have a quick ear.
</HOST>

<JULIA>	<73%>
	Ay; I would I were deaf; it makes me have a slow heart.
</JULIA>

<HOST>	<73%>
	I perceive you delight not in music.
</HOST>

<JULIA>	<73%>
	Not a whit,—when it jars so.
</JULIA>

<HOST>	<73%>
	Hark! what fine change is in the music!
</HOST>

<JULIA>	<73%>
	Ay, that change is the spite.
</JULIA>

<HOST>	<73%>
	You would have them always play but one thing?
</HOST>

<JULIA>	<73%>
	I would always have one play but one thing.
	But, host, doth this Sir Proteus that we talk on
	Often resort unto this gentlewoman?
</JULIA>

<HOST>	<73%>
	I will tell you what Launce, his man, told me: he lov'd her out of all nick.
</HOST>

<JULIA>	<74%>
	Where is Launce?
</JULIA>

<HOST>	<74%>
	Gone to seek his dog; which, to-morrow, by his master's command, he must carry for a present to his lady.
</HOST>

<JULIA>	<74%>
	Peace! stand aside: the company parts.
</JULIA>

<PROTEUS>	<74%>
	Sir Thurio, fear not you: I will so plead
	That you shall say my cunning drift excels.
</PROTEUS>

<THURIO>	<74%>
	Where meet we?
</THURIO>

<PROTEUS>	<74%>
	At Saint Gregory's well.
</PROTEUS>

<THURIO>	<74%>
	Farewell.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Thurio and Musicians.>
</STAGE DIR>

</THURIO>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Silvia above, at her window.>
</STAGE DIR>
<PROTEUS>	<74%>
	Madam, good even to your ladyship.
</PROTEUS>

<SILVIA>	<74%>
	I thank you for your music, gentlemen.
	Who is that that spake?
</SILVIA>

<PROTEUS>	<74%>
	One, lady, if you knew his pure heart's truth,
	You would quickly learn to know him by his voice.
</PROTEUS>

<SILVIA>	<74%>
	Sir Proteus, as I take it.
</SILVIA>

<PROTEUS>	<74%>
	Sir Proteus, gentle lady, and your servant.
</PROTEUS>

<SILVIA>	<74%>
	What is your will?
</SILVIA>

<PROTEUS>	<74%>
	That I may compass yours.
</PROTEUS>

<SILVIA>	<74%>
	You have your wish; my will is even this:
	That presently you hie you home to bed.
	Thou subtle, perjur'd, false, disloyal man!
	Think'st thou I am so shallow, so conceitless,
	To be seduced by thy flattery,
	That hast deceiv'd so many with thy vows?
	Return, return, and make thy love amends.
	For me, by this pale queen of night I swear,
	I am so far from granting thy request
	That I despise thee for thy wrongful suit,
	And by and by intend to chide myself
	Even for this time I spend in talking to thee.
</SILVIA>

<PROTEUS>	<75%>
	I grant, sweet love, that I did love a lady;
	But she is dead.
</PROTEUS>

<JULIA>	<75%>
<STAGE DIR>
<Aside.>
</STAGE DIR> 'Tware false, if I should speak it;
	For I am sure she is not buried.
</JULIA>

<SILVIA>	<75%>
	Say that she be; yet Valentine thy friend
	Survives; to whom, thyself art witness
	I am betroth'd: and art thou not asham'd
	To wrong him with thy importunacy?
</SILVIA>

<PROTEUS>	<75%>
	I likewise hear that Valentine is dead.
</PROTEUS>

<SILVIA>	<75%>
	And so suppose am I; for in his grave, Assure thyself my love is buried.
</SILVIA>

<PROTEUS>	<75%>
	Sweet lady, let me rake it from the earth.
</PROTEUS>

<SILVIA>	<75%>
	Go to thy lady's grave and call hers thence;
	Or, at the least, in hers sepulchre thine.
</SILVIA>

<JULIA>	<75%>
<STAGE DIR>
<Aside.>
</STAGE DIR> He heard not that.
</JULIA>

<PROTEUS>	<76%>
	Madam, if your heart be so obdurate,
	Vouchsafe me yet your picture for my love,
	The picture that is hanging in your chamber:
	To that I'll speak, to that I'll sigh and weep;
	For since the substance of your perfect self
	Is else devoted, I am but a shadow,
	And to your shadow will I make true love.
</PROTEUS>

<JULIA>	<76%>
<STAGE DIR>
<Aside.>
</STAGE DIR> If 'twere a substance, you would, sure, deceive it,
	And make it but a shadow, as I am.
</JULIA>

<SILVIA>	<76%>
	I am very loath to be your idol, sir;
	But, since your falsehood shall become you well
	To worship shadows and adore false shapes,
	Send to me in the morning and I'll send it.
	And so, good rest.
</SILVIA>

<PROTEUS>	<76%>
	As wretches have o'er night
	That wait for execution in the morn.
</PROTEUS>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt Proteus, and Silvia, above.>
</STAGE DIR>

<JULIA>	<76%>
	Host, will you go?
</JULIA>

<HOST>	<76%>
	By my halidom, I was fast asleep.
</HOST>

<JULIA>	<76%>
	Pray you, where lies Sir Proteus?
</JULIA>

<HOST>	<76%>
	Marry, at my house. Trust me, I think 'tis almost day.
</HOST>

<JULIA>	<76%>
	Not so; but it hath been the longest night
	That e'er I watch'd and the most heaviest.
</JULIA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 2>


<SCENE 3>
<The Same.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Eglamour.>
</STAGE DIR>
<EGLAMOUR>	<77%>
	This is the hour that Madam Silvia
	Entreated me to call, and know her mind:
	There's some great matter she'd employ me in.
	Madam, Madam!

</EGLAMOUR>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Silvia above, at her window.>
</STAGE DIR>
<SILVIA>	<77%>
	Who calls?
</SILVIA>

<EGLAMOUR>	<77%>
	Your servant, and your friend;
	One that attends your ladyship's command.
</EGLAMOUR>

<SILVIA>	<77%>
	Sir Eglamour, a thousand times good morrow.
</SILVIA>

<EGLAMOUR>	<77%>
	As many, worthy lady, to yourself.
	According to your ladyship's impose,
	I am thus early come to know what service
	It is your pleasure to command me in.
</EGLAMOUR>

<SILVIA>	<77%>
	O Eglamour, thou art a gentleman—
	Think not I flatter, for I swear I do not—
	Valiant, wise, remorseful, well-accomplish'd.
	Thou art not ignorant what dear good will
	I bear unto the banish'd Valentine,
	Nor how my father would enforce me marry
	Vain Thurio, whom my very soul abhors.
	Thyself hast lov'd; and I have heard thee say
	No grief did ever come so near thy heart
	As when thy lady and thy true love died,
	Upon whose grave thou vow'dst pure chastity.
	Sir Eglamour, I would to Valentine,
	To Mantua, where, I hear he makes abode;
	And, for the ways are dangerous to pass,
	I do desire thy worthy company,
	Upon whose faith and honour I repose.
	Urge not my father's anger, Eglamour,
	But think upon my grief, a lady's grief,
	And on the justice of my flying hence,
	To keep me from a most unholy match,
	Which heaven and fortune still rewards with plagues.
	I do desire thee, even from a heart
	As full of sorrows as the sea of sands,
	To bear me company and go with me:
	If not, to hide what I have said to thee,
	That I may venture to depart alone.
</SILVIA>

<EGLAMOUR>	<78%>
	Madam, I pity much your grievances;
	Which since I know they virtuously are plac'd,
	I give consent to go along with you,
	Recking as little what betideth me
	As much I wish all good befortune you.
	When will you go?
</EGLAMOUR>

<SILVIA>	<78%>
	This evening coming.
</SILVIA>

<EGLAMOUR>	<78%>
	Where shall I meet you?
</EGLAMOUR>

<SILVIA>	<78%>
	At Friar Patrick's cell,
	Where I intend holy confession.
</SILVIA>

<EGLAMOUR>	<78%>
	I will not fail your ladyship.
	Good morrow, gentle lady.
</EGLAMOUR>

<SILVIA>	<79%>
	Good morrow, kind Sir Eglamour.
</SILVIA>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt severally.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 3>


<SCENE 4>
<The Same.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Launce with his dog.>
</STAGE DIR>
<LAUNCE>	<79%>
	When a man's servant shall play the cur with him, look you, it goes hard; one that I brought up of a puppy; one that I saved from drowning, when three or four of his blind brothers and sisters went to it. I have taught him, even as one would say precisely, 'Thus would I teach a dog.' I was sent to deliver him as a present to Mistress Silvia from my master, and I came no sooner into the dining-chamber but he steps me to her trencher and steals her capon's leg. O! 'tis a foul thing when a cur cannot keep himself in all companies. I would have, as one should say, one that takes upon him to be a dog indeed, to be, as it were, a dog at all things. If I had not had more wit than he, to take a fault upon me that he did, I think verily he had been hanged for't: sure as I live, he had suffered for't: you shall judge. He thrusts me himself into the company of three or four gentleman-like dogs under the duke's table: he had not been there—bless the mark—a pissing-while, but all the chamber smelt him. 'Out with the dog!' says one; 'What cur is that?' says another; 'Whip him out,' says the third; 'Hang him up,' says the duke. I, having been acquainted with the smell before, knew it was Crab, and goes me to the fellow that whips the dogs: 'Friend,' quoth I, 'you mean to whip the dog?' 'Ay, marry, do I,' quoth he. 'You do him the more wrong,' quoth I; ''twas I did the thing you wot of.' He makes me no more ado, but whips me out of the chamber. How many masters would do this for his servant? Nay, I'll be sworn, I have sat in the stocks for puddings he hath stolen, otherwise he had been executed; I have stood on the pillory for geese he hath killed, otherwise he had suffered for't; thou thinkest not of this now. Nay, I remember the trick you served me when I took my leave of Madam Silvia: did not I bid thee still mark me and do as I do? When didst thou see me heave up my leg and make water against a gentlewoman's farthingale? Didst thou ever see me do such a trick?

</LAUNCE>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Proteus, and Julia in boy's clothes.>
</STAGE DIR>
<PROTEUS>	<81%>
	Sebastian is thy name? I like thee well
	And will employ thee in some service presently.
</PROTEUS>

<JULIA>	<81%>
	In what you please: I will do what I can.
</JULIA>

<PROTEUS>	<81%>
	I hope thou wilt. <STAGE DIR>
<To Launce.>
</STAGE DIR> How now, you whoreson peasant!
	Where have you been these two days loitering?
</PROTEUS>

<LAUNCE>	<81%>
	Marry, sir, I carried Mistress Silvia the dog you bade me.
</LAUNCE>

<PROTEUS>	<81%>
	And what says she to my little jewel?
</PROTEUS>

<LAUNCE>	<81%>
	Marry, she says, your dog was a cur, and tells you, currish thanks is good enough for such a present.
</LAUNCE>

<PROTEUS>	<81%>
	But she received my dog?
</PROTEUS>

<LAUNCE>	<81%>
	No, indeed, did she not: here have I brought him back again.
</LAUNCE>

<PROTEUS>	<81%>
	What! didst thou offer her this from me?
</PROTEUS>

<LAUNCE>	<81%>
	Ay, sir: the other squirrel was stolen from me by the hangman boys in the marketplace; and then I offered her mine own, who is a dog as big as ten of yours, and therefore the gift the greater.
</LAUNCE>

<PROTEUS>	<81%>
	Go, get thee hence, and find my dog again,
	Or ne'er return again into my sight.
	Away, I say! Stay'st thou to vex me here?
	A slave that still an end turns me to shame.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit Launce.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Sebastian, I have entertained thee
	Partly, that I have need of such a youth,
	That can with some discretion do my business,
	For't is no trusting to yond foolish lout;
	But chiefly for thy face and thy behaviour,
	Which, if my augury deceive me not,
	Witness good bringing up, fortune, and truth:
	Therefore, know thou, for this I entertain thee.
	Go presently, and take this ring with thee.
	Deliver it to Madam Silvia:
	She lov'd me well deliver'd it to me.
</PROTEUS>

<JULIA>	<82%>
	It seems, you lov'd not her, to leave her token.
	She's dead, belike?
</JULIA>

<PROTEUS>	<82%>
	Not so: I think, she lives.
</PROTEUS>

<JULIA>	<82%>
	Alas!
</JULIA>

<PROTEUS>	<82%>
	Why dost thou cry 'alas?'
</PROTEUS>

<JULIA>	<82%>
	I cannot choose
	But pity her.
</JULIA>

<PROTEUS>	<82%>
	Wherefore should'st thou pity her?
</PROTEUS>

<JULIA>	<82%>
	Because methinks that she lov'd you as well
	As you do love your lady Silvia.
	She dreams on him that has forgot her love;
	You dote on her, that cares not for your love.
	'Tis pity, love should be so contrary;
	And thinking on it makes me cry, 'alas!'
</JULIA>

<PROTEUS>	<83%>
	Well, well, give her that ring and therewithal
	This letter: that's her chamber. Tell my lady
	I claim the promise for her heavenly picture.
	Your message done, hie home unto my chamber,
	Where thou shalt find me sad and solitary.
</PROTEUS>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

<JULIA>	<83%>
	How many women would do such a message?
	Alas, poor Proteus! thou hast entertain'd
	A fox to be the shepherd of thy lambs.
	Alas, poor fool! why do I pity him
	That with his very heart despiseth me?
	Because he loves her, he despiseth me;
	Because I love him, I must pity him.
	This ring I gave him when he parted from me,
	To bind him to remember my good will;
	And now am I—unhappy messenger—
	To plead for that which I would not obtain,
	To carry that which I would have refus'd,
	To praise his faith which I would have disprais'd.
	I am my master's true-confirmed love,
	But cannot be true servant to my master,
	Unless I prove false traitor to myself.
	Yet will I woo for him; but yet so coldly
	As heaven it knows, I would not have him speed.

<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Silvia, attended.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Gentlewoman, good day! I pray you, be my mean
</JULIA>
	To bring me where to speak with Madam Silvia.
<SILVIA>	<84%>
	What would you with her, if that I be she?
</SILVIA>

<JULIA>	<84%>
	If you be she, I do entreat your patience To hear me speak the message I am sent on.
</JULIA>

<SILVIA>	<84%>
	From whom?
</SILVIA>

<JULIA>	<84%>
	From my master, Sir Proteus, madam.
</JULIA>

<SILVIA>	<84%>
	O! he sends you for a picture?
</SILVIA>

<JULIA>	<84%>
	Ay, madam.
</JULIA>

<SILVIA>	<84%>
	Ursula, bring my picture there.
<STAGE DIR>
<A picture brought.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Go, give your master this: tell him from me,
	One Julia, that his changing thoughts forget,
	Would better fit his chamber than this shadow.
</SILVIA>

<JULIA>	<84%>
	Madam, please you peruse this letter.—
	Pardon me, madam, I have unadvis'd
	Deliver'd you a paper that I should not:
	This is the letter to your ladyship.
</JULIA>

<SILVIA>	<84%>
	I pray thee, let me look on that again.
</SILVIA>

<JULIA>	<84%>
	It may not be: good madam, pardon me.
</JULIA>

<SILVIA>	<84%>
	There, hold.
	I will not look upon your master's lines:
	I know, they are stuff'd with protestations
	And full of new-found oaths, which he will break
	As easily as I do tear his paper.
</SILVIA>

<JULIA>	<85%>
	Madam, he sends your ladyship this ring.
</JULIA>

<SILVIA>	<85%>
	The more shame for him that he sends it me;
	For, I have heard him say a thousand times,
	His Julia gave it him at his departure.
	Though his false finger have profan'd the ring,
	Mine shall not do his Julia so much wrong.
</SILVIA>

<JULIA>	<85%>
	She thanks you.
</JULIA>

<SILVIA>	<85%>
	What say'st thou?
</SILVIA>

<JULIA>	<85%>
	I thank you, madam, that you tender her.
	Poor gentlewoman! my master wrongs her much.
</JULIA>

<SILVIA>	<85%>
	Dost thou know her?
</SILVIA>

<JULIA>	<85%>
	Almost as well as I do know myself:
	To think upon her woes, I do protest
	That I have wept a hundred several times.
</JULIA>

<SILVIA>	<85%>
	Belike, she thinks, that Proteus hath forsook her.
</SILVIA>

<JULIA>	<85%>
	I think she doth, and that's her cause of sorrow.
</JULIA>

<SILVIA>	<85%>
	Is she not passing fair?
</SILVIA>

<JULIA>	<85%>
	She hath been fairer, madam, than she is.
	When she did think my master lov'd her well,
	She, in my judgment, was as fair as you;
	But since she did neglect her looking-glass
	And threw her sun-expelling mask away,
	The air hath starv'd the roses in her cheeks
	And pinch'd the lily-tincture of her face,
	That now she is become as black as I.
</JULIA>

<SILVIA>	<86%>
	How tall was she?
</SILVIA>

<JULIA>	<86%>
	About my stature; for, at Pentecost,
	When all our pageants of delight were play'd,
	Our youth got me to play the woman's part,
	And I was trimm'd in Madam Julia's gown,
	Which served me as fit, by all men's judgments,
	As if the garment had been made for me:
	Therefore I know she is about my height.
	And at that time I made her weep agood;
	For I did play a lamentable part.
	Madam, 'twas Ariadne passioning
	For Theseus' perjury and unjust flight;
	Which I so lively acted with my tears
	That my poor mistress, moved therewithal,
	Wept bitterly, and would I might be dead
	If I in thought felt not her very sorrow!
</JULIA>

<SILVIA>	<86%>
	She is beholding to thee, gentle youth.—
	Alas, poor lady, desolate and left!
	I weep myself to think upon thy words.
	Here, youth, there is my purse: I give thee this
	For thy sweet mistress' sake, because thou lov'st her.
	Farewell.
</SILVIA>

<JULIA>	<87%>
	And she shall thank you for't, if e'er you know her.—
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit Silvia, with Attendants.>
</STAGE DIR>
	A virtuous gentlewoman, mild and beautiful.
	I hope my master's suit will be but cold,
	Since she respects my mistress' love so much.
	Alas, how love can trifle with itself!
	Here is her picture: let me see; I think,
	If I had such a tire, this face of mine
	Were full as lovely as is this of hers;
	And yet the painter flatter'd her a little,
	Unless I flatter with myself too much.
	Her hair is auburn, mine is perfect yellow:
	If that be all the difference in his love
	I'll get me such a colour'd periwig.
	Her eyes are grey as glass, and so are mine:
	Ay, but her forehead's low, and mine's as high.
	What should it be that he respects in her
	But I can make respective in myself,
	If this fond Love were not a blinded god?
	Come, shadow, come, and take this shadow up,
	For 'tis thy rival. O thou senseless form!
	Thou shalt be worshipp'd, kiss'd, lov'd, and ador'd,
	And, were there sense in his idolatry,
	My substance should be statue in thy stead.
	I'll use thee kindly for thy mistress' sake,
	That us'd me so; or else, by Jove I vow,
	I should have scratch'd out your unseeing eyes,
	To make my master out of love with thee.
<STAGE DIR>
<Exit.>
</STAGE DIR>

</JULIA>

</SCENE 4>

</ACT 4>

<ACT 5>


<SCENE 1>
<Milan. An Abbey.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Eglamour.>
</STAGE DIR>
<EGLAMOUR>	<88%>
	The sun begins to gild the western sky,
	And now it is about the very hour
	That Silvia at Friar Patrick's cell should meet me.
	She will not fail; for lovers break not hours,
	Unless it be to come before their time,
	So much they spur their expedition.
	See, where she comes.

</EGLAMOUR>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Silvia.>
</STAGE DIR>
	Lady, a happy evening!
<SILVIA>	<88%>
	Amen, amen! go on, good Eglamour,
	Out at the postern by the abbey-wall.
	I fear I am attended by some spies.
</SILVIA>

<EGLAMOUR>	<88%>
	Fear not: the forest is not three leagues off;
	If we recover that, we're sure enough.
</EGLAMOUR>
<STAGE DIR>
<Exeunt.>
</STAGE DIR>

</SCENE 1>


<SCENE 2>
<The Same. A Room in the Duke's Palace.>
<STAGE DIR>
<Enter Thurio, Proteus, and Julia.>
</STAGE DIR>
<THURIO>	<89%>
	Sir Proteus, what says Silvia to my suit?
</THURIO>

<PROTEUS>	<89%>
	O, sir, I find her milder than she was;
	And yet she takes exceptions at your person.
</PROTEUS>

<THURIO>	<89%>
